Shares of Grubhub (GRUB) seesawed Friday as Amazon (AMZN) said it will expand its online food ordering and delivery business through a partnership with Olo.XOlo provides an online food ordering and delivery platform, saying it has an "exclusive network" of more than 200 restaurant brands across 40,000 locations and with more than 60 million customers. Its says its clients include Chipotle (CMG). Shake Shack (SHAK) and Wingstop (WING)."This integration will enable Amazon Restaurants to onboard new restaurants with ease, as well as quickly add more new choices and delivery options for customers," Gus Lopez, general manager of Amazon's restaurant division, said in a prepared statement.Grubhub shares fell 3.4% to close at 51.69 on the stock market today. The shares were down more than 5% earlier in the day.Grubhub is the market leader in online food-delivery services, with a market share estimated by Cowen to be 34%, followed by Uber Eats at 20%, Eat24 at 16% and Amazon at 11%.Analysts have expressed concerns that the expansion of Amazon and other competitors in the field of restaurant food-delivery services will raise customer acquisition costs and lower Grubhub profit.IBD'S TAKE: Grubhub is currently one of nine companies on the exclusive IBD Leaderboard platform, a premiums service to help readers pick growths stock. Grubhub stock is up 45% this year but its drop below the 50-day moving average today sends a warning signal for investors.Last month Grubhub announced it would pay $287.5 million in cash to acquire Yelp's (YELP) online food ordering and delivery business, Eat24. Also in early August, Grubhub and Groupon (GRPN) forged a strategic partnership to bring food delivery to Groupon customers across the U.S. In June, Grubhub acquired Foodler, a Boston-based rival, for an undisclosed amount.The scary thing for Grubhub is that Amazon is gaining rapid traction in the food-delivery category despite the fact that its "still acting rationally and not aggressively pricing," said a report from Morgan Stanley in June.RELATED:Why The Grubhub Deal With Yelp Solves A Big Problem For BothAmazon Raises The Pressure On Grubhub As Shares DowngradedAmazon 'Well-Positioned' To Capture Market Share In Grocery Delivery

Shares of fast-casual chain Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) tumbled to 2017 lows following a report that customers said that sickness and two hospitalizations resulted after eating at one of its restaurants in Virginia.XThe drop comes as Chipotle still tries to repair its image following a foodborne illness scare that began in 2015 that caused a retreat among consumers and investors. The CDC declared the E. coli outbreak over in February 2016.The company since then has poured money into instituting new safety protocols, tested out a rewards program and rolled out other marketing efforts to reclaim diners.Business Insider, citing the website iwaspoisoned.com, customers reported vomiting, severe stomach pain, diarrhea, nausea and dehydration after eating at the restaurant. The restaurant, located in Sterling, has been temporarily closed, Business Insider said.Chipotle Mexican Grill fell 4.3% to 374.98 in the stock market today, sinking as low as 362.40, the worst since early November.Business Insider said eight reports were sent to iwaspoisoned.com. According to information there, at least 13 people, who ate there on July 14 and 15, reported illness after eating at the restaurant."We are working with health authorities to understand what the cause may be and to resolve the situation as quickly as possible," Jim Marsden, Chipotle's executive director of food safety, said, according to Business Insider. Marsden said the "reported symptoms are consistent with norovirus," which he said does not come from Chipotle's food supply.Marsden added that the illnesses were confined to that one restaurant and that it would be re-opening on Tuesday after being re-sanitized, Business Insider said.Cowen analyst Andrew Charles said that based on the report, the incident appeared to be isolated and that another E. coli outbreak was unlikely given the quick sanitation time."However, we do not view the pullback as a buying opportunity given uncertainty around consumer reaction to the ensuing headlines," he said.

McDonald's (MCD) on Tuesday said it was seeing higher average checks at restaurants that had mobile order and pay, and that delivery was helping the burger chain in the later portions of the evening that were typically slow.XBut as the burger chain's second-quarter results lifted shares higher, Domino's Pizza (DPZ) crashed on weak international same-store sales and an array of other investor concerns.As McDonald's management did in its first-quarter earnings call, management spent much of its time discussing its efforts to become a more digital company via mobile ordering, delivery and a new restaurant format featuring self-ordering kiosks and table service.CEO Steve Easterbrook said it "will take time to build awareness" of that evolution. But the company said it was seeing higher average checks, so far, from restaurants that have mobile ordering.As for delivery, the company also appeared to be getting an early read on what was working. Sixty percent of orders were being placed late at night. Restaurants near colleges and in downtown and lower-income areas also tended to get more delivery activity than others.Management said it was on track to make mobile order and pay available in 20,000 restaurants worldwide by the end of the year, with more than 5,000 restaurants currently using it around the world. McDonald's also said that the new restaurant format, called "Experience of the Future," would roll out at a faster pace next year.As for the second quarter, the company said it grew sales and guest counts in all of their top nine markets for the first time since 2008, regaining customers along the way."Our gain will result in pain being felt elsewhere," Easterbrook said.In the U.S., $1 sodas and other cheap drink promotions — for smoothies, shakes and blended coffee — helped, as did its "premium" offerings, such as sandwiches that included toppings like pico guacamole and sweet barbecue bacon.Margins, however, fell during the quarter, due to higher labor costs and investments to prepare for digitization and the broader introduction of fresh-patty Quarter Pounders next year.Earnings per share jumped 36% to $1.70, beating estimates for $1.62. Revenue fell 3% to $6.05 billion, compared to views for $6 billion. U.S. same-store sales grew 3.9%, beating forecasts for a 3.2% increase.Shares rocketed 4.75% to close at 159.07 in the stock market today, rebounding to a new all-time high. The stock fell 1.3% to 151.85 on Monday, closing below its 50-day moving average for the first time since early November.Meanwhile, Domino's plunged 10% to 192.40, stabbing through the 50-day line at that key test of investor support, despite reporting earnings per share, revenue and same-store sales that topped estimates.But the pizza chain's strong EPS was largely driven by the tax rate, Nomura-Instinet analyst Mark Kalinowski said in a research note. He also said that domestic company-owned operating margins were lower, and that there was "some disappointment" that no accelerated payouts were announced after a recent recapitalization.And all of that, he said, was "occurring in the context of a stock with higher valuation multiples than most other restaurant stocks."While Domino's mobile ordering platform has helped it stand out in a restaurant industry that has been trapped in a discounting frenzy, and its rewards program and international prospects have been seen as key accelerants for sales. But more analysts have sounded the alarm as the company's shares have marched higher over the past year.Stephens analyst Will Slabaugh, in a research note on Monday, said "we believe most of these positives are priced into the stock."The pizza chain's earnings per share jumped 35% to $1.32, beating estimates for $1.22. Revenue popped 15% to $628.6 million, above views for $613 million. Domestic same-store sales jumped 9.5%, above forecasts for 7.7%.However, international comps rose just 2.6%, "slightly under our expectations," the company said in a release.Once-trendy Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) reported Q2 earnings after the close that beat forecasts while revenue missed. Chipotle, still struggling to recover from food-borne illness outbreaks that started in 2015, has been hit again by reports this month of customers getting sick.Shares closed up 2.5% at 348.62 after hitting a four-year low on Monday, and rallied another 2.5% late.RELATED:Fast Food Makes Its Biggest Change Since The Drive-Thru WindowFor Earnings Trades, These 4 Names Look The Most Actionable

Burger chain Wendy's (WEN) reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings early Wednesday. Jack in the Box (JACK) released fiscal third-quarter earnings after the market close that were even worse than views, though same-store sales topped forecasts.Estimates: A 30% jump in second-quarter earnings per share to 13 cents, as revenue dives 22% to $299 million, according to Zacks Investment Research. Same-store sales were seen up 3.1%, according to Consensus Metrix.Results: Adjusted EPS rose 50% to 15 cents. Sales were $320.3 million. North American same-store sales rose 3.2%.Outlook: Wendy's sees full-year EPS of 45-47 cents. The Zacks consensus is for 47 cents, and that was before Wendy's 2-cent beat in Q2. Wendy's expects 2017 North American same-store to rise 2%-3% with labor costs up 4%. The burger chain still sees $12 billion in sales in 2020.Stock: Shares rose 3.8% to 15.80 in the stock market today. The stock closed Tuesday in a flat base with a 16.76 buy point.Nomura-Instinet analyst Mark Kalinowski suggested in a research note that some mozzarella-related selections — its Fresh Mozzarella Chicken Sandwich or Fresh Mozzarella Chicken Salad — were among Wendy's popular items during the second quarter. As for the third quarter, promotions for Bacon Queso items seem likely to help, he said.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which is testing queso, climbed 0.3% to 334.59.Estimates: Fiscal third-quarter EPS down 2% to $1.05, as revenue dips 2% to $361 million.Results: EPS was 99 cents on sales of $357.8 million. Jack in the Box same-store sales fell 0.2%, but that was better than views for a 0.5% drop. Comps at Qdoba, its Mexican chain, rose 0.5%, above views for a 0.5% drop.Qdoba's comps gain came as "as guests responded favorably to menu innovation," the restaurant operator said.Outlook: The company sees fiscal fourth-quarter same-store sales flat to down 2% at Jack in the Box systemwide, with company-owned Qdoba comps also flat to down 2%.Shares: Jack in the Box shares rose 2% in after-hours trading. The stock closed down 0.2% to 94.68.Jack in the Box also said that its evaluation of whether Qdoba fits in with the broader company was still ongoing."Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC continues to assist the company's Board of Directors in its evaluation of potential alternatives with respect to Qdoba, as well as other ways to enhance shareholder value," the company said in its earnings release.The company added that there was no guarantee that the evaluation would lead to a transaction. Jack in the Box also said it had set no timeline.When Jack in the Box reported first-quarter results in May, it said it was looking at "potential alternatives" regarding Qdoba."It has become more apparent since then that the overall valuation of the company is being impacted by having two different business models," the company said then.The restaurant operator at that time it "lost ground" to some rivals during the first quarter, amid an industrywide value-meal war that took some attention away from Jack in the Box's new menu items. Delayed tax refunds and extended rainfall in California also likely kept diners away, the company said then.IBD'S TAKE: To make up for flagging sales, more quick-service chains are turning to mobile ordering and delivery. McDonald's (MCD) closed flat at 154.92. The company on Tuesday said hopes to broaden its restaurant footprint in China to 4,500 locations by 2022, compared to 2,500 today.Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR) lost 0.8% to 60.70.RELATED:McDonald's Touts Digital Progress; Domino's Falls HardChipotle, Wynn Resorts, U.S. Steel, Hawaiian Earnings TopJack In The Box Beats Views, Eyes 'Potential Alternatives' For QdobaBurger King Parent Restaurant Brands Earnings Top, Sales Miss

The major market indexes moved higher in morning trade Wednesday. The tech-heavy Nasdaq extended its winning streak to nine days as it set another record high, rising 0.4%. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average had more muted advances, up 0.2% and less than 0.1%, respectively.XAmong the Dow industrials, DuPont (DD) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH) paced the advancers, rising about 1% each. DuPont remains in buy range from a 82.40 double-bottom entry, while UnitedHealth touched a new high as its gains from a 164.10 flat-base entry approach 20%.On the downside, IBM (IBM) reported earnings late Tuesday, prompting a 4% fall in shares. Shares reached a new 2017 low, almost 20% off its highs.Among other companies reporting earnings, investment bank Morgan Stanley (MS) jumped 2.5% in the stock market today on its way back above a 46.08 cup-with-handle entry. The company reported stronger-than-expected Q2 results early Wednesday.In the meantime, railroad operator CSX (CSX) dropped 5% to trade under its 50-day line. The company topped Q2 targets late Tuesday, but suggested that shareholders returns may not be as plentiful.Among analyst actions, PayPal (PYPL) was downgraded to hold from buy at SunTrust Robinson Humphrey. Shares fell 2% early as shares slipped back into the 5% buy range from a 55.24 flat-base buy point.Meanwhile, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) received dueling analyst opinions following reports Tuesday that customers were sickened at one of its restaurants in Virginia. BMO Capital Markets and Wells Fargo Securities downgraded the stock to market perform, while Telsey Advisory Group upgraded it to outperform. Shares traded down 2%, following Tuesday's over 4% decline. The stock is approaching its Nov. 2016 lows, over 50% off its 758.61 record high.Among leading stocks, Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX) soared over 24% after the company reported positive Phase 1 and 2 results for its cystic fibrosis treatment. Shares are now over 50% above a 103.83 cup-base entry.Within the IBD 50, chip stocks Lam Research (LRCX) and Applied Materials (AMAT) traded 1.9% and 0.8% higher, respectively. Both stocks are approaching buy points. For Lam Research, the entry is 167.15 out of a cup-shaped base, while Applied Materials has formed a flat base with a 47.96 entry. Both are later-stage bases.On the downside, Medidata Solutions (MDSO) declined 2.5% after Tuesday's brutal reversal from new highs. Shares are approaching their 50-day line.RELATED:Morgan Stanley Flirts With Buy After Earnings, Solid Trading RevenueVertex Catapults 24% On Strong Trial For Cystic Fibrosis DrugChipotle, IBM Divide Analysts; PayPal Downgraded; TransUnion Price HikedDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And Analysis

Wall Street analysts on Wednesday split on restaurant chain Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and tech services firm IBM (IBM) following news Tuesday, while aerospace and defense giant Lockheed Martin (LMT) received a price-target hike after its second-quarter earnings report. Elsewhere, electronic payments firm PayPal (PYPL) got hit with a downgrade and credit-monitoring company TransUnion (TRU) got a price-target increase.XChipotle stock tumbled on reports Tuesday that customers were sickened after eating at one of its restaurants in Virginia. Chipotle is still trying to repair its image after a food-borne illness scare that began in 2015 caused a retreat among consumers and investors.BMO Capital Markets and Wells Fargo Securities each downgraded Chipotle stock to market perform on Wednesday.But Telsey Advisory Group sensed a buying opportunity. It upgraded Chipotle to outperform from market perform and set a price target of 440.Shares in Denver-based Chipotle fell 0.6% to 372.83 in the stock market today, trading at 2017 lows after losing 4.3% to 374.98 on Tuesday.Armonk, N.Y.-based IBM late Tuesday beat views on earnings, but missed on revenue, in its second-quarter financial report. Earnings per share rose 1% year over year, but revenue fell 5%. It was Big Blue's 21st straight quarter of falling revenue vs. a year earlier.RBC Capital Markets reiterated its sector perform rating on IBM stock and cut its price target to 160 from 165.However, BMO Capital Markets upped its price target on IBM to 167 from 165 and maintained its market perform rating.IBM shares fell 4.2% to 147.53 on Wednesday, hitting a 52-week low.RBC Capital Markets raised its price target on Lockheed Martin after the company's Q2 earnings report, but stuck with its sector perform rating on the stock.On Tuesday, Lockheed raised its full-year guidance as increased F-35 sales helped lift second-quarter earnings and revenue well above estimates.RBC upped its target on Lockheed to 289 from 263.Shares of the Bethesda, Md.-based company rose 1.35% to 290.67.Lockheed stock hit an all-time intraday high of 292.97 on Tuesday. It ended the regular session Tuesday down 0.6% to 286.79.Lockheed stock broke out of a 12-week cup base with a buy point of 270 on Feb. 27.SunTrust Robinson Humphrey on Tuesday downgraded PayPal stock to hold.PayPal shares notched a record high of 58.96 on Tuesday. The stock fell 1% to 58.35.San Jose, Calif.-based PayPal is currently ranked No. 35 on the IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks.RBC reiterated its outperform rating on TransUnion and upped its price target on the stock to 46 from 45.TransUnion stock rose 0.7% to 45.31, hitting a new high.Chicago-based TransUnion is ranked No. 36 on the IBD 50 list.

Bulls raked in some small gains midday Friday, as the stock market failed to gain much traction from big banks' earnings beats.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 0.3%, 0.2% and 0.1% respectively. The small cap Russell 2000 inched up 0.1%. Volume in the stock market was down vs. the previous session's pace.XJPMorgan Chase (JPM) reported quarterly results before the open, topping the Street's consensus view on earnings by 15%. Revenue continued to rise at single-digit pace, up 8%. Wells Fargo (WFC) beat views by almost 6%, and Citigroup (C) by 5%, according to William O'Neil + Co. data.Despite the favorable performance, the market found reasons for pessimism. JPMorgan's trading revenue fell 14%, which was worse than what analysts estimated. For Wells Fargo, the negative niche was the mortgage business, which fell about 19%. Citigroup's problem was weakness in the credit-card space.This bent toward finding the flaw in the details and ignoring the overall increases is a sign of stock-market weakness. In a stronger market, the flaws are brushed off. Pressure on the uptrend hasn't been lifted, and the negative reaction of bank stocks confirmed it.Along with banks, retail stocks were among the day's losers.Upscale home furnisher RH (RH) dropped more than 8% in fast trade before cutting losses slightly. After bottoming in February, RH broke out of an awkward-looking consolidation in June. The stock is now about 9% above a 60.21 buy point. The Street expects RH to deliver a 44% earnings-per-share gain to $1.82 in fiscal 2018 ending in January. The stock has a 95 Composite Rating, which puts RH in the top 5 percentile among all the stocks in IBD's database. The home furnishings retail group is in the top 20 among 197 industry groups.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) sank 1% in strong volume. The battered stock broke out of a consolidation in late March, advanced 14% in about five weeks, and then round-tripped in June to back under the buy point.Blue chip stocks were mostly up. In the Dow Jones industrial average, Visa (V) crept above a 96.70 buy point. Volume was only average.RELATED:Two Key Financial Stocks Break Out As Banks Falter7 Chinese Stocks That Fund Managers Are Buying

The Dow Jones industrial average ran ahead of the stock market again Wednesday, as Boeing (BA) gave the industrials a market-leading gain.The Dow was up 0.4% and climbed to a record high. The average was the only major index that had not made a record high already this week. Dow component Boeing gapped up more than 8% to an all-time high after the aerospace and defense giant reported quarterly results and gave a bullish outlook.XThe S&P 500 rose a fraction and the Nasdaq 0.1% as both reached record highs as well. Volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE compared with the same time Tuesday. Small caps lagged, with the Russell 2000 off by 0.2%.Energy stocks were one of the day's leaders as U.S. crude prices jumped 1.5% to $48.61 a barrel, the highest in nearly eight weeks. The Energy Department reported today that U.S. crude inventories fell sharply last week.Chip stocks also drew some institutional interest, accounting for some of the gains in higher-than-normal volume.Broadcom (AVGO) moved just past the 256.88 buy point of a flat base. The price increase seemed limp and volume was well below normal — two characteristics that dampened an otherwise bullish move. Lam Research (LRCX) is trying to break out past a 167.15 buy point.In the software sector, Electronic Arts (EA) climbed above the 116.14 buy point of a flat base. Afternoon volume was about one-fourth higher than normal, not quite as much as you normally find with successful breakouts. BofA/Merrill Lynch upgraded the video game publisher to buy from neutral and hiked the price target to 131 from 125. EA reports earnings after Thursday's close.Zions Bancorp (ZION) broke out of a cup-with-handle base. The Salt Lake City-based regional bank cleared the 45.38 buy point in hefty volume.Three restaurants fell sharply in heavy volume. Domino's Pizza (DPZ) fell 2.5%, adding to yesterday's 10% plunge following quarterly results. Bloomin' Brands (BLMN) plunged 8%, undercutting a base it had been forming. Operating earnings of 28 cents a share met expectations, while sales fell 4% to $1.03 billion for the parent of Outback Steakhouse.Beleaguered Chipotle (CMG) was down 1% and still around the lowest share price since April 2013.RELATED:Boeing On Track For Best Day In 8 Years On Huge Cash Gains, Profit OutlookOil Rises For Third Day As U.S. Stockpiles Tumble, Production Falls2 Defense Giants Boost Views After Strong Earnings

The major market indexes advanced higher in early trading Wednesday. The Dow Jones industrial average led the way, jumping 0.5% to record highs. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 moved up 0.3% and 0.1%, respectively.XAmong the Dow industrials, Boeing (BA) soared over 8% after its Q2 earnings topped estimates early Wednesday. Meanwhile, the company raised its full-year earnings and cash flow guidance. The airplane maker was now trading over 20% above a 185.81 flat-base entry, offering investors a potential profit-taking opportunity.Chip stocks rallied across the board in early trading after multiple positive earnings results within the industry. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Texas Instruments (TXN) both surpassed analyst estimates, prompting shares to jump 9% and 2.4%, respectively.Leading chip stocks Applied Materials (AMAT) and Broadcom (AVGO) moved up 1.3% and 1.2%, respectively. Applied Materials is approaching a 47.96 cup base buy point, while Broadcom is breaking out above a 256.88 flat-base entry.Meanwhile, graphics chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) advanced 2.6% as it reached a new high in the stock market today.Chipotle (CMG) turned negative, falling 0.7%, after rising as much as 2% in early trading after reporting strong Q2 results late Tuesday. The burrito maker still has a lot of work to do to recover from its recent sell-off. Shares have fallen almost 33% in a little over two months.Casino operator Wynn Resorts (WYNN) declined over 6% after its Q2 earnings missed estimates by one penny. BMO Capital upgraded the heavy machinery company to outperform from market perform. Shares pierced their 50-day line.RELATED:Week In Review: Netflix Soars, Amazon Hits Home Depot, GE Dives On OutlookAnalysts Sour On Goldman, Dig Caterpillar, Mixed On Blue ApronDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisFANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google

The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 index hit new highs as techs continued to reassert market leadership. Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and Microsoft (MSFT) all hit record highs. Netflix soared on subscriber gains while Amazon will sell Kenmore appliances from Sears (SHLD), sending the latter sharply higher but hitting several retailers, including the Dow's Home Depot (HD). The Dow Jones industrial average also was hit by General Electric and banks, though blue-chip Visa (V) and American Express (AXP) continued the good news for payment stocks.XThe Nasdaq composite rose 1.2%, hitting record highs during the week, rising 10 straight sessions through Thursday. Netflix and other FANG stocks, such as Facebook and Amazon, contributed. The S&P 500 index climbed 0.5%, also hitting fresh highs during the week. Dow industrials fell 0.3%, weighed down by Goldman Sachs (GS), General Electric (GE) and Home Depot.Internet television network Netflix added 5.2 million net new subscribers in the June quarter vs. Wall Street's consensus estimate of 3.22 million. It also guided higher for the current quarter, with a forecast of 4.4 million net new subscribers, topping the consensus view for 3.97 million. Bulls pointed to its strong subscriber growth, while bears voiced caution about its ballooning video-content obligations, including original TV series like "Stranger Things" and "Glow." Netflix ended Q2 with 103.95 million subscribers worldwide, including 51.92 million in the U.S. and 52.03 million in foreign markets. Netflix's international streaming subscribers topped those in the U.S. for the first time in Q2.Netflix skyrocketed 17% to record highs for the week.Sears will sell Alexa-enabled Kenmore appliances via Amazon, sending its shares soaring on Thursday but the gave up most of that gains on Friday. But Whirlpool (WHR) and major sellers of appliances Home Depot, Lowe's (LOW) and Best Buy (BBY) were hit. Home improvement chains Home Depot and Lowe's had been seen as Amazon-proof, or at least Amazon-resistant. Best Buy, which has bounced back in recent years from Amazon's initial onslaught, was hurt earlier this month on news that Amazon is creating a Geek Squad rival.Amazon appears to be getting more government attention as its size and scope grow, with an FTC probe and antitrust rumblings.Software giant Microsoft earned 98 cents excluding items for the June fiscal fourth quarter, up 42% year over year and well above views for 71 cents. Revenue rose 9% to $24.7 billion after forecasts for $24.27 billion. Microsoft credited demand for cloud-computing services like Azure and Office 365 as well as its acquisition of LinkedIn. But the Dow component gave cautious guidance for the current quarter. Shares dipped Friday but remain in buy range.RELATED:Microsoft Crushes Earnings Estimates; Stock Dips On OutlookGeneral Electric fell 2.9% on Friday after saying full-year EPS is trending to the low end of its $1.60-$1.70 target, citing oil and gas weakness. GE reported smaller earnings and revenue declines for Q2, though some analysts cited some weakness below the headline figures. Fellow industrial conglomerate Honeywell International (HON) also beat on top and bottom lines, but guided full-year estimates slightly higher. Honeywell shares rose Friday, retaking a buy point.RELATED:General Electric Stock Dives On Earnings OutlookAmerican Express beat on the top and bottom lines, though provisions for losses jumped 26% due to loan-portfolio growth and a rise in the rate for lending write-offs. Visa earnings also topped, with strong cross-border travel – helped by the stronger dollar – and global payment volumes driving results, according to Mizuho analyst Thomas McCrohan. The company also hiked its full-year revenue growth outlook above views. Visa and American Express, both Dow components, rose 2.8% and 0.4%, respectively, with both still in buy range.TD Ameritrade (AMTD) stock broke out from a long consolidation on July 18 as the online broker beat on both the top and bottom lines, even as industry trading fees for stocks and ETFs have plunged this year. Charles Schwab (SCHW) that day matched views, with shares falling below a 42.71 buy point that they had cleared in late June. E-Trade (ETFC) shares gapped up to make a new 52-week high on Friday after the company scored an overall beat Thursday. Shares are now out of buy range.Chip-gear maker ASML (ASML) and wireless-communications chipmaker Qualcomm (QCOM) were the first major semiconductor industry players to report June-quarter earnings this year. ASML rose to record highs after posting better-than-expected sales and earnings during the second quarter. Qualcomm disappointed with its current-quarter profit outlook that came up short of views, even though it beat estimates for its fiscal Q3. Apple (AAPL) chip-supplier Skyworks (SWKS) reported better-than-expected fiscal Q3 sales and earnings and guided higher for the current period.Drug giants Novartis (NVS) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) reported better-than-expected earnings Tuesday. Dow component J&J reported adjusted income of $1.83 a share, topping views by 4 cents. But sales of $18.84 billion were light. Novartis' $1.22 a share, excluding various items on $12.24 billion in sales, topped analyst views.Both drug stocks rose during the week, but were both still in buy range as of Friday's close.Goldman Sachs' fixed-income trade revenue plunged 40% in Q2, the second straight quarter that the trading-heavy bank said it misread the market. Weaker trading and net-interest income also hurt Bank of America (BAC), though Fed rate hikes have helped the bank and it said it expected net-interest income to rise in Q3. Morgan Stanley (MS) reported that trading revenue fell, but less so than rivals. JPMorgan (JPM) and Citigroup (C) have also signaled caution amid slow loan growth and longer-term bond yields, which can indicate flagging confidence over the chances for long-term economic gains. Morgan Stanley cleared a buy point while Goldman undercut its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Check Point Software (CHKP) reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings on Thursday, but gave weak guidance for the current Q3. Check Point tumbled 7.2% that day, falling below its 50-day moving average. Check Point on Wednesday briefly topped a buy point but closed below that trigger. So did four other cybersecurity stocks that day. Those stocks, along with Proofpoint (PFPT), retreated modestly on Check Point's warning.United Airlines (UAL) on Tuesday offered a disappointing third-quarter unit-revenue forecast as airline competition picks up heading further into the summer, sending its shares plunging 10.4%. Delta Air Lines (DAL) and American Airlines (AAL), which have remained bullish on the key metric, fell significantly as well. United said it could take at least several months out for plans — like expanded service to different parts of the U.S. and the rollout of cheaper "basic economy" fares — to pay off.The No. 1 U.S. health insurer's earnings per share rose 25.5%, topping forecasts. Revenue grew 8% to $50.05 billion, roughly in line, though it was the smallest gain in nine quarters.  UnitedHealth (UNH) has exited the ObamaCare exchanges, though it's a big player in Medicare and Medicaid coverage. The Optum services unit saw a 9.9% revenue rise. UnitedHealth now sees adjusted full-year profit of $9.75-$9.90 a share. Analysts had expected $9.81 before Q2's results.UnitedHealth rose 2.6%, with Republicans' health care struggles also influencing shares of insurers and hospitals.RELATED: UnitedHealth Raises Full-Year Target After Q2 Earnings Jump 25.5%Top U.S. rail companies topped quarterly forecasts, but CSX (CSX) said crude oil train shipments have fallen to zero and hinted that returns to shareholders may be more cautious. Union Pacific (UNP) predicted nearly flat volumes in Q3 as coal shipments stabilize, but it still sees second-half volumes improving over the first half. Kansas City Southern (KSU) benefited from auto production and energy market reforms in Mexico. CSX fell 6.2% for the week while Union Pacific lost 4.3%. Kansas City Southern edged up 0.4%.Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX) stock rocketed 21% to an all-time high Wednesday on strong Phase 1 and 2 data in the trial of a cystic fibrosis treatment. The triple-drug combo aims to treat the genetic disease's underlying cause.Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) easily topped analysts' second-quarter views Thursday with adjusted income of $5.95 per share on $756 million in sales. Shares of the maker of robot-surgical systems fell 3% Friday afternoon.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) shares tumbled 12.8% to a four-year low on reports that the fast-casual chain temporarily closed a restaurant in Virginia following reports that diners there had gotten sick. The once-trendy fast-casual burrito eatery has been trying to mend its reputation and sales after a food-borne illness scare that began in 2015.Harley-Davidson (HOG) cut its motorcycle shipment outlook to 241,000 to 246,000 units to dealers this year, a 6% to 8% drop, down from prior guidance for a flat to modest decline. The iconic motorcycle brand reported a 4.5% EPS decline but that was better than estimates for $1.37. Sales slid 5% to $1.77 billion. Retail sales of new motorcycles tumbled 9.3% amid "weak industry conditions." Shares fell 6.5%.

Analyst actions on Monday included an upgrade for Costco (COST), downgrade for Grubhub (GRUB) and price-target changes for PayPal (PYPL), Micron Technology (MU) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).X Raymond James upgraded the warehouse club to outperform from market perform, with a 173 price target. Analyst Budd Bugatch sees the 13% share decline on the Amazon (AMZN) deal to buy Whole Foods (WFM) as unwarranted. He expects minimal effect on Costco's business model that's benefiting from member growth and strong renewal rates.Shares of Costco rose about 2% to 160.20 on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Wall Street is still expecting another bidder to emerge for Whole Foods, which could force Amazon to raise its price. Here's who might and might not make a competing bid.Morgan Stanley downgraded the online food ordering company to equal weight from overweight, paring its price target to 43 from 47. Analyst Brian Nowak sees competitor UberEats "gaining traction" as well as a serious threat from Amazon restaurant delivery. He notes that scaled restaurants could subsidize one-hour PrimeNow delivery.Wedbush analyst Aaron Turner has said that Grubhub would be a logical buyout target for Amazon after Whole Foods.Shares of Grubhub sank 6.4% to 44.64, below the 46.93 buy point cleared last week.BTIG raised its price target for the online payments company to 63 from 53, keeping a buy rating. Analyst Mark Palmer sees "increasing user engagement" as an indication of sustainable growth, with PayPal's user base leading more merchants to adopt it as a payment option.Last week, Pacific Crest Securities upgraded PayPal to overweight, saying that it will reap upside from recent deals with Visa (V) and Mastercard (MA), while threats from Apple (AAPL) Pay and banks are overblownShares of PayPal dipped 1.1% to 53.71.Cowen raised its price target on the memory chip maker to 38 from 34, keeping an outperform rating, ahead of its Q3 earnings report on Thursday after the close. Analyst Timothy Arcuri expects another "beat and raise" and thinks the current valuation of the stock doesn't reflect the sustainability of its business.Shares of Micron rose 2.4% to 32.50, but pulled back after hitting a two-year high intraday of 32.96Wells Fargo cut its price target on the fast-casual burrito chain to 470 from 530, keeping an outperform rating. Analyst Jeff Farmer cited the "return of commodity inflation" on top of wage inflation. He cut his 2017 EPS estimate to $8.37 from $9.18, though that remains above the consensus $8.04.Chipotle last week slashed guidance, sending shares down nearly 8%.Shares of Chipotle fell 0.3% to 414.01.RELATED:PayPal Worries Over Apple Overblown, New Deals Help: AnalystWhat Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailGrubhub Stock Nibbles At Highs, But Uber Wants Its LunchTwo Major Chip Stocks Break Out To Buy Points While Another TumblesStocks Lower, But Medicals Climb; Chipotle Tumbles

XMcDonald's (MCD) cheap cheeseburgers and digital tinkering are getting a thumbs up from Wall Street.Cowen analyst Andrew Charles feels good about the Happy Meal maker's same-store sales growth prospects in the key U.S. market, thanks to its value-menu promotions and development of mobile ordering and in-store tech advancements.He upgraded the Happy Meal maker to outperform from market perform and bumped up his price target to 180 from 142."Over the last two years, (McDonald's) has done a great job launching popular innovations within the context of simplifying the menu, while introducing more effective value initiatives that have recently begun to improve the brand's value perceptions," wrote Charles in a note to clients Tuesday.And consumer-facing technology that McD's has in the works, like mobile ordering, kiosk ordering and table delivery, "should bear fruit in 2018," he said, positing that the "operational enhancements" of the fast-food giant's mobile ordering capabilities will set it apart, i.e. curbside pickup won't stop customers in the drive-thru lane from getting their orders quickly.McDonald's shares closed up 0.6% at 154.07 the stock market today. Peer Restaurant Brands International (QSR), which owns Burger King, Tim Hortons and Popeye's, dipped 0.3%.Meanwhile, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) reaffirmed second-quarter and full-year guidance in a filing late Monday.The burrito and taco chain, on the tail end of a recovery from its food-borne illness outbreaks, said in late April that it expects same-store sales growth in the high-single digits and 195 to 210 new restaurant openings in 2017. But it now sees slightly higher marketing and operation costs, and as a result expects other operating costs as a percentage of sales for Q2 "to be at or slightly higher than reported for the first quarter."Nomura analyst Mark Kalinowski took his price target down to 480 from 510 and cut his estimates on the news.Chipotle shares tumbled 7.3%.RELATED:Is It Safe To Buy Chipotle Again? Analysts Weigh In On Q1 Earnings

XThe Nasdaq composite followed up Monday's bullish gain in lower volume with a 0.5% decline in higher volume in late trading Tuesday.The Dow eased 0.1%, buoyed by strength in Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE), while the S&P 500 lost 0.5%, hurt by weakness in oil and gas names.A distribution day was taking shape for the Nasdaq in the stock market today because volume was tracking quite a bit higher than Monday's level.Benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude oil hit a multimonth low, settling at $43.23 a barrel, down 2.2%.A big biotech rally lifted shares of IBD 50 name Regeneron (REGN). Shares popped 6% to 498.60, but it's well extended from a 453.06 buy point.Other biotechs on the move included Celgene (CELG). Shares rose 1% to 126.55. The right side of its current base shows nice accumulation (higher-volume gains) as Celgene approaches a 127.74 buy point.Contract research organizations, which provide outsourced services to biotech and Big Pharma, got a lift after Parexel (PRXL) agreed to be taken private by a private equity firm for $5 billion. Shares of Parexel rose 4% to 87.15.Tesla (TSLA) was near session lows but still rose 0.6% after a report released by the National Safety Transportation Board found no fault in Tesla's automated pilot system involved in a highly publicized May 2016 crash of a Model S in which its driver was killed.Chipotle (CMG) tumbled 7% after the company offered up lukewarm same-store sales guidance and also warned of higher costs.In earnings news, Lennar (LEN) jumped nearly 6% early but faded. Shares gained 1.5% to 53.52 after the company reported better-than-expected earnings and its third-straight quarter of accelerating earnings growth.Financials were under some pressure as the 10-year Treasury yield eased 2 basis points to 2.16%, but losses in the Select Sector SPDR Financial (XLF) were tame at 0.6%. It's setting up in a nice base with a 25.39 buy point, while many other financials have done a good job holding gains after recent breakouts.RELATED:Netflix Price Target Hiked, Nvidia Upgraded, Nike PT LoweredLennar Earnings Top Q2 Views; Shares Eye Buy PointThese Biotechs Are Leading The Sector To A 3-Month High Today

Gripping a Starbucks (SBUX) to-go cup on the train to work may not be ingrained in Chinese culture the way it is for many Americans, but one analyst is willing to bet that the coffee giant can instead make the sit-down cafe experience a popular one in China."With almost no scaled competitors, we believe Starbucks can do for cafe culture in China what Yum (Brands) did for fast food," wrote Mizuho analyst Jeremy Scott in an initiation note on the company. "Create it."Starbucks has made no secret about its aggressive growth plans in China, which include doubling its store count there to 5,000 by 2021.For now, tea remains the hot drink of choice for 99% of Chinese consumers at home.But Scott said Starbucks' positioning as a "third place" outside of home and work "has spawned a growing cafe culture in higher tier cities," one that has made going out for coffee one of "cultured indulgence."And that's already prompting a shift in how Chinese consumers get their caffeine fix. Outside of the house, coffee and tea consumption are now about equal, wrote analysts, citing Euromonitor and MSUSA estimates.Shares of Starbucks dipped 0.1% to 62.19 on the stock market today, their fifth straight decline. Starbucks is near the top end of buy territory after overextending for a few weeks. The stock broke out of a flat base with 59.64 entry point in late April.Calling Starbucks the "most promising growth model in the industry," Mizuho's Scott initiated coverage on the stock with a buy rating and 75 price target. He also highlighted the promise of mobile-order-and-pay once the company overcomes its workflow issues (read: recent issues of in-store congestion from the popularity of the order-ahead feature).If all goes according to plan, maybe someday China's coffee drinkers will be just like Americans: hogging the good tables for hours as they work on their screenplays at Starbucks.Meanwhile, Scott — who initiated coverage on a number of restaurant names including McDonald's (MCD), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Yum Brands (YUM) — looked less favorably upon Starbucks' main U.S. competitor, Dunkin' Brands (DNKN), starting it off with a neutral rating and 56 price target."As the take-away coffee market grows increasingly divided between value and premium, Dunkin's positioning becomes increasingly challenged as it straddles value-orientation and upmarket beverages," he wrote, adding that increasing competition in the form of promotional activity from McDonald's and others "should continue to drive menu deflation in our view."Shares of Dunkin' Brands, which owns Baskin Robbins and Dunkin' Donuts, sank 2.7% to 56.93, falling out of buy range after clearing a 57.90 entry point from a cup-with-handle base in late May.Yum Brands, which spun off Yum China (YUMC) last year, fell 1.2%. McDonald's rose 5 cents to 151.49.RELATED:Where Does Starbucks Go From Here? More Unicorn Frappuccinos?

XIf an individual investor is to win consistently in the stock market, he or she must stay a step ahead of the game.While investors should always heed current conditions, they also should have a Plan B ready for when the market turns. In the current confirmed uptrend, this means investors must know what they will do when the correction comes.The market hasn't had a correction of 10% or more since late 2015 to mid-February 2016, when the Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 pulled back 18% and 14% respectively.When the next pullback comes, here are five things to consider:No. 1: Be realistic. Recognition that a pullback is underway will emerge as the correction unfolds. No one can pick the market's turn at its birth, but an investor can thin holdings as they show weakness.No. 2: Expect change. Right now, chips and the mega caps have been the leaders. The leaders of one bull trend rarely repeat in the next uptrend. So, when a correction knocks stocks around, and then the market begins a new uptrend, don't expect the same leadership.No. 3: Look for resilience. In "How to Make Money in Stocks" William J. O'Neil wrote, "In a correction during a bull, or upward-trending market, the growth stocks that decline the least (percentage-wise) are usually your best selections." So, when a correction comes, study the industry groups to see what is holding together best.No. 4: Watch for new highs. "Once a general market decline is definitely over, the first stocks that bounce back to new price highs are almost always your authentic leaders," O'Neil wrote.No. 5: Scan the breakouts. When a follow-through day confirms a new uptrend is underway, leaders sometimes break out on the follow-through day itself, or they emerge in the first few weeks.Consider the 2010 pullback and rally. After a 20% run-up in the Nasdaq from February 2010 to late April 2010, the market started to correct. From early May through August, the Nasdaq pulled back in a choppy fashion.Then on Sept. 1, Day 4 of the attempted rally, the Nasdaq flashed a follow-through sign (1) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) topped a 154.53 entry the same day. Chipotle's stock rose 70% in three months.Apple (AAPL) cleared a 266.09 buy point in a double-bottom consolidation Sept. 13. Apple rose 37% in five months. Lululemon Athletica (LULU) cleared a 43.47 buy point Sept. 14 in a double-bottom pattern. Lululemon's stock rose 96% in five months. China-based internet portal Sina (SINA), cleared a 46.02 entry Sept. 15 and rose 107% in five months. China-based internet search engine Baidu (BIDU) topped 88.42 on Sept. 20 and gained 30% in two months.RELATED:Waiting For A Big Pullback In The Stock Market?How To Spot Stock Market TopsCan President Trump Revive Ronald Reagan's Stock Market Magic?Are Fewer Stocks Or More Stocks Better For Your Portfolio In The Long Run?

Flying drones drop Chipotle (CMG) burritos, 7-Eleven Slurpees and Amazon.com (AMZN) sundries on doorsteps while robots scoot down sidewalks to deliver Domino's (DPZ) pizzas and other meals to homes.These images might conjure thoughts that we've finally entered the age of mechanical gofers, or that we'll soon farm out a slew of summer jobs to robots. But hold on to your transformers for a bit.While companies such as Amazon are pushing the idea of delivery bots — the e-commerce giant now says it wants to start using them for commercial deliveries by the end of 2017 — widespread use of robotic couriers could be years away.Consumers in a few regions and limited test markets are the only ones seeing the benefits, and possible drawbacks, of machines that carry food, drinks and everyday goods to their door. And the tests are raising more questions than they're answering.For one, are these deliveries just publicity stunts designed to show consumer brands are on the cutting edge of technology? Or do they show a future where it might be practical for robots to routinely make home deliveries?"Is there a legitimate business model here? Is there a real need for this? Can I measure ROI (return on investment)? Those are the questions that need to be answered," ABI Research analyst Dan Kara told Investor's Business Daily.It's not clear right now that a robot can handle deliveries as fast or better than a human. Further, the long-term costs of developing and deploying bot couriers is unclear. Plus, companies have yet to figure out how to protect that mechanical merchandise.In other words, it could be some time before you'll see robot-delivered pizza on a grand scale. For now, delivery bots are very much an experiment, with companies and consumers in a dot-com-esque honeymoon phase. Some companies are dreaming big, and harsh reality has yet to set in.Amazon got the public excited about the idea of aerial delivery drones when it announced its Prime Air initiative in December 2013. It wasn't until this past March that it conducted its first drone delivery in the U.S., transporting a bottle of sunscreen to a resort in Palm Springs, Calif., during a tech conference.Still, Amazon is sticking to its vision, and hopes to deliver small packages of up to 5 pounds in 30 minutes or less by drones that can fly up to 50 miles per hour.Retail behemoth Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) has expressed interest in making drone deliveries as has Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL). Google has a drone delivery initiative called Project Wing that is looking to develop automated aircraft to deliver everything from consumer goods to emergency medicine. Last September, Project Wing conducted a test on the Virginia Tech campus, delivering Chipotle burritos by air to students and employees.The movement has prompted delivery specialists, such as FedEx (FDX) and United Parcel Service (UPS), to evaluate their options. Self-driving trucks eventually are expected to deploy small robots to deliver packages to your door. But aerial drones are considered a better solution for greater distances, especially in rural and hard-to-reach places.Gartner analyst Gerald Van Hoy believes that commercial drone deliveries in the U.S. are a few years away, but within sight. Business-to-business drone deliveries might help pave the way for consumer deliveries, Van Hoy told IBD. It is easy to calculate the payback of sending a drone to deliver a tool to a worker in the field vs. sending a human driver, he said.By the same token, business uses of wheeled delivery robots could lead to consumer applications as the technology improves and the value proposition becomes clear, ABI's Kara said.Venture capital firms and corporations are funding robotic delivery initiatives on the chance that they could become a huge deal. But that might not happen, Kara said, noting that many millions of dollars were invested in corporate telepresence robots — sort of interoffice gofers — before that market fizzled.Analysts point out robotic delivery systems could help restaurants that struggle to find enough delivery workers. They also could be a hedge against rising employee costs, especially with the Fight For $15 political movement to raise the minimum wage.Ultimately, there will be questions on regulatory restrictions and finding the right business model. Tech companies and government regulators are working out how best to allow delivery robots in the public air space and on streets and walkways. The biggest questions are business-related, and whether delivery bots are economically feasible, Kara said.A raft of companies have developed robotics, including Google, Northrop Grumman (NOC) and Roomba maker iRobot (IRBT). A few private companies, however, have come to the forefront when it comes to delivery bots.They include two startups, Marble and Starship Technologies, two private robotic firms. In April, Yelp's (YELP) Eat24 food delivery service partnered with Marble to test robotic deliveries with a handful of restaurants in a couple San Francisco neighborhoods.The Eat24-branded robots are the size of a shopping cart. They navigate city sidewalks with artificial intelligence, cameras, ultrasonic sensors and light detection, or lidar, sensors. Typical deliveries are within a mile. Customers are sent a four-digit code to open the four-wheeled robot's storage compartment.Rival delivery robot firm Starship started making food deliveries in Silicon Valley in March. Starship also has conducted trials in Austin, Texas; Portland, Ore.; and Washington, D.C., as well as a dozen European countries.Starship robots are roughly the size of large picnic coolers and have six wheels. In March, Starship announced a deal with Domino's to deliver pizzas by robot within a one-mile radius around its outlets in select German and Dutch cities.While sidewalk robots are seen as the best solution for short-distance deliveries in cities, some politicians don't like the idea.In May, San Francisco Supervisor Norman Yee introduced legislation that would ban autonomous delivery robots from city sidewalks, largely for safety concerns. Those concerns range from machines getting in the way of cars and pedestrians to lawbreakers stealing or vandalizing them.On the other side of the coin, humanitarian concerns are a consideration.Last September, UPS partnered with drone maker CyPhy Works to test the use of drones to make commercial deliveries of packages to remote locations. The companies staged a mock delivery of urgently needed medicine from Beverly, Mass., to Children's Island, about three miles off the Atlantic coast. In the mock scenario, the drone successfully carried an asthma inhaler to a child at a camp on the island.Zipline International is using fixed-wing drones to deliver medical products, such as blood products and rabies treatments, to remote locations. It currently is serving 21 hospitals in Rwanda. Its drones can deliver to any site within about 47 miles, or 93 miles round-trip. As of November, Zipline had raised $43 million in funding."The humanitarian side of drone deliveries is starting to be talked about a lot more," Gretchen West, co-executive director of the Commercial Drone Alliance, told IBD. "It's delivering medicine, aid and supplies after a catastrophe or to remote locations where roads could be washed out. We're starting to see a lot more of that, not just consumer delivery."Already, several companies are making headway deploying robots to deliver items in structured environments like hospitals and hotels, he said. Pittsburgh-based Aethon makes delivery robots for hospitals to ferry food, medicine, towels and other items. San Jose, Calif.-based Savioke makes robots for delivering items to consumers in hotels and high-rise buildings.West says drone deliveries to consumers will happen, but will take longer for the puzzle pieces to come together. Right now, commercial drones in the U.S. face strict limitations.For instance, they can't fly over people, must be operated within visual line of sight, and can't fly at night. Many of these problems will be solved by an unmanned aircraft system traffic management system under development by NASA, she said."It will take several years," West said. "None of this moves very quickly."

X The earnings dump this week from the restaurant industry continued today with better-than-expected profits after the close from Shake Shack (SHAK), Wingstop (WING), Del Taco (TACO) and El Pollo Loco (LOCO). But Shake Shack plunged on weak same-store sales.Estimates: The fast-casual burger chain is expected to report first-quarter earnings per share of 8 cents, flat from a year ago. Revenue is seen leaping 38% to $74.7 million.Results: EPS rose 25% to 10 cents. Sales grew 42% to $76.7 million. Same-store sales slid 2.5%.Outlook: Shake Shack raised its full-year revenue target to $351 million-$355 million from $349 million-$353 million. Analysts had expected $356 million. Shake Shack now sees flat comps vs. prior guidance for a 2%-3% rise."We are clearly dissatisfied with our comp result in Q1, but as a reminder our small comp base is made up of only 32 Shacks, the majority of which exist in the Northeast region which was most affected by cold weather and the holiday shift in March," CEO Randy Garutti said in a statement.Stock: Shares plunged nearly 7% to 30.85 in late trading. Shack Shack had closed down 2.6% to 33.16 on the stock market today. Habit Restaurants (HABT), which topped earnings views late Wednesday, rallied 1.6% to 19.20.Buckingham research analyst John Zolidis, who expected a 1% bump in Shake Shack's same-store sales, said the results would have to compete with a strong showing a year ago, when nicer weather and the introduction of Chick n' Shack helped results.Shake Shack, which began trading in 2015, has been opening new stores. That has raised concerns about whether the company's plans to move beyond where it is already popular will pay off.Goldman Sachs, in a note last month quoted by CNBC, cited "declining novelty and therefore excitement around unit opens as a risk to new store productivity, and … cannibalization as a growing risk to traffic trends at SHAK, as the company continues to add density in markets outside of N.Y."Zolidis said new-store results could be better than expected, but added "we continue to expect that new unit performance will decline over time due to geographic expansion into less productive markets."Shake Shack stepped up expansion plans. It expects 12 net openings of licensed locations this year, as opposed to 11 earlier. The company now expects to add 23-24 U.S. company-owned stores, up from 22-23."We remain committed to executing our strategy of growing in premier locations, investing in our teams and delivering a great guest experience," Garutti said.Estimates: First-quarter EPS down 18% to 14 cents, with revenue up 5% to $98.72 million.Results: EPS fell 6% to 16 cents as sales climbed to $99.8 million. Same-store sales fell 0.3%.Stock: Shares rose 2% in after-hours trading. Shares rose 0.8% to 12.50, above their 50-day average but below their 200-day line.The Mexican chain had warned that Q1 results could take a hit due to the rainfall in California, but said same-store sales got better as the weather got nicer and tax refunds increased, SunTrust analyst Jake Bartlett said in a March research note.And the California-based company's locations in Houston, which Bartlett earlier described as its "beachhead expansion market," were still a weak spot."Until its Houston stores show a meaningful improvement, we expect investors to doubt the sustainability of LOCO's unit-growth story, which should limit multiple expansion," he said in the research note.Rival Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) last week reported results that topped analyst expectations.IBD'S TAKE: As smartphones become more common, running a successful fast-food restaurant could become more about going digital. McDonald's, on its first-quarter earnings call, talked up its more mobile, touchscreen future. Estimates: Analysts expect the chicken-wing chain to report first-quarter EPS of 16 cents, flat from a year ago. Revenue is expected to rise 9.5% to $24.17 million. Domestic same-store sales, as of Monday, were expected to fall 1.4%.Results: Adjusted EPS was 22 cents, up 37.5%. Revenue rose to $26.6 million. U.S. same-store sales fell 1.1%.Outlook: Wingstop Nnow expects full-year EPS growth of 19%-21%, well up from an earlier forecast of 8%-10% growth.Stock: Shares soared 12% to 32.50 in after-hours trading. Shares closed down 0.6% at 29. Corporate earnings results grabbed front and center stage and are helping to propel U.S. equities higher in late-afternoon trading Tuesday, as the major indexes are padding last week's nice gains.The Dow Jones industrial average, boosted by better than expected results in several of its 30 components including Caterpillar (CAT) (Q1 EPS up 100%) and DuPont (DD) (EPS up 30%), rose more than 1.2%. That's better than gains of 0.7% to 0.8% for the Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500.The Dow Jones industrials, at 21,002, are now up nearly 6.3% since Jan. 1, but the Nasdaq composite, breaking 6000 for the first time, is ahead with a nearly 12% gain. Big-cap techs and select consumer-oriented stocks have helped the Nasdaq's cause. But keep monitoring earnings results and see if more money flows into blue-chip-type large caps outside the tech realm.Caterpillar also notched a surprise 4% gain in revenue, its first year-over-year increase in 10 quarters. The last time the construction and mining gear titan saw a top-line lift came in the third quarter of 2014 (up 1%).Cat shares vaulted past a 99.56 flat-base buy point with a gap up at the open, and it's enjoying heavy institutional buying with shares seeing triple normal turnover. The stock opened the day at 102.80, within the 5% proper buy zone following Tuesday's breakout.The Russell 2000 rallied more than 1.2%. Volume is running firmly higher vs. the same time Monday on both main exchanges, a sign of heavy institutional demand for equities.Crude oil futures, meanwhile, rebounded after getting hammered Monday. WTI futures rose 0.9% to $49.67 a barrel but are still down more than 7% year to date.Gold mining stocks and other defensive plays led the market's downside. Newmont Mining (NEM) sank nearly 3% to 32.91 in heavy volume. The mining giant grew first-quarter profit 4% to 25 cents a share on a 13% pickup in revenue.Four months into 2017, it's clear that institutional investors are favoring certain industrial sectors over others. That's good news for stock pickers. Here are five stocks that, in addition to high-growth names in the IBD 50 and Sector Leaders, show more mature fundamentals or are turnaround situations but have the potential to beat the S&P 500. Nvidia (NVDA), $63 billion market value: The leader in graphics processors has stepped nicely into new growth markets including self-driving automobiles, datacenter and AI (artificial intelligence). Nvidia, up nearly 2% to 104.71, is trying to retake its key 50-day moving average near 103 after getting slammed below it on bearish analysts comments on April 1.The stock was a huge leader in 2016, rising 261% from a cup-with-handle breakout at 33.16 back in March that year.Nvidia sports a solid 98 Earnings Per Share Rating on a scale of 1 to 99 and earnings in the April-ending fiscal first quarter are seen rising an impressive 46% to 67 cents a share, on top of the 39% gain in the year-ago quarter. But keep in mind that in the next three quarters, Nvidia faces absolutely steep year-over-year comps, as Q2, Q3, and Q4 profit rose 56%, 104% and 117%, respectively.Given the giant gains in 2016, Nvidia's current correction is very respectable, falling no more than 21% from its all-time high of 120.92.Celgene (CELG), $98 billion market value: The highly respected biotech pioneers treatments for chronic and difficult diseases including multiple myeloma. The stock jumped 2% to 125.87 after finding vital support at the 50-day line. It's up slightly from an earlier 122.49 cup-with-handle entry.The Street sees full-year earnings rising 22% to $7.22 a share in 2017 and up 21% in 2018. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), $13 billion: The former large cap and burrito and taco chain reports Q1 results after the close Tuesday. Watch for an expected positive change in both comparable restaurant sales and see if restaurant-level operating margins show stability or improve.Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), $31 billion: The robotic surgery firm, which recently posted double-digit top and bottom-line growth in Q1, is up more than 31% since Jan. 1. It bolted out of a saucerlike base at 727.23 in late February.Intuitive gets a rock-solid 96 Composite Rating in IBD Stock Checkup, among the top 5 in IBD's Medical-Systems/Equipment industry group. That group is ranked No. 1 among 197 industry groups and subgroups for six-month relative price performance.Watch for potential new buy points to emerge, in the form of a new base or a gentle pullback to the 10-week moving average, as seen on a weekly chart.In some cases, a stock may not fall back to the 50-day line but find support at the 10-week line. So it's crucial to study a stock's price action on both the daily and weekly charts.RELATED:The Case For A Future New Bull Market In GoldEarnings Results Today: Chipotle Leads 5 Big Reports After The CloseStock Market Today: Is It Time To Buy Hasbro Now? The Dow Jones industrial average was moderately higher in afternoon trading Wednesday, and the S&P 500 was flirting with an all-time high, amid another busy day of headline flow.United Technologies (UTX) led the Dow, up nearly 2% on an earnings beat. It's now 4% past a 114.54 buy point, nearing the top of a 5% buy zone.The best performing stock index was the Russell 2000 small-cap index, which rose 1% to an all-time high. The Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite showed gains of around 0.2% to 0.3%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly lower than Tuesday's levels.The market didn't move much on news the House Freedom Caucus will support an ObamaCare replacement bill, according to CNBC. Opposition from the Freedom Caucus was a big reason the revamped bill failed the first time around.The 10-year Treasury yield eased 1 basis point to 2.33%. It's up about 15 basis points in the past six sessions. The strength in the 10-year yield comes as the market seems to be growing more confident about another rate hike at the June Fed meeting.In the stock market today, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) jumped 3% to 485.44 after the company reported a 28% jump in quarterly sales and 17.8% rise in same-store sales. The results were strong but also benefited from easy comparisons. Chipotle is extended now after a breakout from a base in late March over a 434.79 buy point.Costco (COST) gapped up, rising 2.5% to 177, as it works on a new base with a 178.81 buy point. Shares were strong after the company announced a special dividend of $7 a share. It also raised its quarterly dividend to 50 cents a share.Inside the IBD 50, Financial Engines (FNGN) added 3% to 43.85 as it works on a shallow base with a 45.85 buy point. Essent Group (ESNT) also outperformed, rising 3%.On the downside, U.S. Steel (X) crashed 25% after Q1 earnings and sales missed estimates badly. The news wasn't all bad in the group, though, as fellow steel producers Nucor (NUE) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) reversed higher after a soft start.Seagate (STX) also had a tough day, tumbling 16%, after reporting sales that were slightly lower than expected. Group peer Western Digital (WDC) reports Thursday after close. Shares fell 3% to 84.05, but Western Digital is still holding above the 50-day moving average and an 81.67 buy point.After the close, watch for results from Fortune Brands (FBHS), Mellanox (MLNX) and PayPal (PYPL).RELATED:Costco Jumps Near Buy Point On Special Payout, Dividend HikeIs It Safe To Buy Chipotle Again?
