BMO Capital Markets on Wednesday hiked its price target to 45 from 42.Sector Leader MaxLinear (MXL) led the IBD 50 with a 7% jump to a new high in heavy volume. The chip designer's stock rose back above a 17.85 entry and is in buy range. Also on the IBD 50, graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) and oil transporter Phillips 66 Partners (PSXP) rose 3% each.

The stock market opened with thin losses Wednesday, echoing action across global markets ahead of this afternoon’s Fed rate policy news.The S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average all lost 0.1% or less.The focal point of trading for the stock market today -- and for the week -- looks to be the Fed’s rate policy announcement, expected at 2 p.m. ET. While a rate hike appears highly unlikely, any hint as to upcoming Fed behavior could cause the market to adjust.Prices paid by consumers dipped 0.2% in February, according to the Labor Department’s consumer price index, down from a flat month in January and just short of the 0.3% decline projected by economist consensus. Core CPI -- minus energy and food -- rose 0.3%, more than the consensus target of 0.2%, but even with January’s increase.Housing starts rose to an annualized rate of 1.178 million for February. The Commerce Department revised January’s estimate upward to 1.178 million from 1.099 million. Consensus estimates forecast a 1.146 rate for February.Building permits went the other direction, slowing to a rate of 1.167 million. That was down from a pace of 1.202 million in January and below expectations for 1.150 million.The Federal Reserve delivers its industrial production and capacity utilization report at 9:15 a.m. ET.Oil prices were one of the few things in motion. West Texas Intermediate rose 2% to clear $37 a barrel. Prices may respond to the Energy Information Administration’s weekly inventories data, due out at 10:30 a.m.Gold traded up a fraction to $1,232 an ounce. The dollar edged higher vs. both the euro and the yen. Bonds also rose, trimming 2 basis points from the 10-year yield, to 1.95%.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) gave up 4% just after the open. The burrito chain reported late Tuesday its same-store-sales fell 26% in February, better than January’s 36% nose dive, but well below expectations. The company also set its Q1 guidance at a loss of at least $1 per share. The stock ended Tuesday up 26% from a mid-January low, but still deep in a five-month consolidationOracle (ORCL) added 4% early after posting strong fiscal Q3 results late Tuesday. Oracle shares ended Tuesday 17% off a January low and 14% below a  June high.Investment banks were being hit hard in early action, possibly on news reports that Georgian billionaire  Bidzina Ivanishvili’s lawyers “filed the criminal complaint with Geneva prosecutors Tuesday, alleging that (Credit Suisse) failed to install adequate procedures to prevent money laundering,” according to Bloomberg.Credit Suisse (CS), Deutsche Bank (DB) and UBS (UBS) all fell around 5% each.

LinkedIn (LNKD), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) got lower price targets Wednesday, while Oracle (ORCL) and Monster Beverage (MNST) both saw their price targets increased.Morgan Stanley lowered LinkedIn's price target price target to 125 from 190 and cut its rating to equal-weight from overweight. The report sent the professional social network's shares down 5% on the stock market today.Maxim Group cut its price target on Chipotle to 350 from 450 after the trendy burrito chain late Tuesday reported a steeper-than-expected decline in February same-store sales and warned that it will post its first quarterly loss as a public company on.Chipotle's February sales at restaurants open at least 13 months sank 26.1% in February, worse than the 23% drop expected by analysts. Chipotle suffered another setback this week after four workers at a Billerica, Mass., location became ill with what is said to be norovirus.Chipotle's shares closed down 0.5%.Valeant Pharmaceuticals saw a series of analyst moves after the specialty drug maker posted preliminary unaudited Q4 earnings that missed views Tuesday. Valeant also cut its guidance for the current quarter. But its Q3 revenue beat forecasts.Stifel slashed its price target on Valeant to 65 from 200, while RBC Capital Markets cut its price target to 69 from 85.Valeant's shares edged up less than 0.1% Wednesday after plunging 51.5% Tuesday.BMO Capital Markets raised its price target on Oracle to 45 from 42. Oracle's fiscal Q3 loss beat analysts' estimates late Tuesday, and revenue in its cloud software business was also better than expected.Oracle's shares rose 3.8%.Goldman Sachs raised its price target on Monster Beverage to 160 from 157 and upgraded its rating on the energy drink giant to conviction buy from buy. Monster rose rallied 3.2%.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) shares fell Wednesday after four workers at a Billerica, Mass., location became ill with what is said to be norovirus. No customers have been affected.Citing Chipotle spokesman Chris Arnold, Bloomberg said the restaurant had been shut down for a "full cleaning." While Arnold did not confirm the cause of the illnesses, the Boston Globe has reported that the workers were diagnosed with norovirus, citing officials. But Massachusetts health official praised Chipotle and its employees for reporting the outbreak quickly, adding that the store clean-up was complete.Shares skidded 3.4% to 506.63, after paring earlier losses to 492.50, but closer to their 50-day line. They retook support in mid-February after trading below the key level since October.Meanwhile, McDonald's (MCD), which has benefited amid Chipotle's woes as well as its own turnaround drive, was up 1% Wednesday. Jack In The Box (JACK), which owns the Qdoba Mexican-food chain, dipped 0.2%.Since early November, Chipotle has been rattled by a series of sickness outbreaks, including a wave of E. coli in the Pacific Northwest that led to 43 temporary store closings and a norovirus episode in Boston, not far from the location of the current closing.The company had already warned last month of a "very difficult" 2016, though several analysts had expressed optimism then that the fast-casual burrito chain could eventually recover.In early February, Chipotle management guided for break-even Q1 per-share earnings. Analysts expect 17 cents a share for the quarter.RELATED:Chipotle Warns Of ‘Very Difficult’ 2016, Sees No Profit In Q1Chipotle Sales Won’t Return To Health Until 2017: AnalystsImage provided by Shutterstock.

Stocks held early gains going into the noon hour Wednesday, with restaurant stocks acting particularly well.The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.4% while the S&P 500 gained 0.6%. Volume was tracking lower than the same time Tuesday on both exchanges.West Texas intermediate oil futures for April delivery rose 3.6% to $37.83 a barrel. The Energy Information Administration reported that crude oil inventories rose to 3.9 million barrels, more than expected, while gasoline inventories fell to 4.5 million barrels for the week ended March 4.Darden Restaurants (DRI) gapped above its 200-day moving average after raising third-quarter guidance above Street expectations. The operator of Olive Garden and LongHorn Steakhouse expects adjusted earnings per share of $1.18 to $1.21 vs. a consensus estimate of $1.06.The stock was up more than 2%, although it was well off an early high. It might be building the right side of a long, deep base.Chipotle Mexican Grill's (CMG) health problems won't go away. Late Tuesday, the burrito joint announced it closed a restaurant in Billerica, Mass., after several employees fell ill. Earnings fell sharply in the most recent quarterly report, and analysts are expecting a 95% EPS decline in the next report.The stock dropped nearly 6%.Meanwhile, shaken shareholders continued to dump shares of Shake Shack (SHAK). It fell 4% in heavy volume after cascading nearly 12% Tuesday. It issued a disappointing quarterly report.The restaurant industry group was among the day's worst performers, down more than 1%.Gun maker Smith & Wesson (SWHC) had another strong day, rising 3% on the back of a 4% gain Tuesday.

Stocks quietly edged into positive territory near midday Monday, unfazed by another big jump in oil prices.The Dow Jones industrial average moved into higher territory, up nearly 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq composite each inched 0.1% ahead. All three were in negative ground earlier in the day. NYSE volume was tracking about 10% lower than Friday's level, while Nasdaq volume was close to Friday's level.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures rose another 3% to $37.08 a barrel.In the stock market today, DuPont (DD) outperformed among the Dow industrials, rising nearly 3%. Media reports said that Germany’s BASF (BASFY) is considering a bid for its rival. DuPont agreed to a merger with Dow Chemical (DOW) late last year.On the analyst upgrade/downgrade front, Apple (AAPL) got a price target cut, and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) got a price target lift. Shares of Apple fell 1%, while those of Chipotle rose 0.3%.In the chip space, Macom (MTSI) extended gains after Friday's breakout from a double-bottom base. Shares rose 5%. It's still in a buy range from a 41.42 buy point.Inside the IBD 50, Universal Display (OLED) was one of the top percentage gainers in the early going, rising 4%. It's back above its 10-week average as it works on the right side of a cup-shaped base.Among utilities, Black Hills (BKH) gained 2% in thin trading. It completed a bullish three-weeks-tight pattern last week. It's always a good sign when a stock rallies strongly and holds gains. Tight trading is a sign of strength and support.April gold eased 0.1% to $1,269.50 an ounce. It's still near a 13-month high. Expectations are that the European Central Bank will move on Thursday to further ease monetary policy.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Stocks stepped up into moderate gains at Wednesday's open, with earnings reports and oil prices propelling a large share of early action.The S&P 500 rose 0.3%, the Dow industrials added 0.2%, and the Nasdaq recovered from an early slip to trade up a bit less than 0.1%, as losses among biotech stocks dragged heavily on the index.Volume decreased sharply in the stock market today, down 9% on the Nasdaq and 20% lower on the NYSE, relative to action at the same time Tuesday. Weak volume suggests institutional investors are largely on the sidelines.Oil prices upshifted from early gains, rising more than 2%. That put West Texas Intermediate above $37 a barrel, up nearly 4% so far as it works on a possible fourth straight weekly gain. Prices may see some reaction to weekly inventories numbers, due out from the Energy Information Administration at 10:30 a.m. ET.In stocks, Chevron (CVX) led the Dow with a 3% gains. Nike (NKE) dropped more than 1%.Darden Restaurants (DRI) jumped more than 4% at the start of trade. The owner of the Olive Garden restaurant chain reported strong same-store sales for its fiscal third quarter, gave strong preliminary guidance for its fourth quarter, and announced its chief financial officer would retire immediately. The light-volume gain lifted shares back above the stock's 40-week moving average and further up the right side of a seven-month consolidation.Blue Buffalo (BUFF) was the morning's rockstar, spiking 23% after a better-than-forecast Q4 report late Tuesday. The big volume gain sent shares back above their July IPO price, and further up the right side of a seven-month, 47% deep consolidation.Biotech stocks were taking broad losses early Wednesday, possibly owing to some proposed changes to Medicare drug reimbursement announced late Tuesday. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) gapped down to a 4% loss, a second straight slip despite Brean Murray initiating coverage on the company Tuesday, with a buy rating and a 489 price target.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) gapped down more than 3%. The company said it would shut a Billerica, Mass., location after an outbreak of norovirus among its employees there. Chipotle has been fighting to climb out of a five-month consolidation.On the IBD 50 list, Smith & Wesson (SWHC) ticked 2% higher in weak trade. The move put shares almost 3% back above a 26.64 buy point, which the stock had cleared in strong volume on Friday. A big dip Monday retested support just below the buy point.At the bottom of the list, Ligand Pharmaceuticals (LGND) dropped 4%, carving back below its converged 10- and 40-week moving averages in heavy trade. The stock has been trying to climb the right side of a three-month consolidation.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) suffered a cut to its price target Tuesday, while coverage was started on Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), Panera Bread (PNRA) was upgraded, and Urban Outfitters (URBN) scored several price target hikes.Mizuho lowered its price target on Valeant to 70 from 112 and maintained its neutral rating on the stock. On Monday, Valeant said it would report its Q4 results on March 15, more than two weeks after the drug maker’s originally scheduled date of Feb. 29.Valeant delayed the report due to the return of CEO J. Michael Pearson, who had been on leave for two months while being treated for severe pneumonia. The company’s stock price tumbled late last month after it withdrew its 2016 guidance and news surfaced that it was the subject of a previously undisclosed SEC investigation.Valeant shares closed down 3.8% on the stock market today.Meanwhile, Brean Capital assumed coverage on Regeneron Pharmaceuticals with a buy rating and a 489 price target.Regeneron shares lost 3.3%.Panera was upgraded to overweight with a 250 price target by Morgan Stanley. Shares of the fast casual chain set a new high of 218.97 on Monday as it continues to grab market share from Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which has been giving up share ever since last fall’s news of an E. coli outbreak at some of its restaurants.Panera shares fell 2%, and Chipotle stock lost 1.7%.Urban Outfitters received a series of price target hikes despite reporting mixed quarterly results. Stifel raised its price target on the stock to 34 from 30 and maintained its buy rating. Wunderlich hiked its price target to 29 from 26, Telsey Advisory Group raised it to 35 from 23, and Mizuho raised it to 35 from 23.After Monday’s close, the apparel chain beat fourth-quarter earnings views and met revenue expectations, but it also logged a steeper-than-expected dip in comparable store sales.Urban Outfitters shares leapt 16.1% Tuesday morning.BioMarin Pharmaceutical (BMRN) was upgraded to outperform from neutral by Robert W. Baird, which has a 110 price target on the stock. Last week, the rare-disease specialist said its drug for Batten disease was on track for approval after a successful trial. BioMarin said it plans to submit the drug for approval with the FDA and the European Medicines Agency around the middle of the year.Still, shares retreated 3% despite the upgrade.AutoNation (AN) was downgraded to sell from neutral at Goldman Sachs, which has a 110 price target on the stock. Shares sank 6.3%.Shopify (SHOP) was upgraded to overweight from sector weight by Pacific Crest. Shares climbed 3.6%Miller Tabak initiated coverage on a trio of department store chains. It started Macy’s (M) at hold with a 45 price target; Nordstrom (JWN) at sell with a 42 price target; and J.C. Penney (JCP) at buy with a 17 price target.Macy's dipped 1.3%, Nordstrom gained 0.8%, and J.C. Penney rallied 1.5%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Apple (AAPL) got a price target cut early Monday, and Ambarella (AMBA) also got a lower price target amid sluggish GoPro (GPRO) sales, while Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) got a price target hike and AbbVie (ABBV) was downgraded.Pacific Crest lowered its price target on Apple to 127 from 132 and maintained its overweight rating on the stock, citing weaker demand for the iPhone.Apple shares closed down 1.1% on the stock market today.Ambarella’s price target was lowered to 50 from 90 by Chardan Capital Markets, which has a neutral rating on the stock.Last week, the chipmaker posted mixed Q4 results and cut its fiscal 2017 guidance on weak sales of wearable sports cameras made by GoPro, one of Ambarella’s clients.Shares of Ambarella fell 1.8%. GoPro rose 3.7%.Chipotle’s price target was hiked to 550 from 475 by Credit Suisse, which has an outperform rating on the stock. A recent poll found that the troubled burrito chain lost popularity with younger customers last year, while fast-food giant McDonald’s (MCD) rose in popularity.Chipotle ticked 0.9% higher.Drugmaker AbbVie was downgraded to buy at Goldman Sachs, which has a 68 price target on the stock. Shares added 0.45%.Shares of Micron Technology (MU) fell 2.5% Monday after it was downgraded to reduce from neutral by Nomura Securities, which also lowered its price target to 8 from 12.Hewlett Packard Enterprise’s (HPE) price target was raised to 19 from 13.50 by Maxim Group, which rates the stock a hold. Shares rose 3.4%.Cardinal Health (CAH) was upgraded to conviction buy from buy at Goldman Sachs. Shares rallied 0.8%.

McDonald’s (MCD) took over the top spot from Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) as the favorite restaurant destination among U.S. teens and young adults in 2015, according to a new poll released Wednesday, with the burger giant benefiting from a rebound in the quick-service sector.Meanwhile, Starbucks (SBUX) remained a pretty popular destination among female respondents -- though less so than in previous years -- while Yum Brands’ (YUM) Taco Bell was a hit with young males.William Blair’s annual Teen/Young Adult Survey found that restaurant sentiment “weakened somewhat” in 2015, with about 43% of respondents saying they ate out more often than a year earlier vs. 48% in 2014. Still, those numbers compared well to the apparel category, where only 31% of respondents said they spent more on apparel in 2015.“For those eating out less often, financial reasons were by far the main culprit (40%), while the response ‘too expensive’ jumped to roughly 25% from 18% last year, perhaps reflecting push-back to price increases taken by restaurants on structural government-mandated wage inflation,” William Blair analyst Sharon Zackfia said in a report.She said the quick-service sector “had a quantum leap in popularity” in 2015. Eateries in this category accounted for 38% of total restaurant visits by respondents in 2015, up from 30% in 2014. This represented an all-time high for the survey, driven by strong share gains from McDonald’s and Taco Bell.Fast-casual visits fell to about 20% of total visits in 2015 from 28% the prior year, and Chipotle lost the biggest chunk of share. That was the case even though the survey was completed before the E. coli outbreak at Chipotle restaurants, which was first reported in the fall. Casual dining surpassed fast casual to become the second-most-frequented subsector in 2015.“In terms of frequency (of visits), McDonald’s topped the list across genders, while Chipotle fell to second among females (from first the prior year) and third among males (from second the prior year),” Zackfia said.Among female respondents, Panera Bread (PNRA) held the third spot behind McDonald’s and Chipotle for the second year in a row. Starbucks remained in fourth place, though the percentage of female respondents who said they ate there most often fell to 6.3% in 2015 from 7.2% in 2014. Darden Restaurants' (DRI) Olive Garden rounded out the top five among females.“McDonald’s gained material share over the past year across both genders, with the second-highest share gains behind Olive Garden for females and Taco Bell for males,” Zackfia noted.Among male respondents, Taco Bell ranked second behind McDonald’s as the most-visited restaurant. It was followed by Chipotle, DineEquity’s (DIN) Applebee’s and Wendy’s (WEN).Shares of McDonald’s closed down 0.3% on the stock market today.Chipotle rose 3.1%, Starbucks lost 0.8%, Yum fell 1%, Panera fell fractionally, Darden and  Dinequity climbed 0.7%, and Wendy’s retreated 0.4%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Amazon's (AMZN) price target was lowered Monday, General Motors (GM) was downgraded, Yahoo's price target was lifted, and EOG Resources (EOG) was downgraded as the oil and gas sector continues to slump.Bernstein cut its price target on Amazon to 770 from 800. On Monday, the e-commerce giant announced a deal with Morrisons to deliver fresh, frozen and non-perishable goods to U.K. customers.Amazon shares closed down 0.5% at 552.52 in the stock market today.Yahoo's (YHOO) price target was raised to 32 from 29 by Mizuho. Earlier this month, the Internet company said it will explore the sale of its core business, with the board forming an independent committee to look at strategic alternatives.Yahoo shares climbed 1.3%.General Motors was downgraded by Argus Research to hold amid signs U.S. auto sales are peaking.GM shares edged down 0.6%.EOG was downgraded by Wunderlich to hold with a 64 price target after the shale oil company reported weaker-than-expected results last week.Shares were fell 4.1%.Chipotle Mexican Grill's (CMG) price target was raised to 590 at Piper Jaffray as the fast casual restaurant tries to rebound from several health-safety issues, including an E. coli outbreak.Chipotle shares ticked up 0.6%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) said Wednesday that same-restaurant sales so far in Q1 have paled in comparison to those a year ago -- when diners packed its restaurants for college football's first-ever playoff -- while its Q4 results and 2016 guidance came up short of estimates.Meanwhile, Yum Brands' (YUM) Q4 China results pointed to a rebound from earlier food-safety issues.Buffalo Wild Wings said that same-store sales in the opening four weeks of the first quarter rose 0.3% at company-owned restaurants and slipped 1.5% at franchised locations. A year earlier, company comps jumped 12.7%, and franchise comps saw a 12.4% increase.The restaurant chain also said it will stop reporting quarter-to-date comps trends after this quarter, "as a four-week trend is not predictive of quarterly same-store sales."The chicken-wing purveyor targeted 2016 earnings per share of $5.95-$6.20, well below forecasts for $6.48.Q4 EPS climbed 23.4% to $1.32, but that was short of views for $1.48. Sales rose 19.9% to $490.2 million, missing estimates for $507.23 million.Shares were up 1% in after-hours trading, after initially falling 2% late and having closed 4.3% lower on reports of diners in Kansas getting sick.Overall comps rose 1.9% at company-owned restaurants and 0.1% at franchised locations during Q4, short of the company's own expectations.Buffalo Wild Wings said the sluggish performance was likely due to "holiday shifts for Halloween and Christmas." The company has also been dealing with higher labor costs, which jumped 20% from a year earlier.The results come as the company awaits the results of an investigation by health officials in Kansas into reports of gastrointestinal illness potentially linked to one of its restaurants there. At least 10 were reported sick, media outlets said, with the first reports coming Friday.Buffalo Wild Wings said it shut down the restaurant in question, had it cleaned, and then on Sunday reopened it, according to Bloomberg.The test results could come in a matter of days, potentially around the Super Bowl, possibly costing the chain one of its biggest sales days of the year. Last year, the company sold some 11 million chicken wings on Super Bowl Sunday.The results follow Tuesday’s quarterly report from Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), whose reputation, profits and stock price have all been battered by foodborne-illness outbreaks reported last year. Chipotle said Tuesday that 2016 will be "very difficult" and gave a break-even profit forecast for Q1. Sales aren't seen recovering until next year.Yum Brands, whose own food-handling issues in recent years preceded a planned spinoff of its China business, reported Q4 EPS Wednesday that topped views, though its sales missed.China sales rose 7%, with same-restaurant sales up 2%, marking the second straight gain and indicating a continued recovery from the food-safety issues.Overall, Yum's adjusted EPS rose 11% to 68 cents, beating by 2 cents. Revenue declined 1.2% to $3.95 billion, missing views of $4.02 billion.Yum shares slipped 1.4% in late trading.

Investors in $13.9 billion JPMorgan Large Cap Growth Fund (SEEGX) are a little like a cruise ship passenger who falls overboard in a typhoon.None of them would dream of trying to cross an ocean by clinging to a life preserver. But in the current market storm, those investors are no doubt glad to have hold of something that stays afloat.Their life preserver comes in the form of stocks like Reynolds American (RAI). The tobacco company is up 8% so far this year. That makes it one of only about a dozen stocks out of 66 in the portfolio that have gained ground so far in this volatile year.Reynolds American is a defensive stock in a mutual fund whose main focus is growth. Reynolds also an IBD Leaderboard stock carrying a 99 Composite Rating.The Composite Rating combines IBD’s five stock-performance ratings, including EPS and RS Ratings, with 99 being the highest.Information technology was the fund's largest sector as of Jan. 31, with a 37.5% weighting. Consumer staples, like Reynolds, accounted for only 8.1% of the portfolio. Yet Reynolds' 3.4% dividend yield and recently steady sales growth -- 41% and 43% the past two quarters -- make it a safe haven at a time when investors are concerned about the pace of global and U.S. economic growth and its impact on earnings growth of more economically sensitive growth companies.Reynolds is in a buy range from a 49.66 buy point after reclaiming the entry Monday in light volume. It cleared the buy point Jan. 29 in lukewarm volume.Tech, consumer discretionary and health-care stocks -- the fund's three top sectors -- are where manager Giri Devulapally had the fund's largest weightings going into this year.Facebook (FB) is one of those tech names. The social media giant is ahead 2% this year and 10% off its all-time high reached early this month.Sporting a 99 Comp Rating, Facebook's earnings per share grew 16%, 33% and 46% the past three quarters. Facebook was the fund's top holding as of Jan. 31.Restaurant chain Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) is up 10% this year. But it is still 31% off its Oct. 13 high of 757. The stock has a weak 65 Comp Rating.Revenue fell 7% in the latest quarter. That was the first decline after 11 straight quarters of double-digit growth.On Tuesday, Deutsche Bank analysts cut their rating on the stock to sell from hold. They cited the impact of customer health problems and steps the company has taken to boost food safety.Among other holdings, credit-card payment processor Vantiv (VNTV) is up 8% this year. The stock is working on a deep cup base and trading about 4% below a 53.56 entry.Sales growth has slowed for three quarters. But EPS growth has accelerated for three quarters. The stock has a strong 98 Comp Rating.The company’s recent fourth-quarter report topped analysts’ expectations for a fifth straight frame.The fund fell 9.29% in the past the 12 months going into Tuesday vs. an 8.87% setback by its large-cap growth peers tracked by Morningstar Inc. The S&P 500 was down 5.82%.Over the past three years, the fund's average annual gain was 10.84% vs. 10.12% for its peer group and 10.98% by the big-cap bogey.Image provided by Shutterstock.

If Bob Dylan were an active short seller, he might describe January as being like a rolling stone. Indeed, trading aggressively when a market is rolling lower is one edge you attain when you wish to sell stocks short with success.  (MarketSmith) What other steps can you take right now to gain more of an edge? First,…

Stocks continued to march in lock-step with oil prices Wednesday, ending higher as crude jumped back above $38 a barrel.The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the S&P 500 climbed 0.5%, and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.2%. Volume in the stock market today fell 12% on the NYSE and 8% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Investors have viewed oil as a proxy for the global economy so far this year, selling stocks as oil plunged in January and early February, and then buying as crude prices rebounded. With the markets still nervous, mining, utilities and other defensive sectors continue to outperform.But IBD 50 stock MaxLinear (MXL) jumped 6% in heavy volume as the chip designer tries to clear a 17.85 buy point of a cup base. The company has posted two straight quarters of triple-digit sales and profit growth.Meanwhile, gun maker Smith & Wesson (SWHC) jumped 5% to a new high and is now more than 5% past a 26.64 buy point of a cup base that it cleared Friday following a strong quarterly earnings report.On the downside, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell more than 3% after the restaurant chain said it would temporarily close a restaurant in Massachusetts due to health concerns. It was the latest setback for Chipotle, which has suffered a series of health issues.

The stock market opened with modest gains Wednesday amid relatively quiet headline flow.The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 added 0.3% and the Nasdaq was mostly unchanged.The stock market today again gets little input from the economic calendar. Due for a pause after its three-week rally, two days of weak volume suggest the market is unlikely to get too rambunctious before the European Central Bank's policy announcement on Thursday and, the bigger news, the U.S. Federal Open Market Committee's meeting next week.Today, the Commerce Department reports January wholesale inventories data at 10 a.m. ET. The Energy Information Administration reports its weekly inventories data at 10:30 a.m.In oil prices, West Texas Intermediate pushed above $37 a barrel, up about 1.5%. Brent crude rose 1.6%, clearing the $40 mark.The dollar was mixed, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds fell, lifting the 10-year yield 5 basis points to 1.88%. Facebook (FB) and PayPal (PYPL) topped the IBD 50 list with 0.5% gains.Overseas, markets in China and Japan slipped, while Europe's benchmarks logged some nice progress near midday. Frankfurt's DAX led with a 1.3% advance, boosted by data showing German industrial production rebounded 3.3% in February.

Consumer sentiment fell to a four-month low, the University of Michigan. Meanwhile, business inventories…

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) topped Wall Street's meek earnings expectations late Tuesday as the restaurant chain released its first quarterly report since being rocked food-safety scandals, but revenue still fell short and the trendy eatery warned that 2016 will be difficult.The company earned $2.17 per share, a 43.5% plummet but not as bad as analysts had feared. Wall Street had anticipated $1.85 per share, and Chipotle had recently guided for diluted EPS of $1.70-$1.90.Revenue fell almost 7% to $997.5 million, below views for $1.01 billion.Same-store sales fell 14.6%, in line with the expected decline Chipotle Mexican Grill had disclosed in a recent SEC filing. Chipotle also announced a $300 million stock buyback program.But  Chipotle warned on the post-earnings call that 2016 "will be a very difficult year," predicting first-quarter EPS will be breakeven. Wall Street had expected $2.08 a share, down 46%. January same-store sales crashed 36%.Shares fell 3.6% to 458.21 on the stock market today in late morning trade.Chipotle's caution of a deeper and longer road to recovery surprised investors, but it follows a similar experience by Yum Brands (YUM). Yum Brands' China operations suffered a a series of food-safety scandals, and same-store sales remain under pressure several quarters later.For 2016, Chipotle expects 220-235 new restaurant openings and an effective full-year tax rate of about 39%. In a December filing, the company rescinded its previously announced 2016 outlook for same-restaurant sales growth.Chipotle's food-safety woes first came to light in early November, prompting the fast-casual burrito chain to temporarily close 43 locations in the Pacific Northwest. Over 50 people in nine states were hit with E. coli.But that wasn't the only scare. In December, over 140 people were struck with norovirus after visiting a single Chipotle restaurant in Boston, and the company was also served with a subpoena related to an earlier norovirus episode at a California location.The company also disclosed that on Jan. 28 it had been served with a subpoena "broadening the scope of the previously-announced criminal investigation by the U.S. Attorney’s office for the Central District of California.”"The new subpoena requires us to produce documents and information related to company-wide food safety matters dating back to January 1, 2013, and supersedes the subpoena served in December 2015 that was limited to a single Chipotle restaurant in Simi Valley, California,” said the company. “We intend to fully cooperate in the investigation."But the CDC declared on Monday that the outbreaks were over. Chipotle management had already predicted that margins and earnings this year would be "messy," given the situation.It has since implemented a new food-safety program as it focuses on winning back customers, though young people don't appear to be fazed the restaurant's problems. A NPD Group study, released Monday, said that young adults increased their visits to Chipotle by double-digits last year."We are pleased to have this behind us and can place our full energies to implementing our enhanced food safety plan that will establish Chipotle as an industry leader in food safety," said co-CEO Steve Ells in a statement. "We are extremely focused on executing this program, which designs layers of redundancy and enhanced safety measures to reduce the food safety risk to a level as near to zero as is possible."Meanwhile, Buffalo Wild Wings tumbled 6.2% Wednesday intraday  as reports circulated of a Kansas location sickening several people. Buffalo Wild Wings is set to report earnings after the market close. Yum Brands also reports tonight.RELATED:Chipotle Profit Seen Plunging, But Young People Step Up VisitsChipotle Sees ‘Messy’ Year, Plans Redemption

Chipotle Mexican Grill's  (CMG) earnings and margins will be "messy" this year as the company focuses on food safety, and it may not get most of its customers back until next year, even as it sees the CDC soon declaring an end to the E. coli outbreak that tarnished its image, the company said Wednesday. Chipotle, which said it…

While Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) continues to deal with the fallout from E. coli and norovirus outbreaks at many of its restaurants, other companies that sell prepared food — including health food grocer Whole Foods Market (WFM) — have an opportunity to pick up new business.That's the finding from RBC Capital Markets analyst William Kirk, who said in a note to clients Wednesday that Chipotle’s food safety concerns “represent a $933 million revenue opportunity for competitors.” For Whole Foods, much of that opportunity involves attracting ex-Chipotle customers in the immediate area.In addition to groceries, Whole Foods also sells prepared items such as sandwiches, salads and sushi. About half its locations have a Chipotle within one mile, Kirk said. Nearly 85% of Whole Foods locations are within three miles of a Chipotle.Kirk reckons that Whole Foods can capture 25% of Chipotle’s lost sales when a store is located within a mile. That percentage falls to 10% for stores located within one to three miles, and 3% for those located within three to five miles.“Put another way, we have Whole Foods’ opportunity as about 3% of lost Chipotle sales,” Kirk said.He estimates Whole Foods can add $31 million in sales from former Chipotle customers — a drop in the bucket when you consider the company logged nearly $16 billion in revenue last fiscal year. But those sales could grow exponentially in future years, giving Whole Foods a little extra defense against rising competition from mainstream supermarket chains like Kroger (KR).“Conventional grocers have been a major headwind to comparable store sales (at Whole Foods),” Kirk noted.Shares of Whole Foods closed down 0.3% in the stock market today. The stock has fallen about 45% over the past year. Chipotle's stock price fell 1.9% while Kroger lost 0.2%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Stock futures ticked off minor gains ahead of Wednesday's open.Dow futures blipped 0.3% above fair market value. S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 futures were also up 0.3%. Russell 2000 futures inched up 0.5%.The stock market today jumps into hump day with the Nasdaq down 2.1% and the S&P 500 1.9% lower since Friday. Among large insurers, Prudential (PUK) spiked 6% and MetLife (MET) was flat, ahead of its earnings report after today's close.Herbicide, pesticide and seed strain developer Syngenta (SYT) sparked up 4% after confirming it agreed to be acquired by the state-owned China National Chemical Corp. in a deal valued at more than $43 billion. Switzerland-based Syngenta shares gapped up 6% Tuesday as news reports detailed a possible tie-up between the two companies.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell 6% after reporting mixed Q4 results. The firm also announced the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention concluded its investigation of the E.Coli outbreaks linked to the chain and that it received a subpoena from the U.S. Attorney's office for the Central District of California, broadening the scope of the previously announced criminal investigation against the chain.On the IBD 50 list, Edwards Lifesciences (EW) skipped up 5% after trouncing analysts' Q4 earnings and revenue estimates and raising Q1 EPS guidance well above consensus views. Edwards has been lolling below its 10-week moving average in the 10th week of a shallow base with an 83.53 buy point.

The major indexes were sharply lower in afternoon trading Tuesday, registering losses of about 2%. The Nasdaq was off 2.2% and the S&P 500 1.9% as both traded at session lows. The Dow Jones industrial average slid 1.9%. Exxon Mobil (XOM), one of the Dow components, fell 2% in above-average volume. The oil giant’s Q4 EPS fell 57% to 67…

Here’s a quick rundown of Tuesday’s after-hours action:Yahoo (YHOO) reported fourth-quarter earnings dropped 57% but were in line with estimates. Revenue edged up 1.6% to beat views.The company says it’s exploring strategic options, including a reverse spin-off of its Alibaba stake and the sale of non-core assets. Shares jumped nearly 5% in extended trade.Gilead Sciences (GILD) handily topped fourth-quarter earnings and revenue estimates. EPS popped 37%, and revenue rose 16%. Its 2016 product sales forecast was roughly in line with analyst estimates.The hepatitis C and HIV drugmaker also announced a $12 billion share buyback program. Shares rose fractionally late.Illumina (ILMN) fourth-quarter earnings fell 7% on a 15% revenue rise. The bottom line missed by a penny, while the top line beat views.The maker of gene-sequencing systems issued full-year revenue guidance that was in line with views, but its earnings guidance that was light. Shares fell 2% late after closing down 2.7%.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) issued its first quarterly report since it was hit with an E. coli outbreak. Chipotle's Q4 earnings plunge of 44% was not as bad as Wall Street feared, while its 7% revenue decline missed expectations. The CDC declared on Monday that the outbreaks were over, but a criminal investigation is ongoing. Chipotle warned that 2016 "will be a very difficult year," predicting first-quarter EPS will be breakeven. Wall Street had expected $2.08 a share, down 46%.Chipotle tumbled 6% in late trading.

Stocks advanced at Wednesday's open, then dropped back to moderate losses after two weak readings on the U.S. services sector. Volume slipped on the stock market today, down about 7% on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq relative to trade at the…
Stocks continued to get hammered in early afternoon trading Friday as plunging China stocks, sliding oil prices and disappointing U.S. retail sales weighed.

The Nasdaq sank 3.4%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 tumbled 2.8% and 2.7%, respectively, in the stock market today. The S&P 500 briefly undercut its Aug. 24 low. Volume swelled across the board vs. the same time Thursday.
Losers swamped winners by nearly a 10-1 margin on the NYSE and Nasdaq. All industry groups tracked by IBD were lower, with energy, steel and chipmakers leading the decline.

All 30 Dow stocks were in the red. Walt Disney (DIS) slumped 5% to a four-month low in robust trade. The stock is 22% off its 52-week high after a failed breakout past a 117.68 handle buy point. Barclays lowered the media and theme park giant to underweight from equal weight and cut its price target to 89 from 98 amid concerns about subscriber losses at its ESPN sports network.

Analog Devices (ADI) lost 3% in fast turnover to its lowest level since October 2014. RBC Capital Markets cut its price target on the chipmaker to 58 from 69 and Stifel to 64 from 72. Late Thursday, Analog sharply lowered its fiscal Q1 revenue outlook due to weaker-than-forecast customer demand in its portable consumer business unit.

That weighed on Apple (AAPL), fueling concerns about slowing iPhone sales, since Analog is one of its key chip suppliers. Apple dropped 3% in heavy volume, giving back all its Thursday gain and then some.
On the upside, IBD 50 stock Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) soared 7% in fast trade, briefly retaking its 50-day moving average. Defensive stocks have fared better than most in the current weak market.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) climbed 2%, on track for a third straight advance. Shares are 38% off their 52-week high. The burrito chain, which has been blamed for a rash of E. coli cases, said it will close all stores the morning of Feb. 8 for a staff meeting on food safety.

Major averages followed the lead of China stocks Friday, ending the week with a thud. So did crude oil. The Nasdaq closed in the upper half of its range but still lost 2.7%, weighed down by weakness in chip stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 2.4% and the S&P 500 gave up 2.2%. For the week, the Nasdaq shed 3.3%; the Dow and S&P 500 lost 2.2% each.

Coal, oil and gas, and chip stocks lagged. REITs outperformed again. In the REIT group, higher-quality names likeMid America Apartment Communities (MAA), CoreSite Realty (COR) and CubeSmart (CUBE) all ended higher.

At the New York Mercantile Exchange, February WTI crude oil settled at $29.42 a barrel, down 5.7%. For the week, it lost around 11%. The 10-year Treasury yield fell 6 basis points to 2.03%, according to preliminary figures.

Inside the Dow, Wal-Mart (WMT) fell nearly 2% after the company announced plans to close 269 stores around the world, including 154 U.S. locations. Of the 154 U.S. locations, 102 are the company's "Express" format stores.
In the stock market today, Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) was a rare bright spot. Shares of the egg producer jumped 5% in heavy volume.

Meanwhile, after a two-session rally that saw shares gain 12%, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) rallied close to 5%. The fast-casual chain said it's closing all stores Feb. 8 for a few hours for an all-staff meeting on food safety.
In economic news, December retail sales fell 0.1%, slightly below expectations for flat sales. Excluding autos, sales fell 0.1%, well below Econoday's consensus forecast for a 0.2% rise.

Stocks were firmly lower in late-afternoon trading Wednesday, this time spooked by claims by North Korea that the country detonated its first hydrogen bomb.The Dow Jones industrial average lost 1.4%, the S&P 500 gave up 1.3% and the Nasdaq fell 1.1%. Shares fell nearly 2%. Fears of slowing iPhone sales have been weighing on the stock market in recent weeks.The minutes from the Dec. 16 Fed meeting were released at 2 p.m. ET. They revealed that the decision to raise interest rates was a "close call" for some committee members amid low inflation. Oil and gas-related groups lagged as WTI crude oil futures slumped more than 5% to $34.08 a barrel.Among the day's gainers,Netflix (NFLX) jumped 5.5%. It's back above a 44.49 buy point as it firms up at its 50-day moving average.Sellers were in Chipotle (CMG) again. Shares lost 5% after the restaurant chain received a federal grand jury subpoena related to a norovirus outbreak in California. The fast-casual burrito chain said December comparable restaurant sales plunged by 30%, and it now expects Q4 comps to sink by 14.6%.Connect with Ken Shreve on Twitter @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook.

Amazon (AMZN), Nike (NKE), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) are among the companies based in the 10 hottest housing markets for 2016, according to a report from online real-estate research company Zillow this week.Topping the list is Denver, followed by Seattle and Dallas-Fort Worth. Other places that made the list are Utah markets Ogden and Salt Lake City, along with Omaha, Neb., and Boise, Idaho.To determine which markets would be hot, Zillow looked at home value appreciation, low unemployment rates and strong income growth."Trendy tech centers like San Francisco, Seattle and Denver hogged the spotlight in 2015," noted Zillow Chief Economist Svenja Gudell in the report. "But this year, the markets that shine brightest will be those that manage to strike a good balance between strong income growth, low unemployment and solid home value appreciation. As the job market continues to hum and opportunity becomes more widespread, the best housing markets are no longer limited to the coasts or one-industry tech towns."Omaha, home of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, among others, has the lowest unemployment rate of the 10 hottest markets — just 2.9%, the report noted.Denver, home of Chipotle and numerous other big companies, saw housing values rise 16% in 2015, and Zillow forecasts that they will rise another 5% in 2016. Denver's recent income growth is 1.1%, and the unemployment rate is 3.1%, the report noted.Zillow also forecasts that Portland, Ore., which is close to power brand Nike's home base of Beaverton, will see a 5% rise in home values this year vs. a year earlier. Income growth is 1%, while the unemployment rate is 5%.Seattle, home of Amazon and Starbucks (SBUX), to name a couple, is estimated to enjoy 5.4% home value appreciation this year. Income growth is 1.1%, while the unemployment rate is 4.5%, Zillow noted.Zillow forecasts that Dallas-Fort Worth, home of such companies as Exxon Mobil (XOM) and AT&T (T), will see an estimated home appreciation of 5.6% this year vs. a year earlier. Income growth in Dallas-Fort Worth is 1.1%, while the unemployment rate is 4%.Richmond, Va., home of tobacco giantAltria Group (MO), is expected to see home price appreciation of 2.2% vs. a year earlier. Its recent income growth is 1.2%, while its unemployment rate is 4.4%."A strong and diverse economy is the driving force behind Richmond's high income growth, with government, finance, education and manufacturing jobs robust in the area and expected to continue in 2016," the report noted.Boise, Ogden, Salt Lake City and Sacramento, Calif., all have high forecast home value appreciation, the report said. Homes are expected to appreciate an average of about 5% over the next year.

Stocks extended gains in early afternoon trading Thursday as they bounced back from Wednesday's ugly sell-off.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 rallied 1.7% and 1.6%, respectively, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.5%. Volume was positive in the stock market today, tracking sharply higher across the board vs. the same time Wednesday.Oil and gas, chip equipment and medical stocks were among the top gainers. Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) surged more than 4% each to lead the Dow.Microsoft (MSFT) led blue chip techs with a 2% bounce in heavy trade, nearly recovering all of Wednesday's loss. Shares are 11% extended from a 47.64 buy point cleared in October.Apple (AAPL) gained 1.5% in volume after staging an upward reversal. The iPhone maker's stock is still well below its 50-day and 200-day moving average lines and is 27% off its late-April peak. It's on track for a fourth advance in the past five sessions.Intel (INTC) was up 1% in fast trade ahead of its Q4 earnings report, due after the close. The stock has been consolidating now for over a year. SunTrust Robinson Humphrey began covering the chipmaker with a neutral rating. Analysts expect sales to grow for the first time in three quarters.Embattled restaurant chain Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) recouped 7% in hefty trade, extending Wednesday's 6% gain. The stock is 40% off its August high. Credit Suisse reaffirmed its outperform rating and 530 price target.On the IBD 50 , Phillips 66 (PSX) soared 4% in big volume. It's been trading below its 200-day line since Jan. 4. Shares got a lift earlier in the week amid reports that Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) recently upped its stake in the oil refiner.WebMD (WBMD) was the biggest IBD 50 loser, down 8% on a downward reversal, after denying a Financial Times report that it's in talks with potential buyers.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo and on Facebook.

Facebook (FB), Starbucks (SBUX) and Visa (V) are among stocks that would hold up well if the U.S. economy goes into recession, a Goldman Sachs report said.Although Goldman didn't say it's looking for a recession, and many economists say recession is still a remote possibility, the list comes amid recent red flags that some analysts have said could augur recession.Railroad shipments -- a forward-looking indicator -- have fallen amid unstable economic conditions. Industrial production has also been weak, and the strong dollar has hit exporters.David Kostin, Goldman Sachs' chief U.S. equity analyst, came up with the recommendations for recession stocks on the assumption that strong balance sheets and high domestics sales should outperform in a downturn, according to Bloomberg.In addition to Facebook, Starbucks and Visa, Goldman also named Alphabet (GOOGL,), Whole Foods Market (WFM), which continues to benefit from the trend in the U.S. toward healthy food, industrial giant 3M (MMM) and Verizon Communications (VZ), the top wireless service provider.Facebook closed up 0.3% on the stock market today. Starbucks rose 1.5%, Visa ticked 0.2% higher, and Alphabet rose less than 0.1%. Whole Foods ended up 0.9%, while 3M surged 5.2% after reporting strong earnings Tuesday.Verizon last Thursday reported that Q4 EPS shot up 25%  to 89 cents on a 3.2% rise in revenue to $34.25 billion, both topping estimates. Shares gained 2.6% Tuesday.Facebook reports Wednesday, and consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for earnings per share to rise 26% to 68 cents a share on a 40% jump in revenue to $5.37 billion.Visa will report Thursday, and analysts see EPS up 8% to 68 cents on a 7% hike in revenue to $3.62 billion.Chipotle (CMG), Marathon Petroleum (MRO) and Michael Kors (KORS) made it on Goldman's list despite coming under major pressure recently.Chipotle's sales and stock have plunged since an E. coli outbreak at some locations. Marathon has sold off along with the rest of the energy sector as oil prices sank. And Michael Kors has been in an extended slide amid a shift in consumer tastes.On Tuesday, Chipotle shares rose 1.35%, Marathon rallied 3.8%, and Michael Kors rose climbed 2.9%.

While the rest of the stock market crumbled, a pharmaceutical company made a new high in heavy volume Monday. Baxalta (BXLT) rose above the 40.34 buy point of a cup-with-handle base in volume 285% above average. The stock closed at 41.17 , up 2.14 on the day. Of course, it took extraordinary developments to bring out the buyers. Baxalta announced…

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) further cut its fourth-quarter guidance Wednesday and disclosed a subpoena in connection with a federal criminal investigation into a restaurant hit by norovirus in August.The fast-casual burrito chain said December comparable restaurant sales plunged by 30%, and it now expects Q4 comps to sink by 14.6%, with earnings per share coming in at $1.70-$1.90. That's far worse than the 8%-11% quarterly comp decline and EPS outlook of $2.45-$2.85 that the company forecast last month.Chipotle said in a regulatory filing that a separate norovirus incident last month at a restaurant in Brighton, Mass., had compounded the company's problems following an E. coli outbreak at some of its locations during the fall.The restaurant chain also anticipates one-time Q4 expenses of $14 million-$16 million to cover food replacement, food safety, inspection, marketing and other costs. That's a higher estimate than the $6 million-$8 million estimate offered in December.And Chipotle sees restaurant-level operating margins shrinking to 20%-21%, compared to the 22%-24% projected last month. The company is due to report full Q4 results Feb. 2.Shares closed down nearly 5% in the stock market today. The stock has nose-dived 39.5% since the company's last earnings report on Oct. 20.Other restaurant chains also moved lower Wednesday. McDonald's (MCD) dipped 0.7%, Wendy's (WEN) gapped down 2.3%, Jack In The Box (JACK) lost 0.8%, and Sonic (SONC) sank 6.6% despite reporting strong quarterly results late Tuesday.Chipotle said it received the subpoena last month from the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California requiring the company to turn over "a broad range of documents" related to a restaurant in Simi Valley, Calif. The investigation is being led by federal prosecutors and the FDA."We intend to fully cooperate in the investigation," Chipotle said, adding that it was unable to assess the investigation's full impact.Chipotle in recent weeks has vowed to improve safety standards, with its co-CEO issuing a televised apology.The company on Wednesday also said it had OK'd $300 million in share repurchases. Those buybacks are in addition to the $300 million in buybacks approved last month, the company said.Follow Bill Peters on Twitter @IBD_BPeters.

Stocks remained deep in the red in escalating volume amid a flurry of disappointing news in the retail sector. The S&P 500 fell 1.2%, holding in the lower half of the day's trading range. The action is typical for a market in a correction.The Dow industrials slipped 1.4%, while the Nasdaq fell 1.1%. Volume was running slightly higher on the NYSE and roughly flat on the Nasdaq exchange.In the stock market today, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) soured again, losing more than 5% in nearly triple its average volume. The stock slumped as low as 423.77, reaching two-year lows on news that the burrito and taco shop chain was served with a federal grand jury subpoena from the U.S. District Court in central California related to a criminal investigation following an outbreak of norovirus that sickened customers at a Chipotle restaurant in Simi Valley, Calif.Chipotle also said it expects same-store sales in Q4 to fall 14.6% vs. a year earlier, and earnings in the range of $1.70 to $1.90, down sharply from the $3.84 it earned in the same period in 2014.Restaurant peer Chuy's Holdings (CHUY), which also sells Mexican-style food, fell in sympathy, down nearly 3% and slipping beneath a 34.19 buy point within a messy cup-with-handle base.In the automotive retail industry, AutoNation (AN) remained sharply lower, gapping down nearly 12% after reporting it had to make deeper-than-expected discounts in luxury cars to prop up sales in December. Apple (AAPL) sank more than 2% on fears that demand for its smartphones have cooled. The Nasdaq mega-cap is poised to make its lowest close since October 2014 and is 25.5% below a 52-week high.On the upside, thinly traded Nautilus (NLS) rallied nearly 4%, adding to gains of 10.5% and 10.1% in the first two trading sessions of 2016. Volume was running double its normal pace. The gym equipment maker cleared the 21.06 buy point of a cup-with-handle base. Earlier in the week, Nautilus said it would buy elliptical machine maker Octane Fitness for $115 million.Nautilus sports a 94 Composite Rating , which highlights a 98 Earnings Per Share Rating, just below the maximum 99 score, and an A rating for SMR (Sales + Profit Margins + Return on equity).Follow Saito-Chung on Twitter: @IBD_DChung.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) shares plunged more than 6% after hours in response to a report from Boston College that 28 of its students — including members of the men's basketball team — suffered gastrointestinal issues after eating at one of its restaurants, reports said Monday.Besieged with reports of patrons contracting E. coli from its eateries, the Denver-based fast casual chain said that it temporarily closed the restaurant located in the Cleveland Circle area of Boston "while we work with local health officials to investigate a number of illnesses among Boston College students," CNBC reported Chipotle as announcing in a statement.The company added, "We do not have any evidence to suggest that this incident is related (to) the previous E. coli incident. There are no confirmed cases of E. coli connected to Chipotle in Massachusetts."The university said that it has notified the Massachusetts Department of Public Health about the matter. State officials reportedly said that it hadn't yet determined the cause of the illnesses.Chipotle shares fell 6.5% to 516.00 in after-hours trading on the stock market today.Chipotle stock has endured negative after-hours shocks in the past — via disappointing quarterly earnings reports, lowered guidance and the like — only to rally soon afterward.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

Halliburton (HAL) and its merger partner Baker Hughes (BHI) were upgraded Tuesday, along with First Solar (FSLR). Oilfield service provider Halliburton was upgraded to overweight from sector weight at KeyBanc, which also upgraded Baker Hughes to overweight. Regulators are skeptical of Halliburton's $35 billion acquisition of Baker Hughes, but discussions with the Justice Department continue, and the companies extended the…

Stocks greeted 2016 by sliding more than 1% Monday, hurt by a rout in Chinese stocks overnight and increased tensions in the Middle East. The Nasdaq slumped 2.1%, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 1.6% and the S&P 500 fell 1.5%. All three indexes were off more than 2% most of the day. Volume jumped 69% on the NYSE and 61% on the Nasdaq compared to Thursday's pre-holiday levels, according to preliminary data.The Shanghai Composite plunged 6.9% after China's official manufacturing index contracted for the fifth straight month, with export orders falling for the 15th straight month. U.S. economic data was also gloomy, as the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index contracted in December for the second straight month.Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia severed diplomatic ties with Iran after protesters stormed its embassy in Tehran following the execution of a Shiite cleric in Sunni-dominated Saudi Arabia. But crude oil prices ended lower after jumping early in the session.Internet retailers were among the hardest hit in the stock market today.Amazon.com (AMZN) dropped nearly 6% and sliced through its 50-day moving average in heavy volume. The stock also fell 7% below its flat-base buy point at 684.92 intraday, triggering a sell signal.U.S.-listed Chinese Internet retailers also took a beating, with JD.com (JD) dropping more than 8%, Vipshop Holdings (VIPS) sinking 8% and Alibaba (BABA) losing more than 5%.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) dropped more than 6% to a 52-week low after negative comments by analysts at Maxim Group and Oppenheimer. The company has been reeling from an outbreak of E. Coli bacteria at some of its restaurants.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) was among the few bright spots. The maker of athletic apparel jumped more than 6% in heavy volume after analysts at Jefferies & Co. added it to their list of favorite stock picks for 2016. Lululemon is still some 20% off a 52-week high.Meanwhile, new issue GoDaddy (GDDY) rose 2% after getting support at its 50-day line.Acuity Brands (AYI), Constellation Brands (STZ), Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) and KB Home (KBH) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings this week.Economic data due Tuesday include auto and truck sales for December. The Institute for Supply Management's index of service sector activity for December and the Labor Department's key jobs report for last month are scheduled for Wednesday and Friday, respectively.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) withdrew its 2016 comp guidance and offered a bleak Q4 earnings view due to the E. coli outbreak, after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said new cases have been linked to the restaurant. Diners across nine states have now been sickened as a result. The popular burrito chain said in an SEC filing that…

Stocks dug into significant early losses in rising trade Wednesday. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 1.3%. The S&P 500 fell 1.2% and the Nasdaq lopped off 1.1% in early action.Volume rose, up about 15% on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE, relative to trade at the same time Tuesday.The stock market today opened effectively misfiring on all cylinders. Oil prices dived, dragging energy stocks to many of the morning's worst losses. Concerns over iPhone sales sent Apple (AAPL) down nearly 2% in very heavy trade, dragging with it an entire population of vendors and suppliers. Stocks in Europe fell hard. Investors crowded into bonds, but the dollar backed off vs. the euro and the yen.Investors took little notice of a healthy read on December employment from ADP's National Employment Report, which showed business adding 257,000 new workers, up 22% over November's hiring pace and well above estimates for a pullback to 190,000.Factory orders fell 0.2% in November, the Commerce Department said — a sharp retreat from October's 1.3% advance but in line with the Street's consensus projection.Researcher Markit's services sector purchasing managers index for December dropped sharply, to 54.3 from 56.1 in November.The December services index from the Institute of Supply Management was a bit more steady, at 55.3 vs. 55.9 in November. But consensus estimates had called for a reading of 56.2.Wal-Mart (WMT) rose almost 1%, the sole gainer on the Dow. The majority of stocks near the bottom of the S&P 500 index were oil-related. But worst hit were AutoNation (AN) and coal miner Consol Energy (CNX), down 10% each.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) dipped 2%. The company lowered its Q4 EPS guidance by about 30%, to well below analysts' consensus. It also said it had received a federal grand jury subpoena requiring a range of documents related to a norovirus incident in Simi Valley, Calif., in August 2015. Chipotle also upped its existing $300 million share buyback program by another $300 million.Ikang Healthcare (KANG) muscled up more than 4%. The China-based chain of medical centers had climbed almost 4% in very heavy trade on Tuesday, ending just below a 21.59 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.On the IBD 50 list, Hawaiian Holdings (HA) bobbed 1% higher — leading a short list of advancing stocks. Hawaiian ended Tuesday down 9% so far this week, narrowing a 56% gain above a 25.69 buy point to 25%.On the downside, Smith & Wesson (SWHC) pegged a 5% loss. Wedbush downgraded the stock to neutral, from outperform, but raised the price target to 26, from 24. The note cited the stock's recent advance, and said it was difficult to discern how much of the current gun sales surge is demand pulled forward by the possibility of heightened federal sales requirements. The stock remains comfortably extended above a 19.07 buy point.

A big movement among foodies these days is to encourage everyone to eat locally. That is, eat locally grown produce, meat, eggs. It sounds good. But like many things that sound good, reality is far more complicated.

Chipotle (NYSE-CMG) for example, wore its commitment to using locally grown food it as a badge of pride — part of its "food with integrity" campaign. But the practice likely contributed to food poisoning across the country, and in December the chain announced it planned to scale this back and adopt stricter, and more centralized, control of its food ingredients.
Now a study out of the University of Washington shows that eating only what's grown locally is an impossibility — at least in one city.
The researchers found that if every available square inch in Seattle were used to grow produce, it would produce only enough food to feed 4% of its population.
If the city didn't want 96% of its people to starve, it would have to expand out 58 miles around the city to meet its food needs.

"I think many people see food growing in their backyard and a salad at dinner throughout the summer season and assume they are feeding themselves," one of the authors, Monika Moskal, told UW Today. "They don't realize that caloriewise, that's not really the whole picture."

Supporting local farmers is all well and good, just like supporting local family-owned businesses. But there's no getting around the fact that most of what we eat is going to come from somewhere else.

It's understandable if executives at Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and other fast-casual restaurant chains are feeling a little heartburn heading into the new year.

The recent E. coli outbreak at dozens of Chipotle restaurants was enough to give the whole restaurant sector indigestion, considering that Chipotle had been one of the industry's leading lights earlier in the year. Even before the E. coli news hit, though, Chipotle and other fast-casual chains were falling out of favor on Wall Street.

"It's been a tough market for high-beta restaurant stocks," Cowen & Co. analyst Andrew Charles told IBD. "There's a very risk-averse type of investor out there, which you can see in the fact that two of the best restaurant performers have been big names like McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX) . In comparison, high-beta stocks have underperformed."

Shares of Chipotle, Panera Bread (PNRA), Shake Shack (SHAK), Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES), Fiesta Restaurant Group (FRGI), Habit Restaurants (HABT) and El Pollo Loco (LOCO) spent the latter half of 2015 heading south.
Analysts say that a number of factors contributed to the decline, including slowing financial growth, overheated valuations and competition from an increasingly crowded field.
Fast Casual Off IPO Menu?

The challenge facing fast-casual restaurant stocks as they enter 2016 is figuring out how to recapture some of the magic that pushed the group to record highs during the first half of 2015. That won't be easy, considering the current mindset of many investors.
It's also unlikely that you'll see many new issues stepping in to give the fast-casual group a shot of adrenaline in 2016, says Maxim Group analyst Stephen Anderson.
"You're seeing harder market conditions for a lot of IPOs — not just for restaurants, but also for tech firms and other industries," Anderson told IBD.

Meanwhile, slowing same-restaurant sales growth has hit most fast-casual chains of late. Zoe's, Fiesta, El Pollo Loco and Habit logged decelerating comp growth during the first three quarters of the year. While Panera saw a year-over-year improvement in comp growth during each of its first three quarters of 2015, that came off easy comparisons with 2014, when gains were minimal.
Chipotle Stock Turns Toxic

The real trouble came for Chipotle, whose comparable restaurant sales growth decelerated in each of the first three quarters of 2015, all down sharply from 2014. During the second quarter, Chipotle's comp growth fell to 4.3% from 17.3% the prior year. Q3 comps grew 2.6% vs. 19.8% a year earlier.

Things got even worse earlier this month when Chipotle, in the throes of its E. coli crisis, warned that fourth-quarter same-store sales won't increase but instead will fall by 8% to 11%. The company also said that earnings per share will end up at $2.45 to $2.85 a share, well off the $4.09 that analysts had expected.
Amid new E. coli issues, Chipotle's stock fell 8.5% in the last week, 35% off its August peak.

The best performer among fast-casual stocks has been Shake Shack, which had its initial public offering in January. Its year-over-year comps grew 11.7% during the first quarter, 12.9% during the second, and 17.1% during the third. Even so, Shake Shack shares are down 58% from their high of 96.75, set in May.

All of the fast-casual players have faced rising competition — not just from each other, but also from privately held chains and small local and regional operations looking to hop on the fast-casual bandwagon.
"It's a very fragmented industry," Cowen's Charles said. "There's not just one player you have to worry about, but many different types of players."

Competition doesn't come just from other fast-casual chains, either. Darren Tristano, president of Technomic, a research and consulting firm, points out that some companies face increased competition from chains that don't fall under the fast-casual umbrella.
Panera Faces Bakery Rivals

"There are a number of menu categories that are starting to see some maturity, including bakery cafes," Tristano told IBD. "Panera is the leader in the bakery cafe segment. It's not only seeing competition from other fast-casual chains, but also from Starbucks and drive-through chains like Dunkin' Brands (DNKN). A lot of fast-food players are really pushing the convenience of drive-through."
Companies that focus on more narrow niches should fare better. Tristano points to Zoe's, which specializes in healthier Mediterranean dishes.
"That's a good category where there's not a lot of competition and plenty of room to grow," Tristano said.
Chipotle Pain, Qdoba Gain?

The Mexican category is "still dominated by Chipotle," Tristano said, though he added that Qdoba Mexican Eats, owned by Jack in the Box (JACK), is continuing to grow in a lot of markets where it overlaps with Chipotle.

The wild card is how Chipotle's E. coli woes will affect the competitive landscape. The outbreak has spread across nine states and sickened more than 50 customers. The chain also came under question when 150 people who ate at a Boston Chipotle contracted norovirus.
Chipotle's woes could open up opportunities for other fast-casual chains to pick up market share.

"For every loser, there will be a winner, and Panera will be the real winner at the start," said Maxim's Anderson. "Even though Panera is not a direct competitor to Chipotle in terms of Mexican food, they have a lot of geographic overlap and share the same types of customer."
Anderson recently made Zoe's a top pick for 2016, saying that its compelling menu, demographic targets and solid economics all support continued expansion.
Tristano is among those who reckon that Chipotle can bounce back and re-establish itself as a force in the restaurant industry.

"Fortunately for Chipotle and other brands, consumers tend to be very forgiving," he said. "The Chipotle brand has a very strong customer following, and because of that they are still in a great posi tion. Of course, they still have to ensure quality and safety, which they are very focused on right now."
Even though fast-casual chains have stumbled of late, many industry watchers still have a positive outlook on the sector.
Sit-Down Still No Standout
Tristano forecasts 7.1% unit growth for fast-casual chains in 2016, in contrast to around 1% for full-service eateries.
"There's still a market-share shift away from more traditional full-service/fast-food categories and toward fast-casual," Tristano said.
That's mainly because consumers continue to gravitate toward what fast-casual chains offer, according to analyst Charles.

"The appeal to consumers is higher-quality food in a faster time frame," Charles said. "That's not going out of style."It's understandable if executives at Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and other fast-casual restaurant chains are feeling a little heartburn heading into the new year.The recent E. coli outbreak at dozens of Chipotle restaurants was enough to give the whole restaurant sector indigestion, considering that Chipotle had been one of the industry's leading lights earlier in the year. Even before the E. coli news hit, though, Chipotle and other fast-casual chains were falling out of favor on Wall Street."It's been a tough market for high-beta restaurant stocks," Cowen & Co. analyst Andrew Charles told IBD. JPMorgan Chase downgraded Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) to neutral Tuesday after another bout of E. Coli cases was linked to restaurants in Kansas, North Dakota and Oklahoma. Shares closed down 5.25% on the stock market today to a 19-month low of 494.61. The stock tumbled 3.5% on Monday. Apple's (AAPL) price target was lowered from 135 to 130 by Cowen,…
Early stock market gains shriveled going into the noon hour Tuesday, as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) was hammered for a fourth straight day after an analyst downgraded the stock.

The Nasdaq was up 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were trading 0.4% higher in the stock market today. Volume was tracking lower than the same time Monday on both major exchanges.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 16 were lower and 34 were higher. Alaska Air (ALK) was among the worst performers, down 3%. Stifel Nicolaus analyst Joseph DeNardi downgraded the stock from buy to hold. The stock has dipped below a 82.88 buy point from a late-stage flat base.
At the same time, DeNardi upgraded shares ofSpirit Airlines (SAVE) from hold to buy. The stock rose nearly 4% at one point, but was trading well below its 200-day moving average.

The best performer on the IBD 50 was Alibaba (BABA), up more than 2%. It's nearing a 86.52 buy point in a flat base that is part of a larger structure. The stock remains below the close of its Sept. 19, 2014, first day of trading and has much overhead supply to work through.

Beleaguered Chipotle Mexican Grill fell 4% and was struggling for support at the 500 price level after JPMorgan downgraded shares to neutral and set a 555 price target. On Monday, the Centers for Disease Control reported that "rare DNA fingerprints of Shiga toxin-producing E. coli" have been found in five people who ate at the restaurant in three states and who reported their illnesses from Nov. 18 to 26. The stock has fallen 29% since a disappointing earnings report Oct. 20 and reports of food-borne illnesses at its restaurants across the country.

Among other movers, shares of Weibo (WB) gained nearly 3% in above-average volume.Early stock market gains shriveled going into the noon hour Tuesday, as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) was hammered for a fourth straight day after an analyst downgraded the stock.The Nasdaq was up 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were trading 0.4% higher in the stock market today. Volume was tracking lower than the same time Monday on both major exchanges.Among IBD 50 stocks, 16 were lower and 34 were higher. Alaska Air (ALK) was among the worst performers, down 3%. Stifel Nicolaus analyst Joseph DeNardi downgraded the stock from buy to hold. The stock has dipped below a 82.88 buy point from a late-stage flat base.At the same time, DeNardi upgraded shares ofSpirit Airlines (SAVE) from hold to buy. The stock rose nearly 4% at one point, but was trading well below its 200-day moving average.The best performer on the IBD 50 was Alibaba (BABA), up more than 2%. It's nearing a 86.52 buy point in a flat base that is part of a larger structure. The stock remains below the close of its Sept. 19, 2014, first day of trading and has much overhead supply to work through.Beleaguered Chipotle Mexican Grill fell 4% and was struggling for support at the 500 price level after JPMorgan downgraded shares to neutral and set a 555 price target. On Monday, the Centers for Disease Control reported that "rare DNA fingerprints of Shiga toxin-producing E. coli" have been found in five people who ate at the restaurant in three states and who reported their illnesses from Nov. 18 to 26. The stock has fallen 29% since a disappointing earnings report Oct. 20 and reports of food-borne illnesses at its restaurants across the country.Among other movers, shares of Weibo (WB) gained nearly 3% in above-average volume.
Stocks stepped into narrow gains in weak trade Tuesday, holding their ground despite a weak reading on existing-home sales in November. The Dow Jones industrial average stuck with a 0.2% gain.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 held up 0.1% gains apiece. Sellers appeared to be focusing on the small caps, sending the Russell 2000 down 0.2%.
Volume sagged 16% on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq relative to activity at the same time Monday.
A slight downgrade to the Commerce Department's Q3 GDP growth estimate was in line with expectations, but may have helped place some early pressure on the stock market today.

Housing price growth slowed, but not quite as much as expected, in October, according to the Federal Housing Finance Agency's Housing Price Index. It rose 0.5% for the month, down from a 0.8% increase in September but better than estimates for 0.4% growth.

Existing-home sales slowed sharply to an annualized rate of 4.76 million in November, the National Association of Realtors said. The group also revised October's sales rate lower to 5.32 million. Consensus estimates had projected a pace of 5.32 million homes sold in November.

In stocks, Nike (NKE) jumped to the front of the Dow with a 1.3% gain. The athleticwear maker reports fiscal second-quarter results after today's close. Chevron (CVX) took the index's worst decline, down 0.9%
NetApp (NTAP) tumbled more than 7% as a pair of analyst downgrades followed the announcement late Monday that it would acquire flash memory gear maker SolidFire for $870 million.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) shed 4% at the open. The Centers for Disease Control said on Monday it was investigating an additional outbreak of E.coli contamination that could be linked to the fast-casual food chain. JPMorgan downgraded the stock to neutral in a note declaring the CDC's newest investigation gives "rational and informed customers" cause to think twice before choosing to eat at Chipotle. The stock is down 34% from an October high.

Marriott International (MAR) and Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) each popped 3% at the start of trade. Marriott filed S-4 registration documents related to the proposed $12.2 billion acquisition of Starwood announced in November. Marriott also said it would begin share repurchases immediately, projecting a total of $2.2 billion in share purchases in 2015. The stock is near lows in a consolidation begun in March.

Two-in-five IBD 50 stocks rose out of the starting gates. Gains were mild and led by China-based Alibaba (BABA),which climbed 1.7%. The stock has built a seven-week flat base with healthy support and an 86.52 buy point.
J2 Global (JCOM) also ranked high, with a 1.2% gain. The Internet-based fax, voicemail and call-service provider is testing its 10-week line of support, 5% above a 75.72 cup base buy point.

Alaska Air (ALK) fell 2.8%, the worst decline among IBD 50 stocks. Stifel downgraded the stock to hold from buy. The stock is struggling to hold support at its 10-week moving average, just below an 80.22 buy point in a late-stage flat base.Stocks stepped into narrow gains in weak trade Tuesday, holding their ground despite a weak reading on existing-home sales in November.
