Olive Garden parent Darden Restaurants beat fiscal-second-quarter earnings estimates and boosted full-year forecasts Friday, indicating fresh upside from modernized service and stronger finances following a management shakeup. Earnings per share nearly doubled to 54 cents, well above views for 42 cents, helped by lower dairy, seafood and company costs. Sales rose 3.2% to $1.61 billion but missed forecasts for $1.62…

Embattled restaurant chain Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) had its price target slashed early Thursday, while Micron Technology (MU) also got a price target cut and payment processing firm Global Payments (GPN) had its price target raised following a major buyout announcement earlier this week. On an abbreviated trading day on Wall Street, Telsey Advisory Group lowered its price target on…

The decision by McDonald's (MCD) in October to launch all-day breakfast service has so far tapped into the nation's love of breakfast and its hatred of time constraints, according to research released Wednesday from the NPD Group. The market research firm found that more diners want breakfast from the gargantuan fast-food chain during breakfast and lunch, and apparently with their…
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) shares plunged Friday after authorities said that three more states reported people infected with E. coli after eating at the restaurant chain.
The outbreak has now been linked to six states — California, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Oregon and Washington — and has sickened 45 people.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said that it was still investigating the specific food item linked to the illness.
Chipotle shares crashed 12.3% to close at 536.19 in the stock market today, hitting the lowest level since May 2014.

Last week, Chipotle reopened 43 restaurants in Seattle and Portland, Ore., that it had closed "out of an abundance of caution" following an E. coli outbreak after health officials said that there was "no ongoing risk" from the incident.

Stocks kicked off a shortened week of trading Monday with solid gains in light volume. A flurry of buying lifted indexes to session highs in the last half hour of trading.
The Nasdaq added 0.9%, the S&P 500 rose 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average picked up 0.7%. Small caps lagged with the Russell 2000 up just 0.3%.
Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in well below Friday's elevated levels due to options expiration.

In the stock market today, it was a case of "sell the news" for two stocks closely associated with "Star Wars." Disney (DIS) lost 1% despite news the movie made an estimated $238 million in the U.S. and Canada over the weekend. Movie-theater company Imax (IMAX), meanwhile, plunged 4%. Sellers have been in the stock since last week's breakout attempt.
Elsewhere, Fitbit (FIT) jumped 5% after Pacific Crest Securities said holiday sales at Fitbit have picked up considerably since Black Friday.
ChipmakerMacom Technology (MTSI) added to gains after a recent breakout over a 38.69 cup-with-handle buy point. Share rose 4%.

Also in the chip space, Avago (AVGO) continues to work on a nice base. Shares added 4% after the Apple supplier got an upgrade from RBC Capital Markets to top pick from outperform. Avago's merger with Broadcom (BRCM) recently passed muster with the European Union.

Nike (NKE) added 1% ahead of its earnings report Tuesday after the close. It's consolidating around its 50-day moving average. Wall Street cheered Nike's last earnings report on Sept. 24. Shares soared 9% on the news.
On the downside, Chipotle (CMG) crashed another 3.5% after the Centers for Disease Control linked the restaurant chain to more E. coli outbreaks in three states.

Stocks were nicely higher in late-afternoon trading Thursday, a welcome development after Wednesday's drubbing. The Dow Jones industrial average, which held up the best Wednesday, outperformed, rising 1.1%.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 added 0.9% each. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking about 20% lower than Wednesday's levels.
Oil was on track for its fifth straight loss. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil futures lost another 37 cents, or 1%, to $36.79 a barrel.
Nasdaq advancing stocks outnumbered decliners by a 3-to-2 margin. The ratio was less than that on the NYSE.
Steel and airline stocks outperformed. Utilities lagged.
In the stock market today, Chipotle (CMG) rallied 4% after founder Steve Ells went on the "Today" show and apologized for diners getting sick. The stock remains depressed.

Twitter (TWTR) was another standout performer, rising 7.5%. But it's still damaged goods at 51% off its high. The company announced Thursday it will start showing ads to its "logged out" audience, or about 500 million people who visit the site every month.
After the close, watch for earnings from Adobe Systems (ADBE). Shares lost 0.2%. It's still holding above its 10-week moving average after a mid-October breakout.
Restoration Hardware (RH) also reports after the close. Institutional selling has started to crop up in the stock ahead of the results. Shares fell nearly 2%.

On the same day Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) unveiled a new food safety program, the fast-casual burrito chain got hit with more bad news: An E. coli outbreak at its eateries has now expanded to nine states, pushing the company's reeling stock price down even further. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said four new E. coli cases have…

Shares of Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) gapped up Thursday after a televised apology by its co-CEO and indications that an investigation into recent E. coli infections may be ending. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says on its website that the E. coli outbreak has reached nine states and sickened 52 people as of Thursday, hospitalizing 20 of them.…

Dave & Buster's Entertainment swung to a profit in its third quarter, far surpassing Wall Street estimates, and lifted its full-year outlook Tuesday as it casts an eye beyond the U.S. For the fiscal year ending Jan. 31, the arcade-restaurant chain, which went public last year, sees revenue of $857 million-$861 million, up from a prior view of $844 million-$853…

After opening sharply lower, stocks staged an abrupt reversal, and for a time just before noon the Nasdaq was trading higher before softening. Oil, which was trading below $37 a barrel in the morning, its lowest level in seven years, also reversed and was trading up to 1% higher going into the noon hour.The Nasdaq was down 0.2%, the S&P 500 lost 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 0.7% in the stock market today. Volume was tracking lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq exchange compared with the same time Monday.The 10 a.m. ET release of the job openings and labor turnover survey, or JOLTS, also seemed to give the market a lift. The government reported that U.S. job openings fell 151,000 in October to 5.383 million.Outerwall (OUTR), operator of more than 40,000 Redbox movie-dispensing kiosks, gapped down and was trading 22% lower. The company slashed its fiscal 2015 guidance and said it will shutter its Sampleit kiosks. It also announced the resignation of Redbox president Mark Horak.United Natural Foods (UNFI) gapped to a new low and was trading 17% lower after reporting weaker-than-expected results.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) was 1% lower, but had been down more following reports that 20 Boston College students got sick after eating at the burrito joint. The company said it believes the culprit is a norovirus that causes gastroenteritis rather than E. coli, which has been linked to illnesses at Chipotle restaurants across the nation.

Stocks fell to moderate losses in higher-volume trade Monday, as a rising dollar and tumbling oil prices pressured the market. The three top indexes — the Nasdaq, the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 — each fell 0.6%.
Small caps were under slightly stronger pressure, with the Russell 2000 showing a 0.8% loss.
Trade rose unevenly in the stock market today, up 29% on the Nasdaq and 6% higher on the NYSE, relative to action at the same time Friday.

A strong dollar and a unrestrained production stance from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries on Friday tripped oil to break its recent trading range in early trade Monday. Europe's Brent crude benchmark dived more than 2% to below $42 per barrel, its lowest level in six years. West Texas Intermediate slumped more than 3%, holding just above its August lows and above $38.
Chevron (CVX) and Exxon-Mobil (XOM) showed the two worst early losses in the Dow, down 3.6% and 2.3%, respectively.

Nine of the 10 largest opening losses on the S&P 500 were energy-related. The other was Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which slumped as much as 6% under continued heat from investors reacting to widening E.coli contamination investigations by the Food & Drug Administration and Centers For Disease Control. Cowen & Co. downgraded the stock to market perform, from outperform and dropped the stock's price target to 515 from 775.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) swept 74% higher in early trade. The owner of the K-cup franchise agreed to be taken private in a $13.9 billion deal with an investor group spearheaded by Luxembourg-based JAB Holding. The companies expect the deal to close in the first quarter. The gain lifted shares to 44% below the stock's November 2014 high.

Airlines stocks rallied, possibly on the drop in oil prices. At the top of those gains, JetBlue (JBLUE) surged more than 5%. United Continental Holdings (UAL) jumped 3%. American Airlines Group (AAL) popped 2%.

On the IBD 50 list, Hawaiian Airlines (HA) knocked out an almost 4% gain, grabbing yet another new high in very heavy trade. The island-hopping airline is well-extended after clearing a cup-with-handle base in October.

The widest loss on the IBD 50 list was a slip of nearly 4% from BBCN Bancorp (BBCN). The Los Angeles-based banker announced plans to acquire peer Wilshire Bancorp (WIBC) in an all-stock deal it valued at around $1 billion. The stock had been pulling back from a Nov. 24 high, narrowing a 23% gain above a 15.94 buy point to less than 12%. The stock had been pulling back from a Nov. 24 high, narrowing a 23% gain above a 15.94 buy point to less than 12%. Wilshire shares rose more than 4%.
Stock futures winked in and out of mixed trade ahead of Thursday's open, as weak economic data counter-balanced a rebound among many commodities-related stocks.
Dow futures shed 8.3 points. Nasdaq 100 futures showed a 4.5-point gain. S&P 500 futures traded less than 1% below fair market value.

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 have both slipped in five of the past six sessions. The Nasdaq remains above its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages, a positive. The S&P 500 on Wednesday stabbed straight through both lines of support in above-average trade — not good. Distribution days continue to climb, signaling selling by large investors and placing yet more pressure on the market.
So far for the week, the Nasdaq starts the session down 2.3%. The S&P 500 opens 2.1% in the hole. Small caps are clearly lagging, with the Russell 2000 and the S&P Small Cap 600 each off 3.2%.
The stock market today gets the week's first real dose of economic news.

The Labor Department reported unemployment claims veered sharply higher, to 282,000 claims, in the week ended Dec. 5. That was nearly 5% above the prior week's tally and far above economists' consensus projections for 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average edged up to 270,750, its second straight gain.

Prices of exports slipped more than expected in November, down 0.6% vs. forecasts for a 0.3% slip. That means U.S. producers are being paid less for their goods. Import prices also slipped less than expected, down 0.4% vs. estimates for a 0.8% decline.
The Treasury is due to report its November budget at 2 p.m.
In stocks, the Dow was flat to positive with advancing stocks holding to gains of less than 0.5%. DuPont (DD) trailed the group with a 1.1% slip.
Coal miner Consol Energy (CNX) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) topped the S&P 500, up about 3% each.

At the bottom of the index, First Solar (FSLR) dropped 9% after the company released 2016 guidance late Wednesday. The midpoint of revenue projections of between $3.9 billion and $4.1 billion missed analyst expectations.
Gold miners mustered a premarket rally, with Anglogold Ashanti (AU) and Sibanye Gold (SBGL) ahead around 6% before the bell.

Fiber optic gear maker Ciena (CIEN) crumbled 10%. The Hanover, Md.-based operation reported better-than-expected fiscal fourth quarter sales and earnings, but management's Q1 and full-year revenue guidance stopped short of analyst projections.

Men'S Wearhouse (MW) tanked 20% after reporting weak Q3 revenue late Wednesday. Comparable sales at Jos. A. Bank stores fell 14.1%. in the quarter, and management said Q4-to-date comparable sales were down 35.1% at Jos. A. Bank stores, but up 5.5% across the rest of the company.
Most leaders on the IBD 50 list were flat ahead of the open. Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) and ARM Holdings (ARMH) topped the group, up slightly more than 1% each.
On Wednesday, Dave & Buster's aggressively trimmed a 9% early gain to a 0.3% advance at the close. The backtrack pulled shares back below a 40.90 buy point in a double-bottom base.
At the other end of the IBD 50 list, Tesoro (TSO) dropped 0.7% — the worst premarket loss in the group.

Markets overseas moved generally lower. The main indexes in Hong Kong and Shanghai fell 0.5% each. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo gave up 1.3%, putting it down 2.3% so far for the week. In Europe, leading indexes in Paris, London and Frankfurt were down less than 0.5% at midday. Stocks backed off their opening surge Thursday to struggle with whisper-thin gains in weak trade. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.1%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 added less than 0.1% each.
Volume weakened in the stock market today, slipping 20% on the NYSE and 11% on the Nasdaq, relative to activity at the same time Wednesday.

Early economic news was below par, with weekly jobless claims rising and export prices falling more than expected, and import price easing only half as far as economists had estimated. The Treasury Department reports its November budget at 2 p.m. ET.
Apple (AAPL) topped the Dow with a 0.5% gain. DuPont (DD) brought up the rear, down more than 1%.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) posted the S&P 500's best early move, surging 5%. Company Chief Executive Steve Ells apologized to customers who fell ill after eating at the restaurants and said the company was implementing broad food safety initiatives aimed at preventing future contamination. The stock added 1% Wednesday after a note from Sanford Bernstein raised expectations that the company would launch significant "traffic driving initiatives" after the chain earns a clean bill of health from the Centers for Disease Control. The stock is still trading 25% below a mid-October high.

Consol Energy (CNX), Fossil (FOSL) and Ball (BLL) were close behind, all up more than 2%. First Solar (FSLR) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) fell to the bottom of the index, down 7% and 4%, respectively.
Department stores jumped into an early rally behind Bon-Ton Stores (BONT), which perked up 5%. J.C. Penney (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) each gained more than 2%

LendingTree (TREE) vaulted 9% after Bank of America upgraded the stock to buy from neutral. The online mortgage lender is still below its 10-week moving average in a sloppy, three-month consolidation.
Dave & Buster's (PLAY) and Hawaiian (HA) led the IBD 50 stocks.
Dave & Buster's rose nearly 3%, moving to just below a 40.90 buy point in a double-bottom base.

Hawaiian's 2% gain hoisted shares to near their Dec. 7 high. No buy point is in sight, however, with the stock 50% past a 25.69 buy point after breaking out of a cup-with-handle base in early October.

Today's after-hours session calls for quarterly reports from Adobe Systems (ADBE), Finisar (FNSR), Nordson (NDSN) and Restoration Hardware (RH).Stocks backed off their opening surge Thursday to struggle with whisper-thin gains in weak trade. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.1%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 added less than 0.1% each.Volume weakened in the stock market today, slipping 20% on the NYSE and 11% on the Nasdaq, relative to activity at the same time Wednesday.Early economic news was below par, with weekly jobless claims rising and export prices falling more than expected, and import price easing only half as far as economists had estimated. The Treasury Department reports its November budget at 2 p.m. ET.Apple (AAPL) topped the Dow with a 0.5% gain. DuPont (DD) brought up the rear, down more than 1%.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) posted the S&P 500's best early move, surging 5%. Stock futures steered deep into the red Tuesday as investors continued to exit energy issues and show no tolerance for company earnings and operational slip-ups.

Dow futures veered 135.5 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures nosed down 41.5 points. S&P 500 futures unspooled 16 points. Small caps were taking hard early hits, sending Russell 2000 futures down 9 points.
The stock market today again gets only a small dose of economic news. The Labor Department delivers its Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey at 10 a.m. ET.

Oil futures were mixed early Tuesday, with Brent crude up, West Texas Intermediate down a fraction after diving nearly 6% each — to multiyear lows — on Monday. The dollar eased vs. the euro after a firm advance on Monday, holding well below Thursday's high.

Metal and mining issues were under some serious early pressure after U.K.-based Anglo American announced a stringent restructuring plan and also eliminated its dividend for the remainder of 2015 and all of 2016.
Anglo shares dived nearly 10% on the London Stock Exchange. ArcelorMittal (MT), Rio Tinto (RIO), BHP Billiton (BHP) and Vale (VALE) all fell 6% to 7% in premarket action.
Dow stocks were in a foul mood, nearly all trading lower, with Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) again diving deepest, down almost 2% apiece.
Energy-related issues also posted most of the worst losses among S&P 500 stocks. Chesapeake Energy (CHK) sank to the bottom of the list, down more than 5%.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) continued to lose value, down 5% on news reports of 28 Boston College students and facility staff falling ill after eating at one of the restaurants. The stock ended Monday down 27% since Oct. 13.
Power utility NRG (NRG) rose 3%, the S&P 500's top premarket gain. The stock is rebounding from a 22% tumble last week after long-time Chief Executive David Crane suddenly resigned.
Quarterly reports had slowed to a trickle, but still figured into early action.
Kids apparel retailer Children's Place (PLCE) jumped 5% after a mixed third-quarter report.
Redbox movie rental kiosk owner Outerwall (OUTR) tumbled 22% after management lowered its full-year 2015 EPS and revenue guidance to well below analyst consensus views.

The company also said President Mark Horak was resigning and that Chief Executive Erik Prusch would act also as interim president. Outerwall shares last week stumbled out of an attempt to climb the right side of a four-month consolidation.
Organic distributor United Natural Foods (UNFI) toppled 11% after weak fiscal Q1 results.

Leaders on both the IBD 50 and Your Weekly Review lists were divided, with more down than up. Pre-opening gains were fractional for Hawaiian (HA) and LinkedIn (LNKD). The hardest hit IBD 50 stocks was Universal Display (OLED), down a bit less than 3%. Universal has been running into resistance as its fights to clear a 55.93 buy point in a deep cup base.

Stock futures traded lower, but steady ahead of Monday's open as oil prices and the Federal Reserve tested investor confidence. Dow futures traded 40.2 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures hung 5.5 points below the line. Nasdaq 100 futures were off a mild 7.6 points. Small caps were under disproportionate pressure, with Russell 2000 futures falling 8.2 points.The stock market today opens under a clear caution flag ahead of Wednesday's policy decision from the Federal Reserve. The Nasdaq dropped 4.1% last week, slicing below support at both its 200-day and 50-day moving averages. The S&P 500 crumpled 3.8%, also violating both levels of support. That means all bets are off on the market's direction for the next two days.Within that uncertainty, oil prices continued diving early Monday, with West Texas Intermediate down more than 2% to below 35% a barrel, its lowest mark in more than a decade. Brent crude dropped nearly 3%, below $37, to its weakest level since 2008. Both benchmarks have logged steady losses since the Dec. 4 Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting, in which the group failed to agree on a production quota, permitting member countries to continue current production levels.Despite the oil price slump, it was DuPont (DD) and Apple (AAPL) that dragged down the Dow before the open. DuPont dipped more than 1%.Apple trimmed its premarket loss to 1%, up from a 3% dive, after Morgan Stanley cut its price target to 143 from 162, citing pressure on international iPhone prices due to oversupply outside China. Apple ended Friday well off an August low, but struggling to retake its 10-week moving average within a five-month consolidation.Jarden (JAH) jumped 5%, Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) slipped more than 2% after Newell said it would pay $13.2 billion in a cash/stock deal to acquire the Boca Raton, Fla.-based maker of Sunbeam irons, Marmot outdoor gear and Crock-Pot cookware.Newell management said the combination is targeting $500 million in annualized cost savings, would be immediately positive for earnings, and should close in Q2 of 2016. Jarden rose 9% last week on merger speculation, moving the stock up the right side of a five-month consolidation.China-based maker of solar electrical components Trina Solar (TSL) spiked 9% on news reports that the company had received an offer to be taken private at $11.60 per share by Shanghai Xingsheng Equity Investment & Management. The offer was 321% above Friday's closing price.Edwards Lifesciences (EW) was confusing brokerage data collection systems in premarket trade, as it prepared to go live with its 2-for-1 stock split at today's open. It is the company's first stock split since May 2010.Overseas, Europe's stocks came off their lows near midday. London's FTSE 100 reversed early losses and wrestled into narrowly positive territory. Frankfurt's DAX was down 0.8%, up from a 1.2% loss. The Cac-40 in Paris eased to a 0.4% loss, from 0.6%.Asia's markets were widely mixed: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dipped 0.7%, the Shanghai Composite jumped 2.5% and the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo stumbled to a 1.8% loss.

Stocks were sharply lower approaching the noon hour Monday as Wall Street was jittery about another sharp fall in oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 gave up 1.1% and the Nasdaq lost 1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq was tracking slightly higher than Friday's level. NYSE volume was tracking close to Friday's levels.

Monday's weak showing illustrates why it's important to tread cautiously when the distribution day count is elevated, as it is now. Headed into Monday, the Nasdaq showed eight distribution days in recent weeks. The S&P 500 has seven. Distribution days point toward institutional selling.

In the stock market today, airlines outperformed again amid another precipitous drop in oil prices. JetBlue (JBLU) rallied 4% as it tries to clear a flat base with a conventional entry at 27.46. Alaska Air (ALK) extended gains after last week's breakout over an 82.88 buy point. Shares rose another 1%.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, WTI crude oil futures plunged $1.88, or 4.7%, to $38.09 a barrel. The 10-year Treasury yield was down 5 basis points to 2.22%.
Lower oil prices have finally found their way to the pump, but some worry that oil's recent plunge could be flagging sluggish economic growth ahead.

Meanwhile, shares of Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell another 3% to a 52-week low. Late Friday, the company withdrew its 2016 same-store sales guidance and offered a weak Q4 outlook after new E. coli cases were linked to the restaurant chain. Shares are now down about 30% from a high of 757 in mid-October.
On the upside, Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) soared 73% on news that it's being taken private in a $13.9 billion deal valuing the company at 92 a share.

Avago Technologies (AVGO) edged higher after surging 13.5% last week on strong earnings. While last week's bullish move qualified as a breakout, Avago is near the top of a six-month consolidation. Early Monday, it was trading less than 2% off its all-time high of 150.50.

Action camera maker GoPro (GPRO) got its price target cut Monday, while embattled restaurant chain Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) suffered a series of downgrades and price target cuts of its own.
Analysts also made calls on biotech startup Bluebird Bio (BLUE), Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) and new issue Ferrari (RACE) .

JPMorgan trimmed GoPro's target to 45 from 55. On Friday, Robert W. Baird downgraded GoPro to neutral from outperform and slashed its price target to 18 from 36. Shares were hit last week, when chip supplier Ambarella (AMBA) gave weak guidance due in part to soft sales for action camera.
GoPro shares lost 2.9% in the stock market today. Ambarella gave up 4.2%.
Cowen & Co. and Guggenheim Securities both downgraded Chipotle — the former to market perform, the latter to neutral — while Maxim Group lowered its price target on the stock to 495 from 585.
Reports said Friday that the E. coli outbreak at Chipotle had expanded to nine states. The outbreak has sickened dozens of customers and forced the closure of 43 restaurants.
Chipotle shares sank 8% to a 1-1/2-year low of 515 early Monday before recovering later in the session. The stock closed down 1.7%.

Bluebird Bio's stock price tumbled 37.5% after it was downgraded to neutral from buy at Roth Capital and had its price target chopped nearly in half to 62 from 121. Over the weekend, Bluebird presented disappointing gene therapy data at the American Society of Hematology annual meeting.

Teva's stock price rose 0.4% after being initiated with a buy rating at Mizuho Securities. Last week, Reuters reported that the generic drugmaker is divesting about $1 billion worth of assets to address antitrust concerns over its deal to buy Allergan 's (AGN) generic drug business.
Shares of Home Depot (HD) fell 0.4% even after its price target was raised to 148 from 133 by Telsey Advisory Group, which has an outperform rating on the stock.

Sports and luxury car manufacturer Ferrari, which had its initial public offering in October, was initiated at overweight and given a 56 price target by Morgan Stanley. Ferrari shares rose 1.1% Monday but were still down more than 10% from their closing price on the first day of trading.
Abbott Laboratories (ABT) climbed 0.6% after it was upgraded to buy at Jefferies and given a 55 price target.
Shares of Big Pharma firm Eli Lilly (LLY) lost 0.3% despite scoring an upgrade to buy at Deutsche Bank. That followed an upgrade to overweight by Barclays last week.

Stocks pared their gains sharply in the last hour of trading as the major indexes closed well off their session highs. The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.5% gain while the Nasdaq rose 0.4% and the S&P 500 climbed 0.2%.
Volume was lighter across the board, according to early figures. Winners outpaced losers by a slight margin on the Nasdaq while decliners edged past advancers on the NYSE.

Lending, steel and airline issues outperformed in the stock market today. Oil stocks were higher too, despite a continued slide in crude prices, which closed below $37 a barrel. Solar, utilities and telecom issues lagged.

LendingTree (TREE) rallied 11% in volume, climbing back near its 50-day moving average. The company said it's adding American Express to its credit card marketplace and expects credit card revenue to more than double quarter over quarter in Q4. Bank of America upgraded LendingTree to buy from neutral.

Smith & Wesson (SWHC) led the IBD 50 as it extended its gains for a sixth straight session with a 6% jump to a record high in fast trade. The stock has rallied more than 21% this week as gun sales soar on a renewed gun-control debate sparked by the mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif.

Global Payments (GPN) rose 3% to bounce off its 10-week moving average for the first time since an October breakout. The e-payment transaction processor and IBD 50 stock is in talks to acquire Heartland Payment Systems (HPY), according to Bloomberg. Heartland surged 9% to a new high.
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) recovered 5% in brisk turnover after founder and CEO Steve Ells apologized on TV to diners who fell ill after eating there. The stock is 24% off its early August high.

On the downside, Ciena (CIEN) gapped down and plunged 17%, falling below its 50-day and 200-day lines in massive trade. The fiber optic company's Q4 results beat views, but its Q1 revenue guidance fell short of analyst estimates.

Like Costco Wholesale (COST) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Starbucks (SBUX) was recently hit with an E. coli scare. While the coffee giant had to pull its "holiday turkey with stuffing paninis" from West Coast stores as a result, its stock remained relatively unfazed by the outbreak. But selling pressure in the general market now has Starbucks testing support…

Starbucks (SBUX) pulled some of its sandwiches due to an E. coli scare, but its stock action shows it's still dreaming of a White Christmas espresso breakout. The coffee giant pulled its "holiday turkey with stuffing paninis" from West Coast stores last month since they contained celery from the same source that delivered E. coli-contaminated produce to Costco Wholesale[ticker…

Stocks sold off but pared losses in the last hour of the regular trading session to close off their intraday lows. The Nasdaq fell 0.8%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.7% each.Volume was lower on the NYSE but slightly higher on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.Energy stocks got slammed in the stock market today, as crude oil prices fell to 6-year lows. Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM), down 3% each, were the biggest Dow losers. Gold miners, steel and biotechs were also down hard.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), down as much as 8% intraday, closed with a 2% loss. The stock got hit with as spate of downgrades and price cuts after Friday reports the E. coli outbreak had expanded to nine states. The restaurant operator also give a weak Q4 outlook.But Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) soared 72% on news it's being taken private in a $13.9 billion deal valuing the company at $92 a share.Airlines also gained. JetBlue Airways (JBLU) lifted 4% in fast trade as it builds the right side of a flat base with a 27.46 buy point. Airlines got a boost from the drop in oil prices, as fuel accounts for nearly a third of their expenses.Fellow IBD 50 stock Hawaiian Holdings (HA) gained 2% to a new closing high. Shares of JetBlue and Hawaiian have rallied more than 65% and 50%, respectively, this year.Gun makers had a good day amid revived focus on gun control after last week's mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif. Smith & Wesson (SWHC) surged 8% to an eight-year high, clearing a 19.07 cup-with-handle buy point in massive volume. It reports quarterly results Tuesday after the close.Sturm Ruger (RGR) leapt 6%, retaking its 50-day and 200-day moving average lines in active trade. The gun maker is working on a base with a possible 66.21 trigger.Economic data on tap for Tuesday include the small business optimism index for November and the Labor Department's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) for October.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo.

The stock market served up more choppiness and more M&A deals — two defining trends of 2015 — to ETF investors in the past month. Market volatility rose to a two-month high. Chemical giants DuPont (DD) and Dow (DOW) clinched a deal to merge. Against that backdrop, investors piled into large-cap exchange traded funds. Dividend payers and low volatility ETF…

Let's take a look at five stocks on IBD's Stocks on the Move screen, which are seeing some big-volume action: Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Dycom Industries (DY), Fitbit (FIT), Pfizer (PFE) and Allergan (AGN). Chipotle is rebounding today from a loss of more than 12% on Friday. The fast-casual Mexican chain has been suffering from an E. coli outbreak that's…

In a Monday morning note upgrading Panera to buy from hold and raising its price target to 210 from 208, Maxim Group analyst Stephen Anderson…

Newly split Hewlett Packard companies Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and HP Inc.  (HPQ) got analysts' actions Monday ahead of their earnings report late Tuesday, while Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) was downgraded after an E. coli outbreak spread to three more states. Maxim Group upgraded HP Inc., the legacy computer and printer business, from hold to buy, but lowered its…
Stock futures struggled to hold narrow gains Monday as the market prepared for a holiday-shortened week of trade. Dow futures were up 109 points, down from a 26-point gain an hour earlier.
Nasdaq 100 futures slimmed their advance to 4.8 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures hovered with a slim, 1.8-point gain. Small caps lagged, with Russell 2000 futures slipping 1.6 points.

The stock market today starts the week under some mixed signals. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 posted strong gains last week and retook support at their 200-day moving averages. But the Nasdaq also held on to its six distribution days, and the S&P 500 stalled on Friday, raising its distribution day count to six. The measure shows high levels of institutional selling, showing large investors are to some degree working against what is currently a confirmed uptrend.

Volume typically fades moving toward the Thanksgiving holiday on Thursday. Stock and bond markets will reopen Friday, but only for short sessions. Markets in London, Paris, Frankfurt, Hong Kong and Shanghai are open throughout the week. Tokyo's market will restart tomorrow and trade through the remainder of the week following its Labor Thanksgiving break today.

In economic news, researcher Markit is on tap to release its November manufacturing purchasing managers index at 9:45 a.m. ET. The National Association of Realtors reports October existing-home sales at 10 a.m.

Crude oil continued to its recent split trade, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate down more than 1% to just above $41 a barrel. Europe's Brent crude rose a fraction to near $45. Gold slipped 1%. Silver fell more than 1% and copper dropped almost 2%.
In stocks, Pfizer (PFE) and Allergan (AGN) agreed to a $155 billion combination. The deal had been highly anticipated, sending Allergan shares only a fraction higher and Pfizer down nearly 2%.
Peabody Energy (BTU) rumbled up 19%. The St. Louis-based miner announced it would sell its coal assets in Colorado and New Mexico to Bowie Resource partners in a $358 million cash deal.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) slumped 3%, still under pressure after a 12% dive on Friday triggered by a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announcement that additional cases of E. coli contamination had been linked to the restaurant chain.

Some Argentina-based issues were in motion after center-right candidate Mauricio Macri won the country's run-off presidential election by a narrow margin. IBD 50 stock Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL) jumped more than 3%. The stock ended Friday at a new high and extended 10% above a 26.23 buy point. Oil and gas producer YPF Sociedad Anonima (YPF) jumped 4%. The Global X MSCI Argentina (ARGT) exchange traded fund leapt more than 6%.

The pace of quarterly reports slows significantly this week, but Ireland-based drugmaker Mallinckrodt (MNK) punched up 7% after revenue and earnings cleared analyst consensus estimates in its fiscal fourth quarter.

Capital Bank Financial (CBF), one of IBD's current Your Weekly Review stocks, jumped 8% in premarket action. The thinly traded stock finished Friday still in buying range above a flat base buy point of 32.70.

Follow Alan Elliott on Twitter @IBD_AElliott.Stock futures struggled to hold narrow gains Monday as the market prepared for a holiday-shortened week of trade. Dow futures were up 109 points, down from a 26-point gain an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures slimmed their advance to 4.8 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures hovered with a slim, 1.8-point gain. Small caps lagged, with Russell 2000 futures slipping 1.6 points.The stock market today starts the week under some mixed signals. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 posted strong gains last week and retook support at their 200-day moving averages. But the Nasdaq also held on to its six distribution days, and the S&P 500 stalled on Friday, raising its distribution day count to six. The measure shows high levels of institutional selling, showing large investors are to some degree working against what is currently a confirmed uptrend.Volume typically fades moving toward the Thanksgiving holiday on Thursday. Stock and bond markets will reopen Friday, but only for short sessions. Markets in London, Paris, Frankfurt, Hong Kong and Shanghai are open throughout the week. Tokyo's market will restart tomorrow and trade through the remainder of the week following its Labor Thanksgiving break today.In economic news, researcher Markit is on tap to release its November manufacturing purchasing managers index at 9:45 a.m. ET. The National Association of Realtors reports October existing-home sales at 10 a.m.Crude oil continued to its recent split trade, with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate down more than 1% to just above $41 a barrel. Europe's Brent crude rose a fraction to near $45. Gold slipped 1%. Silver fell more than 1% and copper dropped almost 2%.In stocks, Pfizer (PFE) and Allergan (AGN) agreed to a $155 billion combination. The deal had been highly anticipated, sending Allergan shares only a fraction higher and Pfizer down nearly 2%.Peabody Energy (BTU) rumbled up 19%. The St. Louis-based miner announced it would sell its coal assets in Colorado and New Mexico to Bowie Resource partners in a $358 million cash deal.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) slumped 3%, still under pressure after a 12% dive on Friday triggered by a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announcement that additional cases of E. coli contamination had been linked to the restaurant chain.Some Argentina-based issues were in motion after center-right candidate Mauricio Macri won the country's run-off presidential election by a narrow margin. Stocks were modestly higher near midday Monday as a shortened week of trading kicked off without much fanfare. The Nasdaq led the way, rising 0.3%. Early gainers in the Nasdaq 100 included Autodesk (ADSK), JD.com (JD),Biogen (BIIB) and Monster Beverage (MNST).
The S&P 500 added 0.2%, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained less than 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking well below Friday's levels in the stock market today.
In merger news, Pfizer (PFE) and Allergan (AGN) agreed to a $160 billion combination. The deal had been highly anticipated. Shares of Pfizer and Allergan fell more than 2% each.
China-based online direct sales company JD.com added to gains on the heels of last week's earnings report. Shares rose 3% to near 31, clearing a key resistance level around 30.

Meanwhile, buyers were in NetEase (NTES) again after a breakout over a 154.98 buy point. Shares rose almost 2%. NetEase, which operates an interactive online community in China, also reported strong earnings last week.

IBD's meat products industry group was the day's best percentage gainer, helped by strength in Tyson Foods (TSN) and Pilgrim's Pride (PPC). Meat processor Tyson Foods soared 9% to a new high as investors weighed its quarterly report. Earnings per share missed expectations, but the company forecast fiscal 2016 earnings of $3.50 to $3.65 compared to the consensus estimate of $3.53. Tyson said its chicken business is benefiting from rising demand and a decline in feed costs. Group peer Pilgrim's Pride jumped 7%.
Chipotle (CMG) reversed higher after crashing 12% Friday on more E. coli problems. Shares rallied 5%.

A couple of top-rated growth names are set to report after the close today. Earnings at IBD 50 name Dycom (DY) are seen rising 71% from a year ago to $1.01 a share. Profit at Palo Alto Networks (PANW) is forecast to rise 113% to 32 cents a share.

McDonald's (MCD) is in an interesting position as it approaches its annual investor/analyst day, with a rising share price but sluggish sales as it and other fast food giants face rising competition from fast casual chains like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Shake Shack (SHAK).

The investor day meeting is scheduled for Tuesday from 1 p.m to 5 p.m. Eastern. Investors should be pretty pleased with McDonald's stock performance of late. Its shares are up about 20% for the year and touched a new high of 113.96 on Oct. 26.

That rise comes despite five straight quarters of lower sales. Its Investor's Business Daily Composite Rating of 80 out of a possible 99 is not bad, but not nearly as strong as retail-restaurant group leaders like Starbucks (SBUX), which has a 94.

Even so, McDonald's has lately rewarded investors who watched the company's stock price go sideways for much of 2015. In a Monday morning note, RBC analyst David Palmer said McDonald's stock price has mainly been driven by gains in return on invested capital as well as earnings growth and earnings-per-share revisions.
EPS growth has been driven in part by same-store sales gains in international markets, he said.

On the downside, U.S. comps "(have) dramatically slowed," Palmer noted. "The company's struggles inside the U.S. have been the most troubling since declining same-store sales have been the result of significant share losses in an otherwise healthy U.S. fast food market in 2015."

One thing Palmer will be looking for from Tuesday's meeting is whether certain company initiatives, including a bigger national advertising push, will drive higher sales of improved menu items such as the Quarter Pounder and Buttermilk Crispy Chicken Sandwich.
What else should investors look for from the gathering?

 Menu upgrades. Publicly traded changes such as Chipotle and Shake Shack, as well as privately held ones like In-N-Out Burger and Chic-fil-A, have raised the bar in terms of consumer expectations regarding fresh, quality ingredients.

McDonald's has made similar moves by working to improve its crispy and grilled chicken offerings, as well as the size and prep methods of its premium burgers, Palmer said. Look for the company to continue looking for ways to upgrade its offerings.
"Improving its core premium quality is going to be one way it can be more like the best-in-class burger/sandwich chains," Palmer said.
 Continued focus on breakfast. McDonald's recently took pains to announce plans to serve certain breakfast items throughout the day, including its popular Egg McMuffin sandwich.
The results so far have been positive, Palmer said. This means McDonald's might expand its all-day breakfast menu in coming months.
"We believe that McDonald's consumer base is broader at breakfast, so increased availability of breakfast items could inspire trial of other core items and day parts," Palmer said.

 Refranchising. At the investor/analyst day meeting, Palmer expects McDonald's "to reiterate its previously communicated target to refranchise 3,500 stores, taking its ownership mix to 90% (from 81% today)."
It's also possible for McDonald's "to go deeper on refranchising over time," Palmer said.
McDonald's shares fell 0.3% on the stock market today. Starbucks lost 1%, while Chipotle gave up 0.5%.

Restaurant stocks have taken a stomach-turning tumble in the last few months, with once high-flying companies like Chipotle Mexican Grill and Buffalo Wild Wings sinking about 20% since early August. IBD's Retail-Restaurants group, which ranked No. 5 at the start of 2015, now ranks 111 out of the 197 industries IBD tracks and has fallen 18% since hitting a collective…

McDonald's (MCD) held its annual investor/analyst day Tuesday on the same day that thousands of fast-food workers nationwide held protests calling for higher pay, but the company chose to focus on its growth strategies.The meeting took place as McDonald's eyes ways to better compete against fast-food rivals such as Yum Brands (YUM) — owner of the KFC and Taco Bell chains — as well as fast-casual chains like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Panera Bread (PNRA) and Shake Shack (SHAK).During the first hour of the scheduled four-hour meeting, McDonald's Chief Executive Steve Easterbrook and other officials outlined several new goals that the company looks to achieve in coming months."My priorities for McDonald's as a modern, progressive burger company are threefold: driving operational growth, creating brand excitement and enhancing financial value," Easterbrook said. "We are taking bold, urgent action to reset the business and prepare the company for the next chapter of its history."McDonald's constant-currency financial targets for 2016 include systemwide sales growth of 3% to 5% and operating income growth of 5% to 7%, excluding potential charges associated with its refranchising strategy and cost-saving initiatives.More Franchises, Fewer CostsIn terms of refranchising, the company raised its target to 4,000 restaurants from an earlier target of 3,500. This accelerates the pace and increases the global franchised percentage from the current 81% to about 93% by the end of 2018. McDonald's long-term goal is to become 95% franchised.McDonald's also raised its net annual general and administration cost-savings target to $500 million, most of which will be realized by the end of 2017. This reflects a $200 million increase from the previously announced target. The new target excludes the impact of foreign currency changes.In addition, Easterbrook said McDonald's has no plans to spin off its properties into real estate investment trusts, as had been speculated."We have given REITs serious consideration, but we don't believe it serves best the interests of shareholders to pursue REITS at this time," he said.Easterbrook also mentioned plans to grow its store count internationally and improve McDonald's level of efficiency and customer service. It looks to add more restaurants along Germany's Autobahn, for example. Meanwhile, it is looking to change the way it toasts buns and grills meat."We were not executing to our standards," he said. "We were missing customer expectations in too many places. For too long we've asked customers to adapt to us. A big part of turning that around is giving customers more choice and always adapting to meet their needs."Meanwhile, McDonald's board declared a quarterly cash dividend of 89 cents per share of common stock, payable on Dec. 15 to shareholders of record at the close of business on Dec. 1. This represents a 5% increase over its previous quarterly dividend.Protests NationwideWhile the meeting was taking place, fast-food workers in hundreds of U.S. cities held strikes and demonstrations calling for higher wages. It was the largest collection of rallies yet in a cause that seeks to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour.The demonstrations began around dawn at McDonald's locations in New York, Boston, Philadelphia and other cities. The protests are expected to continue throughout the U.S. for the remainder of the day and culminate in a rally at the Republican presidential debate in Milwaukee.Earlier this year McDonald's said it would raise wages by more than 10% for workers at U.S. restaurants that it operates, and pay at least $1 more per hour than the local minimum wage for workers at U.S. restaurants.Financially, though, the company has been in a bit of a funk of late. It has logged five straight quarters of lower sales. Year-over-year earnings have declined in four of the last five quarters, though its most recent quarter showed a 28% EPS gain. That kind of performance compares unfavorably to other stocks in IBD's Retail-Restaurants group, including Starbucks (SBUX), Chipotle and Shake Shack.Even so, McDonald's stock price has been on a nice roll lately. Shares hit a fresh high of 113.96 on Oct. 26 and are up more than 10% since Oct. 21.Growth DriversIn a Monday morning note, RBC analyst David Palmer said McDonald's stock price has mainly been driven by gains in return on invested capital as well as recent earnings growth and earnings-per-share revisions.EPS growth has been driven in part by same-store sales gains in international markets, he said.On the downside, U.S. comps "(have) dramatically slowed," Palmer noted. "The company's struggles inside the U.S. have been the most troubling since declining same-store sales have been the result of significant share losses in an otherwise healthy U.S. fast food market in 2015."On a more positive note, McDonald's recent decision to offer an all-day breakfast menu has been a success."We believe that McDonald's consumer base is broader at breakfast, so increased availability of breakfast items could inspire trial of other core items and day parts," Palmer said.McDonald's shares rose 0.3% on the stock market today. Starbucks added 1.4%, while Chipotle climbed 3.2% and Yum lost 0.3%.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.
Stocks flirted with positive territory, but dipped back into the red with just over an hour left to go in Tuesday's regular session.

The S&P 500 was fractionally lower and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq continued to lag with a 0.5% loss. Volume was mixed, tracking sharply higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq vs. the same time Monday.

Solar, video game software and automakers were among the biggest decliners in the stock market today. Tesla Motors (TSLA) skidded 3% in fast trade as the stock remains below its 50-day moving average, where it's been stuck for over a month.

Morgan Stanley said in a note that it expects Q4 and 2016 deliveries to be lower than Tesla's forecasts and that the company will burn up to $1 billon in cash over the next 12 months. It maintained a 450 price target. Tesla is now trading around 218.

Tech stocks weighed on the Dow, as Apple (AAPL) gapped down and fell 4% and Microsoft (MSFT) shed 1.4%, both in above-average volume. Credit Suisse said Apple cut production orders for its iPhone 6s by up to 10%, which sent its supplier stocks down too.
Avago Technologies (AVGO) led IBD 50 losers with a 4% drop. The Apple chip supplier fell below the 50-day moving average, which it had regained on Friday.

CyberArk Software (CYBR) sank 8% in heavy trade, extending its losing streak to four. Bank of America downgraded the security software company to neutral from buy and cut its price target to 48 from 80.

On the upside, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) gained nearly 3%. The fast-casual restaurant operator said it will reopen in a few days 43 stores in the Seattle and Portland, Ore., areas that it had voluntarily closed due to an E. coli outbreak. The stock is 18% off its Aug. 5 peak.

McDonald's (MCD), which spun off Chipotle in 2006, reversed higher. The fast-food giant said it will not spin off its real estate assets. It upped the number of restaurants that it plans to franchise to 4,000 from 3,500.

Stocks were adding to gains going into the noon hour Monday. The Nasdaq led the way with a 0.9% gain; the S&P 500 gained 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.5% in the stock market today. Volume was tracking slightly higher on the NYSE and slightly lower on the Nasdaq exchange.

After the open, two economic indicators helped stocks stay higher. The ISM Manufacturing index fell 0.1% to 50.1 in October. That was the lowest reading of the year and shows that the economy is growing at a very slow rate.
Construction spending beat estimates with a 0.6% rise in September.
Visa (V) gapped down and was trading nearly 3% lower after reporting fiscal Q4 EPS of 62 cents. Wall Street expected 63 cents. The company also announced that it is acquiring Visa Europe.
The stock is trading below a 77.02 buy point from a cup base.

Investors took a 3% bite out of Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) in high volume. The company temporarily closed 43 restaurants in Seattle and Oregon due to an E. coli scare. The Oregon Health Authority said three people near Portland and 19 near Washington got sick after eating at Chipotle since Oct. 14.

Cray (CRAY) leaped more than 7%. It rose 34% last week after reporting better-than-expected earnings. The company makes high-performance computer systems for government, academic institutions and industrial companies.Stocks were adding to gains going into the noon hour Monday. Facebook (FB) got a higher price target Friday, while Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Qorvo's (QRVO) price target was lowered and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) was downgraded.

Argus hiked its price target on Facebook to 130 from 115 and maintained its buy rating on the stock. After Wednesday's close, the social network reported Q3 earnings and revenue that beat consensus views. Also, the number of active daily Facebook users topped 1 billion for the first time.
Despite the price target hike, Facebook shares closed down 1.5% on thestock market today after gapping up 4.6% Thursday.
Qorvo, which supplies chips to the Apple iPhone, among other devices, had its price target lowered to 70 from 75 by Brean Capital, which still maintained its buy rating on the stock.
Even so, Qorvo shares shot up 23% following Thursday's better-than-expected quarterly earnings report. Apple's stock price rose 0.1%.

Another chipmaker, Nvidia (NVDA), popped 13.9% as several analysts made calls on the stock. Late Thursday, Nvidia beat fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue estimates and guided Q4 earnings higher. MKM Partners upgraded the stock to buy, while Roth Capital, Morgan Stanley and Wedbush all raised their price targets on Nvidia.
Nvidia also supplies graphics chips for Tesla's (TSLA) touchscreen dashboard. Earlier this week, Tesla reported strong quarterly results. Tesla shares closed up 0.25%.

Chipotle was downgraded to neutral from outperform at Robert W. Baird, which lowered its price target on the stock to 675 from 850. The former high flyer has been in a funk of late, with shares dropping nearly 20% since Oct. 13 and losing 0.8% Friday.

Duke Energy (DUK) fell 5.2% after it was downgraded to market perform by BMO Capital a day after the utility giant fell short of quarterly EPS views. Last week, Duke announced plans to buy fellow Charlotte, N.C.-based utility Piedmont Natural Gas (PNY) for $4.9 billion.
First Solar (FSLR) climbed 2.3% after it was initiated at outperform by Macquarie.
Retailer TJX Companies (TJX) fell 1.9% after it was initiated at outperform by RBC Capital.
TripAdvisor (TRIP) sank 6.85% on a downgrade to neutral by Guggenheim Securities and to perform by Canaccord Genuity. On Thursday, TripAdvisor fell short of quarterly EPS views.

Shares of Ralph Lauren (RL) climbed 5.2% after its price target was hiked to 150 from 142 by Telsey Advisory Group, a day after the apparel company's stock price popped nearly 15%. That gain came after Ralph Lauren topped Q3 earnings views and offered a bullish outlook.

Restaurant Brands — the product of a 2014 merger between Burger King and Tim Hortons — said earnings grew 21% to 34 cents a share, rising above projections by 6…

The stock indexes posted moderate gains Friday as the Nasdaq wrapped up its best weekly percentage gain since mid-July. The Nasdaq tacked on 0.6% Friday, while the S&P 500 added just under 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%. The small-cap S&P 600 led the field with an 0.8% gain. The IBD 50 matched the small-cap index with an…

Shares of Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) weren't looking so appetizing Monday amid E. coli-prompted store closings, and the issue could weigh on fourth-quarter earnings by about 22 cents a share, says one analyst. The burrito and taco chain shuttered 43 restaurants in Oregon and Washington state "out of an abundance of caution," after health department officials said they were investigating…

Chipotle Mexican Grill served up weak Q3 earnings and gave no evidence that pork's return was reviving sales, sending shares down 7% late Tuesday. The burrito giant earned $4.59 a share, up 11% vs. a year earlier, but 3 cents below the $4.62 that analysts had forecast. Sales rose 12% to $12.2 billion, in line with estimates. But it was…

Stocks were poised for a higher open on this first trading day of November as a round of merger activity offset weak data out of China. Nasdaq 100 futures rose 12 points vs. fair value and S&P 500 futures climbed 2 points.
Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average rallied 23 points.
Stocks rallied for a fifth straight week last week and closed out the month of October with solid gains.

Over the weekend, China reported lackluster manufacturing data. The preliminary Caixin China manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) came in at 48.3 in October, up from 47.2 in September. But readings under 50 signal contraction. China's official PMI came in at 49.8 in October, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This marked the third straight monthly drop for the world's second largest economy.
Asian stock markets were lower, with the Shanghai composite and Hong Kong's Hang Seng losing 1.7% and 1.2%, respectively. Japan's Nikkei fell 2.1%.
In stock news, several companies announced deals.
TreeHouse Foods (THS) agreed to buy ConAgra Foods' (CAG) private brands business for $2.7 billion in cash. ConAgra shares surged 13% in premarket trading, while TreeHouse shares eased a fraction.

Visa (V) announced that it would acquire Visa Europe in a deal valued at more than $23 billion if certain targets are met. Visa Europe split from its parent company in 2007 before the credit card firm's initial public offering.

Separately, Visa also reported mixed quarterly results. It posted fiscal Q4 earnings of 62 cents a share, up from 55 cents a year ago. But it missed views by a penny. Sales climbed to $3.571 billion, barely edging views for $3.57 billion.
The firm also announced a $5 billion stock buyback program. Visa shares fell about 2% in premarket trading. The stock has had a tough time making progress from a 77.02 entry in a consolidation.

Dyax (DYAX) soared 33% on news that it would be acquired by British drug giant Shire (SHPG) for an initial $5.9 billion, or $37.30 per share, in cash. Shareholder may receive an additional $4 a share, depending on approval for its hereditary angioedema treatment.

Elsewhere, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell 4% in premarket trading on news that it closed stores in the Northwest due to an outbreak of E. coli. Shares have already been under pressure recently on weak quarterly earnings.

On the economic front, reports on factory activity from Markit and the Institute for Supply Management will be out at 9:45 a.m. and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Data on construction spending is also due at 10 a.m. ET in the stock market today.

Whether the stock market is enjoying a big market uptrend or bobbing up and down like a buoy in the ocean, earnings growth still matters. The numerous positive surprises in earnings-per-share gains that large-cap companies have issued across the market in the past couple of weeks have certainly helped investors feel more bullish.Earnings research firm S&P Capital IQ sees third-quarter earnings dropping 3.8% among S&P 500 firms to $28.92 a share. That's a solid improvement from the 5% decline seen on Oct. 6. Plus, earnings would likely be up 4.5% for the S&P 500 minus the energy drag.A 4.5% overall gain might not be something to hoot and holler about. The mild increase reflects an economy that is still recovering at a modest pace. Revenue increases have been equally weak. In that light, today's IBD Big Cap 20 screen can be useful in guiding readers to the small minority of companies that are growing much faster.Do not forget that 25% EPS growth is the minimum threshold for IBD's CAN SLIM stock selection system. Consistent double-digit profit increases that fall short of that high bar are still acceptable for large, established companies.Growth deceleration, as seen in former Big Cap 20 component Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) (EPS up 52%, 47%, 27% and 11% in the past four quarters) can knock the stock's EPS Rating down and spark sell-offs.Today, Chipotle is still a great business with outstanding products, service and management. Yet for now, the hot sauce is missing from its quarterly numbers. Thus, the stock is no longer on the screen.Southwest Airlines (LUV) is coming off a thrilling ride, thrusting ahead 11.5% last week for its fourth straight up week.Some traders might say that the reason lies in the stock's "cheap" valuation, currently 14 times trailing 12-month earnings per share. But a bigger reason may be the company's outstanding job in delivering above-normal profit growth. Last week, the discount air carrier reported a 71% jump in Q3 earnings to 94 cents a share, slightly above the consensus view. That's on top of a 62% EPS increase in the year-earlier quarter.No matter what the industry, that is called "crushing it." Over the past six quarters, Southwest's EPS growth has averaged 102%.Alphabet (GOOGL) is rising fast after notching an 18% jump in Q3 profit, marking a third quarter of growth acceleration (3%, 5%, 17%, 18%).Cognizant Technology (CTSH) has rallied 51% since last October. On Monday, the stock was just above a 68.06 cup-with-handle entry point. Wall Street sees EPS up 15% to 76 cents a share in Q3. Over the past four quarters, the average gain was 15.3%. Earnings are due Nov. 4.Starbucks (SBUX) issues Q4 results late Thursday. Expect a 16% rise to 43 cents a share. Earnings have nearly quadrupled from fiscal 2008 (36 cents) to 2014 ($1.33).

The Dow Jones industrial average was in the driver's seat in early afternoon trading Wednesday, while tech stocks lagged, and the S&P 500 was mostly unchanged.The Dow rose 0.4%, helped by strength in United Technologies (UTX), Travelers (TRV), Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA) in the stock market today. The Nasdaq lost 0.4%, and the S&P 500 eased 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking higher than Tuesday's levels.In IPO news, Ferrari (RACE) debuted strongly. Shares priced last night at 52 and opened at 60. The stock was recently trading around 55.81.Meanwhile, two multi-billion dollar deals in the semiconductor industry made headlines.Lam Research (LRCX) jumped 6% on news it's acquiring KLA-Tencor (KLAC) for $10.6 billion. Shares of KLA-Tencor soared 22.5%.And Western Digital (WDC) offered to buy SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion. Shares of Western Digital eased 1%, while SanDisk gained nearly 3%.Market carnage wasn't hard to find despite a quiet showing for the major averages. Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) became the latest target of short-selling firm Citron Research. Shares slumped 30% after being halted earlier in the session.On the earnings front, Chipotle (CMG) retreated 7% after the company reported soft results late Tuesday. Big sellers were in Chipotle in the days leading up to the report.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil lost 95 cents, or 2%, to $45.34 a barrel.Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter: @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook

ETFs holding biotech and airline stocks defied the generally sluggish market action Monday, climbing 1% to 2% as major broad-based indexes narrowly clung to gains. Investors eye a cascade of corporate earnings this week, with several elite IBD 50 stocks among roughly 20% of S&P 500 companies on tap to report. The stock market opened lower today, but edged up…

Breakfast items and the new Premium Buttermilk Crispy Chicken Deluxe helped boost U.S. comps 0.9%, McDonald's (MCD) said, adding that "rebuilding customer traffic remains a top priority for the segment." But their respective sectors could use improvement. Retail, which houses restaurants, ranked No. 14 of 33 sectors in Thursday's IBD. That's better than the Transport sector's No. 25. Stocks sold off into the close after moving little in either direction through most of Wednesday's session. The Nasdaq lagged with an 0.8% loss, while the S&P 500 gave up 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.3%. Volume was higher across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.Losers led winners by more than 2-to-1 on the NYSE and nearly 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq. Drugmakers, restaurants and software stocks were down the most. Gainers included chipmakers, homebuilders and air freight transporters.Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) sank 19% to a one-year low after becoming the latest target of short-seller Citron Research, which accused the company of irregularities in booking sales. The Canadian drugmaker called the report "erroneous."Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Yahoo (YHOO) fell 6% and 5%, respectively, after reporting disappointing quarterly earnings Tuesday after the close. Both stocks had their price targets cut by analysts.But it wasn't all bad on the earnings front. General Motors (GM) gapped up and motored 6% higher after its Q3 profit and sales topped views. The stock jumped above its 50-day moving average for the first time in nearly four months.Ferrari (RACE) closed well off intraday highs but still gained 6% on its first day of trade. Shares of the Italian sports car maker priced at $52 a share, at the top of its expected range. They raced ahead as much as 17% during the session.A few IBD 50 stocks also outperformed. SolarWinds (SWI) gapped up and soared 16% to a 2.5-year high on news that private-equity firms Silver Lake Partners and Thoma Bravo are acquiring it. Manhattan Associates (MANH) rose 6% to a new high after its Q3 results beat views late Tuesday. It's extended past a 65.63 handle buy point. Hawaiian Holdings (HA) soared 5% in fast trade to a new high. Companies reporting in Thursday's busy earnings schedule include Alphabet (GOOGL), Amazon.com (AMZN), McDonald's (MCD), Microsoft (MSFT), Under Armour (UA) and United Continental (UAL).Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo.

Leading indexes turned Wednesday's modest opening gains to mixed and busy action, powered primarily by quarterly reports and company news. The Nasdaq backed out of a narrow advance and slipped 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each clung to fractional gains.
Volume swept up 30% on the Nasdaq and rose 5% on the NYSE, gauged against trade at the same time Tuesday.
The stock market today had its little drama sketched out as the Nasdaq rose to test resistance at its 200-day moving average, near the 4800 level.
In stocks,Boeing (BA) and Walt Disney (DIS) led the Dow, up more than 1% apiece. Exotic car maker Ferrari (RACE) throttled up 6% in its first day of trade.

But KLA-Tencor (KLAC) was the stock to catch on the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100, up 24% at the open after reporting Q3 results and announcing it would be bought by Lam Research (LRCX) in a cash/stock deal valued at $10.6 billion. Lam's shares shook off premarket declines and soared 7%.

Chip news wasn't all good, however. Micron Technology (MU) dived 7% after a downgrade to underperform from Bank of America. Micron fell 115 Tuesday on word that SanDisk (SNDK) was in late-stage merger talks with Western Digital (WDC), dimming hopes for a chip wedding between SanDisk and Micron.
Biogen (BIIB) gabbed a 6% gain after reporting an across-the-board Q3 win. The stock has been feeling for a bottom in a deep double dip, seven-month consolidation.
Manhattan Associates (MANH) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) bracketed the IBD 50 list.
Manhattan surged 4% on a solid third-quarter report . The jump snatched back Tuesday's loss and sent shares 6% above 65.63 cup-with-handle buy point.
Chipotle slumped 7% after reporting disappointing Q3 results late Tuesday. The heavy-volume loss drove shares below their 200-day moving average.
Water-heating products maker A.O. Smith (AOS) jumped 4% after a mixed earnings report. The light-volume gain lifted shares a bit more than 1% above a 71.91 cup-with-handle buy point.
Cirrus Logic (CRUS) notched a 3% gain. Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) and Hawaiian Holdings (HA) jumped 2% each.
Overall, losses in the IBD 50 group were relatively mild, the worst being a 1% slip by China-based NetEase (NTES).
Oil prices traded down nearly 2% to $45.45 a barrel ahead of the Energy Information Administration's weekly inventories data, due out at 10:30 a.m. ET.

Stock futures pointed sharply higher, but were off their early highs ahead of Wednesday's start of trade, following some mixed early economic news and as markets rallied in Europe.

Dow futures steered up 118.7 points, and Nasdaq 100 futures traded 25.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a 12.1-point gain. Small caps were positive and steady, with Russell 2000 futures holding a 4-point gain.

The stock market today opens with a two-day rally under its belt, with both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq ending higher in their trading ranges on Tuesday. Both indexes remain below their 50-day moving averages, although the Nasdaq is positioned for a possible test of that line this week.

Personal spending rose 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said, a welcome improvement from October's zero-gain showing and in line with economist expectations. Personal incomes rose 0.3%, a tad below October's 0.4% gain but better than views for a 0.2% advance.

Durable goods orders were flat for the month, sharply below October's (downwardly revised) 2.9% gain, but better than the 0.5% contraction projected by economist consensus. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.1% vs. estimates for no change.
At 10 a.m. ET, the University of Michigan is scheduled to report its final consumer sentiment estimate for December and the Commerce Department gives its new home sales numbers for November.
The dollar was mixed early Wednesday, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds slipped, sending the 10-year yield up 2 basis points to 2.25%.

Crude prices moved higher, with the Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate benchmarks trading in tandem: both up 1.5% and just below $36.70 per barrel. Crude prices may see some effect from weekly U.S. inventories data from the Energy Information Administration, due out at 1030 a.m. ET. Metals and agricultural commodities were mixed.

Mining companies appeared poised to rally for another day, with BHP Billiton (BBL) up 6%, and Rio Tinto (RIO), Freeport McMoran (FCX) and Vale (VALE) jumping 5% each. The bounce in oil and mining issues tripped a rally on European markets, sending London's FTSE 100 up more than 2%, and the Cac-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX up nearly that much, in midday trade.

In U.S. stocks, Nike (NKE) vaulted nearly 3%, leading the Dow as well as the IBD 50 list in premarket action. The athletic wear maker reported late Tuesday its fiscal second-quarter earnings topped consensus forecasts. Revenue rose 4.1%, just shy of expectations. Gross margins increased more than forecast, to 45.6%, primarily due to higher selling prices. The stock has been testing support at its 10-week moving average, just below a flat base buy point of 133.62.

Devon Energy (DVN) spiked 11%. Devon has been highly active on the acquisitions front this month, paying $2.5 billion for assets in the Anadarko and Powder River basins, and sold its San Juan River holdings in New Mexico to BP (BP).

Celgene (CELG) mustered a 6% gain before the open. The drug maker announced the settlement of litigation vs. India's Natco Pharma and its U.S. partner, Arrow International, a subsidiary of Allergan (AGN), pertaining to patents for the oral cancer drug Revlimid. Celgene shares have been consolidating since July.

Micron Technology (MU) tanked 7%, hurt by fiscal Q1 earnings results delivered late Tuesday. Revenue grew 12.5% to $1.2 billion, in line with estimates.Same-store sales grew 2.6% and operating margin fell 50 basis points to 28.3% due to higher labor costs.Chipotle shares fell 7% late, after closing the regular session down 1.8%. Yahoo's (YHOO) Q3 results and Q4 guidance fell short of analyst estimates.The struggling Internet company also announced that it had reached agreements over searches and search ads with Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google unit.Yahoo also said it's on track to complete its proposed tax-free spinoff of its 15% stake in Alibaba (BABA) by the end of the year.Shares of Yahoo dipped 1% in extended trading, after closing the regular session down 2%. Ferrari priced its IPO at 52 a share, the high end of its range.
