First it was a recall of nut butters on salmonella concerns. Then a fire damaged a rice factory. And if that didn't hurt Hain Celestial Group enough since last summer, weak foreign currencies provided a third kick.
On a more personal level, CEO Irwin Simon had to have knee surgery in January to repair torn ligaments from an accident.

Through it all, Hain Celestial (HAIN) has generally seen its stock climb the past few years — barring periodic gyrations, such as Feb. 9's 3% dip as the overall market fell on concerns over Greece and China.
Hain stock is up 41% from an August low, including a 5.4% jump on Feb. 4 after second-quarter earnings were reported, bringing the stock back from a January lull.

While slower than expected, net sales in Hain's December-ending second quarter of fiscal 2015 were still up 31% to an adjusted $701.7 million. Adjusted earnings rose 26% to 54 cents per share, beating views.
Whole Package
A big part of Hain's appeal is its focus on the healthy side of the packaged-goods business.

It's behind some of the biggest brands in herbal tea (Celestial Seasonings), soy milk (WestSoy), organic baby food (Earth's Best), natural soups and cereals (Health Valley), healthy snacks (Terra) and cold-pressed juices (BluePrint), to name some of the many niches the company plays in.

"Demand remains strong across all channels for natural-organic foods," said analyst Scott Van Winkle of Canaccord Genuity. "And given that Hain is a multibrand, multicategory business, it is going to participate in the growth across all channels."
CEO Simon likes to say that his company has brand offerings in 10 of the top 15 highest-penetrated organic and natural product categories. Plus, he says, it has more than 500 gluten-free products.

Van Winkle credits management for working efficiently through good and tough times. In Hain's September-ending first quarter — which included its voluntary nut-butter recall in August — Hain grew earnings and revenue more than 30% vs. the year-earlier period.

And second-quarter earnings beat views despite interrupted production from fire damage at its Tilda specialty-rice factory in the U.K. in late October, which contributed to slower than expected sales.
Hain lowered its full-year outlook to reflect the multiple headwinds, including a $70 million impact from weaker foreign currencies and $20 million from the nut butter recall and fire.
The firm expects total net sales for the year ending in June of $2.650-$2.675 billion, up 23% to 24% over the prior fiscal year. Earnings are seen rising 17%-19% to $1.85-$1.89 per share.
Analysts see revenue growing 24% to $2.671 billion and earnings going up 18% to $1.88, according to a poll by Thomson Reuters.
"The recall is behind them at this point," Van Winkle said. "But the manufacturing challenges from the fire at the Tilda facility are going to take a few quarters to work through."
Hain bought U.K.-based Basmati and specialty-rice company Tilda in January 2014. It was one of numerous acquisitions made since its founding in 1993 and the first of three in 2014.

The other two last year were Rudi's Organic Bakery and the 51.3% interest that it didn't already own in organic poultry brands FreeBird and Plainville Farms — part of its Hain Pure Protein subsidiary.
High-Profile Customers
Hain Pure Protein sells to Panera Bread (PNRA) and Chipotle (CMG), among other customers.

"Hain's ability to complete accretive and synergistic M&As (mergers and acquisitions) has been a key reason for its success in recent years," said David Palmer, an analyst with RBC Capital Markets, in a research note on Feb. 5.

As one example, Palmer noted that sales of snack-focused Sensible Portions, which Hain acquired in 2010, grew 51% for the 12-week period ending January 2. That was up from 42% growth in the prior 12-week period.
Hain competes with numerous companies. They range from small organic and natural-foods players to the big packaged-goods giants that have increasingly been adding healthier products to their mix.
General Mills (GIS), for example, acquired organic snack and convenient-meals provider Annie's Homegrown in October. Campbell Soup (CPB) bought organic baby products company Plum Organics in 2013.
"Dozens if not hundreds of companies are their competitors," Van Winkle said. "This isn't General Mills against Kellogg (K) in the cereal aisle. This is a multibrand company in a rising category."
WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), for instance, is a rival in soy milk and organic dairy milk.
Traditional supermarkets such as Safeway and Kroger (KR), mass merchants Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT), and natural-organic grocer Whole Foods (WFM) and others in its category carry Hain products.
Hain's largest single customer is United Natural Foods (UNFI), a distributor to Whole Foods and other stores. Hain's products are sold in more than 65 countries.

The U.K. is Hain's second largest market after the U.S. Second-quarter net sales in the U.K. jumped 38% vs. the year prior to $200.8 million. Tilda contributed around $50 million of the total, even with the ongoing production disruption from the fire.
U.S. net sales rose 8% to $354 million. The nut-butter recall cut into sales by $5.3 million. Rudi's added $16.1 million.
Hain saw double-digit growth in several brands, including Sensible Portions, The Greek Gods, Terra, Garden of Eatin', Imagine and WestSoy, among others.
In a Q2 conference call on Feb. 4, Simon said that business had been strong in January. He alluded to cold-weather favorites such as tea, soup and snacks.

"We love cold weather and we love snowstorms," he said.First it was a recall of nut butters on salmonella concerns. Then a fire damaged a rice factory. Restaurant stocks have been on a strong run of late, with leaders like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) trading near record highs and helping to push the Retail-Restaurants group to No. 8 out of 197 industries that IBD tracks.
The sector might be poised for even more good times in the months ahead if recent National Restaurant Association data are any indication.

The association's Restaurant Performance Index (RPI) for November, released just before the New Year's break, shows that restaurant operators are bullish about their prospects over the next couple of quarters, thanks to a strong operating environment and favorable macro trends.
The overall RPI reading in November was 102.1, down slightly from October's 102.8 but still above 100, meaning that the restaurant industry is in expansion rather than contraction mode.

Importantly, the RPI's Expectations Index component — which measures restaurant operators' six-month outlook for same-store sales, employees, capital expenditures and business conditions — stood at 102.8 in November. That's up from 102.5 in October and marks the 25th straight reading above 100 — a sign that restaurant operators are optimistic that business conditions will continue to improve in coming months.
Restaurant operators have benefited from a couple of recent trends, said analyst Stephen Anderson of institutional trading firm Miller Tabak in a note published Friday morning.
"Lower fuel prices and a constructive jobs picture contributed to a new cyclical high in operator expectations in November," Anderson wrote.

He added, "The jobs picture — which we see as the most important driver for the sector — is on more solid footing as 2015 begins," In addition, "a mild start to the winter of 2014-2015 also should help December same-restaurant sales."
These trends have helped the Retail-Restaurants group make it back into IBD's Top 10 industry groups after falling outside the Top 100 six months ago.

In addition to Chipotle and Buffalo Wild Wings, leading stocks in the group by IBD Composite Rating (which factors in earnings growth, stock gains and other metrics) include Nathan's Famous (NATH) and Texas Roadhouse (TXRH). The biggest stocks by market cap in the group are McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX).Restaurant stocks have been on a strong run of late, with leaders like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) trading near record highs and helping to push the Retail-Restaurants group to No. 8 out of 197 industries that IBD tracks.The sector might be poised for even more good times in the months ahead if recent National Restaurant Association data are any indication.The association's Restaurant Performance Index (RPI) for November, released just before the New Year's break, shows that restaurant operators are bullish about their prospects over the next couple of quarters, thanks to a strong operating environment and favorable macro trends.The overall RPI reading in November was 102.1, down slightly from October's 102.8 but still above 100, meaning that the restaurant industry is in expansion rather than contraction mode.Importantly, the RPI's Expectations Index component — which measures restaurant operators' six-month outlook for same-store sales, employees, capital expenditures and business conditions — stood at 102.8 in November. Major averages extended gains Thursday after a solid move higher Wednesday in lower volume.

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 gapped up and were trading above their 50-day moving averages, rising 1.6% each. The Dow Jones industrial average also rose 1.6%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly higher than Wednesday's levels.
Part of the strength was attributed to comments made by Chicago Fed President Charles Evans late Wednesday. He said the Fed should not be in a rush to raise interest rates.
In economic news, weekly jobless claims fell 4,000 to 294,000. Economists expected a slightly larger drop to 290,000.
In the stock market today, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) jumped 3.5% in solid volume after Morgan Stanley maintained an overweight rating, but lifted its price target to 757 from 696.
Inside the IBD 50, nearly half the names on the list rose 2% or more. Chip stocks like Cavium (CAVM), Skyworks (SWKS), Avago (AVGO) and NXP (NXPI) all advanced at least 3%.
On the downside, Biogen Idec (BIIB) reversed gains despite positive phase-two data for a multiple sclerosis drug. After rising 2% early, shares fell nearly 2%.

The December jobs report will be be out Friday at 8:30 a.m. ET. Stocks held on to small gains midday Monday, shaking off Dallas Fed manufacturing data that badly missed expectations.
The Nasdaq added 0.1%, the S&P 500 was up 0.2%, and the Dow inched up a fraction. Volume in the stock market today was tracking significantly higher from Friday on both exchanges.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) added nearly 2% in heavy trading and is approaching an all-time high. The stock recently cleared a 675.34 buy point from a shallow consolidation. Earnings and sales growth has accelerated for the last two quarters on huge same store sales growth at the burrito chain.

Identity theft protection firm LifeLock (LOCK) rose 3% in heavy volume and cleared an 18.09 buy point from a flat-base pattern. The stock is showing signs of institutional accumulation and has a highest possible 99 Composite Rating.

Gilead Sciences (GILD) climbed 3% in active trading as it continues to bounce off support at its 200-day moving average. With Q3 same-store sales up 19.8% from a year earlier, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) continues its streak with another view-topping quarter, but the trendy eatery tamped down expectations for next year. Third-quarter earnings skyrocketed 56% to $4.15 a share vs. views for $3.84, its best gain in more than two years. Revenue rose 31.1% to $1.08 billion. Wall Street had…
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) got another taste of victory Monday with view-topping quarterly figures, but conservative fiscal 2015 same-store sales guidance sent shares down after hours.
Third-quarter earnings skyrocketed 56% to $4.15 a share vs. views for $3.84, Chipotle's best gain in more than two years, as traffic continued to climb despite higher prices.
Restaurant-level operating margin widened by 200 basis points to 28.8%.

Revenue rose 31.1% to $1.08 billion, exceeding Wall Street estimates of $1.06 billion and marking the fourth straight quarter of accelerating sales growth after gains of 29%, 24%, 21% and 18%. Same-store sales jumped 19.8% from a year earlier, up from a Q2 comp-sales surge of 17.3%.
The burrito and taco chain opened 43 restaurants and continues to see a "midteens" same-store sales rise for the year with 180 to 195 new restaurants.
But it sees same-store sales rising at a low- to mid-single-digit pace for 2015 and 190 to 205 new store openings.
Shares fell nearly 5% in after-hours trading after closing up 1.8% in the regular session.

Though the comp-sales outlook may have caught some investors off-guard, William Blair analyst Sharon Zackfia says that it isn't surprising, as the company's first look at 2015 same-store-sales guidance "typically proves to be very conservative."
"They almost always guide for something in the flat to low-single-digit range for traffic," she said, noting that the 2015 figures appear to be "normal guidance" for Chipotle.

Other analysts weren't that surprised either. Wunderlich Securities' Robert Derrington told IBD that his 2015 comp-sales estimate and the Wall Street consensus view are about 7%. Sterne Agee analyst Lynne Collier has it at 5.4%.

Food costs, on the other hand, surprised analysts, accounting for 34.3% of revenue, up 70 basis points from a year ago. Costs were driven by beef, avocado and dairy prices but offset by higher menu prices.
Beef and veal prices are seen increasing by 8% to 9% for the year and pork prices are seen rising by 7.5% to 8.5%, the Agriculture Department said in late September.
The spread of porcine epidemic diarrhea virus impacted pork prices over the summer, though the industry is reportedly rebounding from the hit as the pig population recovers.
A drought in Texas and Oklahoma weighed down herds as feed costs propelled cattle prices.

"Beef will continue to be an issue, but I do think dairy is projected to come down a bit," Collier told IBD, noting that Chipotle's food costs are already higher to start with due to the restaurant chain's use of organic ingredients.

"Food costs remain a key vulnerability, given the chain's infrequent pricing decisions and exposure to a fragmented natural/ organic supply chain," said RBC Capital Markets' David Palmer in a research note.

Still, the popular fast-casual eatery's results were "scintillating," Wunderlich's Derrington told IBD. Chipotle reported "much-better-than-expected same-store sales (and) much-better-than-expected earnings growth."Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) got another taste of victory Monday with view-topping quarterly figures, but conservative fiscal 2015 same-store sales guidance sent shares down after hours.Third-quarter earnings skyrocketed 56% to $4.15 a share vs. views for $3.84, Chipotle's best gain in more than two years, as traffic continued to climb despite higher prices.Restaurant-level operating margin widened by 200 basis points to 28.8%.Revenue rose 31.1% to $1.08 billion, exceeding Wall Street estimates of $1.06 billion and marking the fourth straight quarter of accelerating sales growth after gains of 29%, 24%, 21% and 18%. Darden Restaurants (DRI) has struggled recently as millennials favor fast-casual restaurants with a healthier vibe. How will the operator of Olive Garden fare when it announces fiscal second-quarter results on Tuesday?
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Darden to report an 80% jump in earnings to 27 cents per share. But revenue is seen falling 23% to $1.55 billion.
Last month, Miller Tabak analyst Stephen Anderson said in a research note that he expected Darden to raise its full-year earnings outlook on lower costs and higher sales.

Cheaper gasoline prices may put more cash in consumers' wallets to spend on dining out, according to Anderson. He also noted the success of promotional deals at LongHorn Steakhouse and Olive Garden, like the bottomless pasta bowl.
In November, Darden announced the trimming of management layers to generate $20 million in cost savings annually. CFO Brad Richmond will retire at the end of March.

Also in November, Starboard Value won all 12 seats on Darden's board of directors. The activist investment adviser was critical of Darden's sale of Red Lobster in July. The new board has since eliminated Darden's "poison pill" plan.

Starboard's influence could also bring changes to how Olive Garden restaurants serve customers. In September, it issued detailed suggestions like cutting down on breadsticks, putting salt in the pasta and serving more alcohol. Starboard has also called for the sale of real estate assets and the spinoff of smaller Darden chains.

Meanwhile, full-service restaurants like Olive Garden and LongHorn have been losing market share to fast-casual chains like Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Panera Bread (PNRA) that offer organic or locally grown ingredients at an affordable price.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) may be setting up in a new base, but it's not without problems.
The base is a double bottom with handle and a 675.34 buy point, part of a base-on-base formation going back to March.

One of the problems with the base is the lack of accumulation, as shown in the Accumulation/Distribution Rating. The stock gapped down 7% on Oct. 21 in reaction to an earnings report. Volume was the heaviest of the base.
The 7% down day turned out to be the base's bottom, but the recovery has been mostly on below-average volume. Also, Chipotle has made a big move since bottoming in 2008.
The Restaurants-Retail industry group is ranked No. 10 out of 197 groups as of Thursday's IBD.
A newcomer in the fast-casual dining space is Fiesta Restaurant Group (FRGI), which has 329 Pollo Tropical and Taco Cabana restaurants in the U.S., the Caribbean and Central and South America.

The stock, showcased in this column in Thursday's paper, has moved out of a short consolidation and is trading near an all-time high. A study of weekly and daily volume shows significant institutional accumulation. The RS line has also confirmed the stock's new high, a bullish development.
Earnings in the most recent quarter were up 62%, and analysts expect a 56% increase in the next report.
The Pantry (PTRY) operates more than 1,500 convenience stores at gas stations under select banners, including Kangaroo Express. It's in 13 Southeastern states.

Earnings have been erratic over the years. After losing a penny a share in fiscal 2013, the company earned 68 cents a share in 2014. Analysts are forecasting a 51% increase in 2015 and an 18% increase in 2016. Small-cap stocks, by their very nature, are often overlooked. But historically they outperform other asset classes. Small-cap growth stocks can become enormous winners.Today's Screen Of The Day is Small Cap Leaders, which includes top-rated companies with a market capitalization of $300 million to $2 billion.Today's list includes four hot restaurants with tasty returns.With low gas prices pumping more cash into consumers' pockets, restaurants are cooking. The Retail-Restaurants group is ranked an outstanding 12th on IBD's list of 197 industries.Cracker Barrel (CBRL), which doesn't even make the Small Cap Leaders menu, late last month reported outstanding earnings and sales growth that topped views, helped by lower gas prices that drove more diners to its highway locations.Wunderlich restaurant analyst Bob Derrington said in a recent report that with plunging fuel prices consumers are more inclined to treat themselves to a meal at their favorite restaurant.Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) is No. 4 on the Small Cap Leaders list. Derrington raised his rating on the casual restaurant chain late last month. Citing improving sales and profit trends he raised his Q4 earnings-per-share estimate to $1.12 from $1.03 and reiterated a buy rating.The chain known for its buffalo wings and sports theme has been a steady performer, climbing 138% in the last two years.It formed a deep cup-with-handle base from late July to late November. It rose above a 164.58 buy point and just kept going. Its stock, which is also on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, rose 2.9% on Wednesday to 172.55, an all-time high.Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) is No. 5 on the list. The operator of more than 420 full-service restaurants serves steaks, ribs, fish and chicken items ranging from $9.99 to $24.99. Its stock moved sideways for most of the year, riding its 50-day and 200-day lines up and down in a narrow range.Texas Roadhouse cleared a short consolidation in late August, moved sideways, then found support at the 50-day line in late October. It jumped nearly 6% on Nov. 4 following its latest earnings report. Shares hit a record high of 33.43 on Nov. 28. It's held steady near that level in December and closed up 1.7% Wednesday at 32.78 in stock market trading.Jack in the Box (JACK), known for its TV ads featuring an executive with a clown head, features a wide variety of value-priced fast-food items. Jack in the Box is another top pick for Wunderlich's Derrington.Although it mainly competes with McDonald's (MCD) with burgers and fries, the company also plays in the popular Mexican food sector with its Qdoba Mexican Grill franchise. Qdoba competes with highly rated fast-casual giant Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).Jack in the Box stock formed a cup-with-handle base from March 18 to Aug. 7, when it crossed above a 62.07 buy point following an earnings report. Shares moved sideways for another month before beginning a steady climb. In its latest run it's generally found support at its 10-day or 21-day lines, bullish support levels. Shares rose 1.9% Wednesday at 77.68, close to last week's record high.Sonic (SONC), a fast-food chain, has reported double-digit profit increases for 11 quarters in a row. Analysts project that it will continue that streak this year. Sales have been less impressive, rising 4% and 3% in its last two quarters.Sonic cleared a consolidation in late October, leaving its old base for good on Oct. 21, a day after its latest earnings report. The stock peaked at 29.97 on Dec. 2 and Dec. 3. Sonic slid less than 1% Wednesday to 26.30.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

El Pollo Loco's (LOCO) stock is now in line with similar restaurants, and a recent refinancing could boost 2015 earnings per share by about 10%, analysts said Wednesday.
Morgan Stanley upgraded the Mexican chain, which bills itself as "faster fast casual," to equal-weight from underperform and ratcheted its price target to 25 from 23.

"While we have always been proponents of LOCO as a strong regional brand with sound expansion plans, valuation kept us cautious as the post-IPO valuation made shares the most expensive, even of its highest-growth peers," according to a Morgan Stanley note obtained by Benzinga.

"Now at 39 (times) our '15 EPS estimate, the shares are trading at only a 6% premium to peers such as (Fiesta Restaurant Group (FRGI), vs. 130% during the post-IPO peak, as increased float (not fundamental concerns) normalizes valuation."
Shares rose 2.3% to 26.25 in the stock market today.

The stock has cut a steep decline from its 37.30 closing price on Nov. 6, when El Pollo Loco reported underwhelming Q3 earnings. Shares also dropped on Nov. 20, after the company priced a follow-on offering in October.
El Pollo Loco is part of IBD's Retail-Restaurants Group, ranked highly at No. 8 out of 197 groups IBD tracks.

Fiesta Restaurant Group (FRGI), which operates the Pollo Tropical and Taco Cabana restaurants, dipped less than 1%. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) is better positioned than peers to grow because it's a leader in the movement to healthier fare, Goldman Sachs said as its resumed coverage of the hot fast-casual chain Monday with a buy rating and 12-month price target of 790. Goldman analyst Karen Holthouse said that data from Kantar Media showed the company's investments in marketing…
While the stock market clocked a slight gain in the last full month of summer, the uptrend was under pressure during the second half of September.
Managers of top-performing funds the past three months continued to add shares of medical issues during market pullbacks.
Among 197 industries groups tracked by IBD, three medical subgroups: Hospitals, Ethical Drugs and Biotech/Biomed, are ranked in the top 10, as of Thursday.
Large drug firms Allergan (AGN), Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ), Actavis (ACT) and Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) continued to grab top funds' interest, in their latest reporting periods.
Leading funds also like biotech firms, such as Gilead Sciences (GILD), Biogen Idec (BIIB), and Celgene (CELG).
Transportation stocks remained in the spotlight, includingSouthwest Airlines (LUV), Fedex (FDX) and Union Pacific (UNP).
A few notable buys by top funds worth mentioning include social media giant Facebook (FB), burrito chain Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA).

IBD found 26 best-performing funds adding Chipotle, investing an estimated $92 million in their latest reporting periods. The $25.7 billion T. Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth Fund owned a big stake in the firm.

The fast-casual Mexican chain runs 1,600 restaurants in the U.S. and Canada. It also ventured into Southeast Asian flavors with a new concept called ShopHouse Southeast Asian Kitchen. In December, Chipotle announced plans to expand into the pizza segment with Pizzeria Locale in Denver.
The Chipotle menu is simple, serving up burritos, tacos, burrito bowls and salads using fresh and organic ingredients. Its rival with a similar menu, El Pollo Loco, made its IPO debut in July.
After the stock's breakaway gap in July, shares have been trading steadily in a tight range between 643 and 698.

Earnings have been growing steadily in the double digits in at least six quarters. Its third-quarter earnings results are due after the market closes Oct. 20. Analysts currently see earnings rising 43% to $3.81 a share.
Sell Side

Just months after Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) and El Pollo Loco (LOCO) made bullish trading debuts, investors might be starting to feel some heartburn now.

On the heels of Chipotle Mexican Grill's (CMG) success, other fast-casual chains have been looking to make their mark on the market. Zoe's, which has more than 125 locations across 15 states, offers Mediterranean fare such as turkey pitas and hummus — on trend with those looking for more healthful fast fare.
But some may have been spooked after Halloween, as shares of Zoe's hit a high of 38.42 on Oct. 31 from its April offering at 15, then slid nearly 14%. Shares were down 1.8% in the stock market today.

Nevertheless, Zoe's has an IBD Composite Rating of 82, which means it has outperformed 82% of all other publicly traded stocks. The company ranks 28th in the Retail-Restaurants Group. Chipotle holds the No. 1 spot.
El Pollo Loco, the chicken chain, had been flying high since its IPO at 15 in July, touching 41.70 on Aug. 1, then 40.89 in mid-September.
Following its early-November earnings report, shares have been on a decline, falling even further after the announced pricing of its follow-on public offering of 6 million shares at a price of 27.
Shares dipped 0.7% Wednesday. The company has a Composite Rating of 78 and ranks 30th in the Retail-Restaurants Group.

Habit Restaurants (HABT), the newest of the three, has gotten investors fired up since its IPO last week at 18, jumping almost 120% on its first day of trading. The grill chain, which features a fresh-ingredient angle on its charburgers and albacore tuna sandwiches, hit 40.25 on Nov. 21.
But shares fell more than 13% Tuesday, the same day it announced the closing of its IPO. Shares were up 6% Wednesday. Ranked 38th in its industry group, Habit has a Composite Rating of 69.

Plunging oil prices have created huge opportunities for top-rated companies, such as Spirit Airlines (SAVE), whose growth is tied to fuel prices.
Today's IBD 50 computer-generated roster of top-rated stocks includes five highly rated stocks that will likely benefit more than others from plunging oil and gas prices.

Discount carrier Spirit's Airlines' ultralow air fares and new routes are driving growth. On Dec. 1, Bank of America Merrill Lynch analyst Glenn Engel joined a growing chorus of analysts forecasting big gains for airlines as fuel costs drop and air travel grows, Bloomberg said.
Engel projected that North American airline earnings will rise 73% to $19 billion in 2015 as a result of falling fuel prices and higher consumer discretionary spending.

Since Thanksgiving Day, when OPEC left oil production steady, triggering a fresh dive in crude futures, Spirit Airlines stock is up 7.7%. Spirit shares rose 1.2% on the stock market Friday, hitting a new high.

Apple (AAPL) on Sept. 19 rolled out its new flagship iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus. The huge sales surge for its latest smartphones has put Apple on track for record growth, according to market tracker Kantar Worldpanel.

"Apple has experienced a huge jump in sales share across almost all major markets thanks to the launch of the iPhone 6," Kantar analyst Dominic Sunnebo said in a Dec. 3 report, adding, " In major European economies, the U.S. and Australia, Apple's share of sales has risen."
Apple shares have actually fallen 3.3% since Thanksgiving, after running up to a closing high on Nov. 26.
Note: Apple iPhone chip suppliers Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) also are on the IBD 50 and should benefit from extra iPhone demand.
Advance Auto Parts (AAP) is a leader in the auto retailer group and will likely benefit from increased auto travel as gas prices at the pump continue to hit multiyear lows.
Gas is below $3 a gallon nationwide, and fell below $2 in San Antonio, a CNN report said on Friday. More driving means more wear and tear on autos and more repairs.

Auto-parts retailers also benefit as the average age of vehicles on the road climbs, boosting demand for replacement parts. Market research group IHS Automotive expects the average age of cars on the road will rise from the current record high of 11.4 years to 11.7 years in 2019.
Advance Auto Parts stock is up 5.8% since Thanksgiving.
Note: Rival parts retailer, AutoZone (AZO) reports earnings on Tuesday.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) is a leader in the hot fast casual restaurant sector. Fast casual combines the speed of fast food with higher-quality food, including fewer frozen and processed foods. It's also capitalizing on the growing popularity of Mexican food.

Chipotle is one of three restaurants with a 99 Composite Rating in the 58-company Retail-Restaurant group. The group itself is ranked a lofty 10 on IBD's list of 197 industries. Chipotle is the only fast casual to carry that top rating.
Chipotle shares are fractionally higher since Thanksgiving.
MasterCard (MA), like Apple, is seeing gains as increasingly confident consumers loosen their purse strings.

Additionally MasterCard, along with Visa (V) and other credit card companies, have greater access to China — the world's largest consumer market — after the Chinese government in early November said it would loosen credit regulations to promote consumer spending.

MasterCard stock is up 2.9% since Thanksgiving, hitting a fresh high on Friday. Shares have risen for 13 straight sessions — and that followed a consolidation following a 13.6% run-up over five days following its latest earnings report.

Will lower poultry prices lift high-flyer Buffalo Wild Wings in the already-hot restaurants industry group? Chances are that they can.

That's the opinion of Wunderlich Securities analyst Robert Derrington, who has raised his earnings outlook and price target for the highly-rated sports bar and eatery, based on an improved outlook on poultry prices.

"Key poultry indices have declined to their lowest level since March 2014 and could continue to trend lower as favorable grain prices provide a supportive backdrop for producers," Derrington noted in a report citing his commodity sources.

The improving trend prompted him to raise his Q4 EPS estimate for Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) to $1.12 from $1.03 and his full-year 2014 EPS to $5.00 from $4.92. He also increased his price target to 185 and reiterated his buy rating on the stock.

His revised outlook comes following word from the U.S. Department of Agriculture this week that it has raised its 2015 chicken production forecast by its largest amount in five years and its second largest since 2004. Derrington says that his commodity sources suggest the increase could actually be up as much as 4%, "adding the potential for even more favorable poultry prices in 2015."

He notes that chicken wing prices have declined 15 cents per pound in the last two weeks. His sources also suggest that even lower prices are likely and that recent peak wing prices this fall could prove to be the peak for the next several years. "If so, that could mitigate BWLD's chief source of earnings and share price volatility," Derrington noted. "With an improving poultry (wings) outlook combined with 3% higher menu pricing (at Buffalo Wild Wings), we project 2014 and 2015 margins to improve vs. our prior estimates."
Derrington increased his estimate for the company's Q4 restaurant margin to 17.9% from 17.3%.

Buffalo Wild Wings is part of IBD's Retail-Restaurants industry group, which ranks No. 8 out of 197 industry groups that IBD tracks. The stock gets a high IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of a possible 99, factoring in statistics such as earnings growth and long-term stock price gains.

The group also includes IBD 50 stock Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), which has the group's top Composite Rating of 99, as do Nathan's Famous (NATH) and Texas Roadhouse (TXRH).Will lower poultry prices lift high-flyer Buffalo Wild Wings in the already-hot restaurants industry group? It's not like the U.S. has a shortage of burger joints. Walk a few blocks in any direction, and you'll probably stumble across one.
That doesn't necessarily mean there are too many. If there were, Habit Restaurants (HABT) might not have made such a big splash on Wall Street last week with its initial public offering.

Habit operates fast casual restaurants under the Habit Burger Grill name, mostly in California. It specializes in freshly prepared, made-to-order char-grilled burgers, sandwiches, salads, shakes and malts.

The IPO priced at 18, above the expected range of 14 to 16. The stock raced out of the gate in its first day of trading Thursday, opening on the Nasdaq at 30 and closing up 32% at 39.54 — though it has given back some gains amid profit-taking and currently trades near 30.
Habit sold 5.75 million shares and raised $92.4 million in the IPO, which included full exercise of an underwriter overallotment option of 750,000 shares, it said Tuesday.
The Habit IPO amounted to another impressive stock market debut involving fast casual chains after El Pollo Loco Holdings (LOCO) and Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) earlier this year.
What Do Investors Crave?

One difference is that while Habit is known for its burgers, the others specialize in different fare — Mediterranean food for Zoe's and Mexican for El Pollo Loco. They join other fast casual chains such as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) (tacos and burritos) and Panera Bread (PNRA) (sandwiches, salads and soup) that specialize in something other than burgers.

Habit's focus on burgers doesn't just put it up against other fast-casual chains. It also means the company competes with a host of other burger chains, from fast food giants such as McDonald's (MCD) and Burger King Worldwide (BKW) to regional chains like In-N-Out Burger, Whataburger and Five Guys.

"There are a lot of different burger chains out there — you can find a burger every place you turn," said analyst Robert Derrington, who follows the restaurant industry for Wunderlich Securities. "Do we have too many restaurants? Absolutely. Do we have the right types of restaurants? I would say no."
Habit may be the right type of restaurant, he says, for a few reasons.

"They seem to be a very viable and differentiated player," Derrington told IBD. "They have reasonable price points. They try to do more than just burgers, fries and shakes by offering sandwiches and salads. So far the returns appear to be pretty solid. They could have a pretty good run here."

Habit executives could not comment for this article due to the quiet period following the IPO. The company did respond to email questions from IBD, answering them with statements from its Securities and Exchange Commission filings.

The company says the $34.5 billion fast casual restaurant segment "has created significant recent disruption in the restaurant industry and is rapidly gaining market share from adjacent restaurant segments, resulting in significant growth opportunities for restaurant concepts such as the Habit."
A Burger For The Everyman

Habit looks to differentiate itself from the rest of the field by "combining the quality, convenience and hospitality commonly associated with our casual dining and fast casual competitors at a price point that is below the low end of the average range of the fast casual segment."
Habit's average customer spent $7.56 for the 52 weeks ended Sept. 30. In contrast, Chipotle has an average check of $13 to $15, according to news and industry reports.
Habit would not say how rising food costs might affect its prices.
Instead, it noted that as a percentage of revenue, food and paper costs rose from 32.4% in the 26 weeks ended June 25, 2013, to 33% in the corresponding period a year earlier.
"This increase was primarily driven by food cost inflation, with increases in protein and dairy costs, and was partially offset by lower produce costs," Habit said.

The company logged revenue of $120 million in 2013, up from $84 million the prior year and $28 million as recently as 2009. According to its S-1 filing, it recorded net income of $5.8 million in 2013, a gain of 88% from a year earlier.
Much of the company's growth is due to its rapid expansion. At the end of 2009, it had 26 restaurants in three California markets. As of Aug. 25, it had 98 restaurants in 10 markets in four states.
Habit opened 22 restaurants in 2013 and expects this year's openings will total between 23 and 25. In 2015, it expects to open 26 to 28 new restaurants.
"We plan to balance our growth between existing and new markets, with the majority of new restaurants expected to open in existing markets in 2014 and 2015," the company said.

In August, Habit opened its first location on the East Coast with a restaurant in New Jersey. The company said it is in the "early stages of our growth story, and estimate(s), based on our internal analysis, a total restaurant potential in the U.S. in excess of 2,000 locations."
That's a pretty big leap from the current lineup. But analyst Derrington says Habit is off to a good start under the leadership of CEO Russell Bendel.

"They have a pretty good track record of building traffic," Derrington said. "I can see how this management team could continue to grow and evolve the business."It's not like the U.S. has a shortage of burger joints. Shares of Cracker Barrel Old Country Store moved higher in early trading on the stock market today after the restaurant operator topped quarterly sales and earnings views, helped by lower gasoline prices that drove more business to its highway locations.

Reporting before the open Tuesday, the Lebanon, Tenn.-based Cracker Barrel (CBRL) logged EPS of $1.42 for its fiscal first quarter, which ended in October. That was up from $1.22 the previous year and well ahead of consensus analyst estimates of $1.29.

Sales climbed 5% to $683.4 million, also topping views. Comparable-store restaurant sales rose 3.3%, helped by a 2.5% increase in the average check and a roughly 2% rise in the average menu price. Comparable-store retail sales climbed 6.1% from a year earlier.

"As the gasoline price decline accelerated in late summer and through much of the fall, we had expected CBRL to be one of the primary beneficiaries of this trend, as 85% of all locations are at interstate highway exits," Miller Tabak analyst Stephen Anderson noted in a report.

He was also "encouraged" to see Cracker Barrel management raise its full-year EPS guidance to a range of $5.95-$6.10 from prior guidance of $5.80-$5.95. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect full-year earnings to rise 7% to $6.02 a share.

As reported last week in IBD, Cracker Barrel expects to serve about 1.4 million meals over the week of Thanksgiving and go through about 24,000 cases of turkey breast. Its restaurants will remain open on Thanksgiving Day.

Shares of Cracker Barrel rose 4% to a record high of 126.79 in early trading Tuesday. The company has a strong IBD Composite Rating of 94 out of a possible 99, factoring in things like earnings and stock-price growth. It is part of IBD's Retail-Restaurants group, which ranks No. 10 out of 197 industries tracked.

Leading stocks in the group include Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Nathan's Famous (NATH), Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) and Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD).Shares of Cracker Barrel Old Country Store moved higher in early trading on the stock market today after the restaurant operator topped quarterly sales and earnings views, helped by lower gasoline prices that drove more business to its highway locations.Reporting before the open Tuesday, the Lebanon, Tenn.-based Cracker Barrel (CBRL) logged EPS of $1.42 for its fiscal first quarter, which ended in October. The next several Investor's Corner columns will suggest ways to boost your stock portfolio return, immediately and in the long run.
Suggestion No. 1: Invest only in truly innovative companies.

Innovative, fast-growing and dynamic companies are often the most compelling growth stocks. Quite naturally, these companies also tend to show the most rapid growth in earnings and sales in the market.
Although there is a phenomenal amount of innovation occurring right now in the high-tech field, don't fall into the trap of thinking innovation is limited only to technology companies.
Among the market's most innovative headliners, automaker Tesla Motors (TSLA) easily holds its own beside names like Facebook (FB) and GoPro (GPRO).
Not so many years ago, groundbreaking tech name Google (GOOGL) went public shortly ahead of another innovative concept, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).
Going back even further, two pioneers in their fields, Qualcomm (QCOM) and Starbucks (SBUX), went public within six months of each other at the start of the 1990s.

To understand the actual technology from companies like Qualcomm or Aruba Networks (ARUN), investors often must read extensively as well as learn from the insights provided by analysts and others familiar with the technology. That's where IBD's New America and Internet & Technology sections come in.
For more consumer-oriented offerings, first-hand experience is often the best way for an investor to determine just how innovative their target company is.

No matter how innovative the firm, fundamentals always count. Keep in mind that innovative companies often make for lousy stocks. An innovative product is only one ingredient of a successful stock. Management must come up with an enlightened business plan, and then execute at high levels to manage finances, workforce, production, distribution, sales and marketing, and the company's network of suppliers.

Debt, return on equity, profit margins and cash flow are all key metrics to track, along with sales and earnings. Support by mutual funds is also crucial. Do a fast check of all these gauges by using Stock Checkup on Investors.com and the research tables in the paper (starting on this page).

General Electric (GE), with its nuclear facilities engineering, jet engines, sea water filtration and wind energy technologies, is a jewel in the U.S. crown as a leading innovator. But its sales have not increased in almost five years. The stock trades 36% below a 2007 peak of 42.15 and deep in the shadows of its record high in 2000.

Even the best growth names aren't always a thrill a minute. Apple (AAPL) introduced its highly innovative and successful iPod in October 2001, nearly three years before the stock broke out in August 2004 and took off for good.The next several Investor's Corner columns will suggest ways to boost your stock portfolio return, immediately and in the long run.Suggestion No. 1: Invest only in truly innovative companies.Innovative, fast-growing and dynamic companies are often the most compelling growth stocks. Quite naturally, these companies also tend to show the most rapid growth in earnings and sales in the market.Although there is a phenomenal amount of innovation occurring right now in the high-tech field, don't fall into the trap of thinking innovation is limited only to technology companies.Among the market's most innovative headliners, automaker Tesla Motors (TSLA) easily holds its own beside names like Facebook (FB) and GoPro (GPRO).Not so many years ago, groundbreaking tech name Google (GOOGL) went public shortly ahead of another innovative concept, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).Going back even further, two pioneers in their fields, Qualcomm (QCOM) and Starbucks (SBUX), went public within six months of each other at the start of the 1990s.To understand the actual technology from companies like Qualcomm or Aruba Networks (ARUN), investors often must read extensively as well as learn from the insights provided by analysts and others familiar with the technology. That's where IBD's New America and Internet & Technology sections come in.For more consumer-oriented offerings, first-hand experience is often the best way for an investor to determine just how innovative their target company is.No matter how innovative the firm, fundamentals always count. Keep in mind that innovative companies often make for lousy stocks. An innovative product is only one ingredient of a successful stock. Management must come up with an enlightened business plan, and then execute at high levels to manage finances, workforce, production, distribution, sales and marketing, and the company's network of suppliers.Debt, return on equity, profit margins and cash flow are all key metrics to track, along with sales and earnings. Support by mutual funds is also crucial. Do a fast check of all these gauges by using Stock Checkup on Investors.com and the research tables in the paper (starting on this page).General Electric (GE), with its nuclear facilities engineering, jet engines, sea water filtration and wind energy technologies, is a jewel in the U.S. crown as a leading innovator. But its sales have not increased in almost five years. The stock trades 36% below a 2007 peak of 42.15 and deep in the shadows of its record high in 2000.Even the best growth names aren't always a thrill a minute. Apple (AAPL) introduced its highly innovative and successful iPod in October 2001, nearly three years before the stock broke out in August 2004 and took off for good.

Investors will scrutinize El Pollo Loco's  (LOCO) third-quarter earnings, due late Thursday, for signs it's benefiting from a consumer switch to fast casual restaurants that's made the category the hottest in the restaurant sector. This will be the company's first Q3 report since it launched its initial public offering July 25 for the restaurant known for its fire-grilled chicken…
Stocks from the consumer sector are making their presence felt in today's Spotlight.
Some of these companies show outstanding current earnings growth, but digging a little deeper reveals some flaws as well.

Zeltiq Aesthetics (ZLTQ) rose briefly after going public in 2011 before suffering a massive correction over the next 18 months. The stock bottomed at 3.20 in April of 2013 and has since bounced back in a big way.
The company uses a patented cooling technology to target and reduce fat bulges. Long a money loser, Zeltiq reported its first-ever quarterly profits in the second and third quarters this year.

Chart-wise, Zeltiq is near an all-time high and just below a 27.14 buy point in a cup base. On Friday and Tuesday, the stock briefly climbed above the pivot but reversed lower by the close. Investors should look for convincing turnover if the stock is able to retake its buy point again. An IBD New America article profiled the company on Oct. 27.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) has been on a roll fundamentally, reporting accelerating sales and earnings growth in recent quarters. It may be working on a new base, but it's still below its 10-week moving average line. The stock has an Accumulation/Distribution rating of D, reflecting net institutional selling. Look for that rating to climb for a sign that big investors have returned to the stock.
Restaurants are well represented in the Spotlight. Jack in the Box (JACK) and Fiesta Restaurant Group (FRGI) made the list.

Republic Airways Holdings (RJET) is part of the red-hot airlines industry group. The company has reported three straight quarters of accelerating profit growth; however, sales growth has lagged, remaining in the single digits.

The stock recently hit a 52-week high despite shaping a flawed chart pattern. With the ruble crumbling to rubble, investors in Russia ETFs are fleeing the dust.
The country's stocks nose-dived Tuesday after a massive interest-rate hike failed to prop up the currency, leading to worries about capital controls, as reported by IBD.
The losses exacerbate Russia's market performance woes: its stock market and currency have fallen more than 55% and 47%, respectively, in 2014.

"A substantial part of the decline is explained by the 32.4% price decline of oil, since Russia is a major producer of oil, and part of the impact is due to U.S. and Western sanctions imposed on Russia over the Ukrainian situation," senior index analyst Howard Silverblatt of S&P Dow Jones Indices wrote in an analysis Dec. 4.
Market Vectors Russia (RSX) — the largest ETF tracking that country's equities, with $1.24 billion in assets — has nose-dived 30% in the past month and 50% so far in 2014.
Its junior counterpart, Russia Small-Cap (RSXJ), has been pummeled even more: 31% and 57% over those same periods. Both ETFs hit 52-week lows on Tuesday before bouncing back somewhat.
In a shock move Dec. 15, Russia's central bank hiked the benchmark interest rate to 17% from 10.5%. It was a desperate attempt to prop up the currency.
"Raising rates is an attempt to attract foreign investors to buy Russian bonds at 17%," thereby shoring up the ruble, said Steve Blumenthal, CEO of CMG Capital Management.
Top-Heavy In Energy

The fortunes of Russia ETFs are closely tied to oil and gas; energy stocks make up 40% of RSX's portfolio. The highly concentrated RSX's top 10 holdings include Novatek, Lukoil (LUKOY) and Gazprom (OGZPY).
Given recent trends, many strategists advise investors to steer clear of volatile Russia ETFs for a while.
"A 200-day moving average stop loss would have protected investors and preserved capital" during the recent rout, said Blumenthal. RSX hasn't been above the moving average since July 16.
Blumenthal added: "Consider re-entering when its price moves above its 50-day moving average."
Emerging Divergence
The performance of individual countries in emerging markets is increasingly divergent and sensitive to falling oil prices, economists at IHS noted in a November report.
"Net oil importers will benefit, while net oil exporters will be hurt," the report's authors wrote.
"Iran, Russia and Venezuela are particularly at risk," they added. "All three countries rely on oil to balance their budgets."
Meanwhile, lower oil prices are expected to help net importers such as India, Indonesia and China, as well as key Central European countries such as Poland and Turkey.

And the U.S. could see a bump in GDP growth if low oil prices boost spending, the IHS economists said.With the ruble crumbling to rubble, investors in Russia ETFs are fleeing the dust.The country's stocks nose-dived Tuesday after a massive interest-rate hike failed to prop up the currency, leading to worries about capital controls, as reported by IBD.The losses exacerbate Russia's market performance woes: its stock market and currency have fallen more than 55% and 47%, respectively, in 2014."A substantial part of the decline is explained by the 32.4% price decline of oil, since Russia is a major producer of oil, and part of the impact is due to U.S. and Western sanctions imposed on Russia over the Ukrainian situation," senior index analyst Howard Silverblatt of S&P Dow Jones Indices wrote in an analysis Dec. 4.Market Vectors Russia (RSX) — the largest ETF tracking that country's equities, with $1.24 billion in assets — has nose-dived 30% in the past month and 50% so far in 2014.Its junior counterpart, Russia Small-Cap (RSXJ), has been pummeled even more: 31% and 57% over those same periods. Fantasy football draft parties and World Cup fans may have kept traffic flowing through Buffalo Wild Wings over the summer, but the sports bar chain will soon raise menu prices, citing higher chicken-wing costs and minimum-wage hikes.

"Current costs for traditional chicken wings of $1.98 per pound are 30% higher than our third quarter average cost," said CEO Sally Smith in a release. "Given this trend and known raises in certain minimum wage rates, we are increasing menu prices an average of 3.0% at the end of November." Smith added, "We believe net earnings growth will exceed 28% for 2014."
In its Q2 earnings release, Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) predicted that earnings growth would top 25% and could hit 30%.
Analysts currently see full-year earnings growth of 32% to $4.99 a share for 2014.

Stock brokerage and investment bank Feltl had upgraded Buffalo Wild Wings on Friday to buy from hold on its strong operational performance but cut its price target to $153 from $155. The firm had said that Buffalo Wild was overinflating its chicken-wing price concerns. Wing prices are a major factor for the sports-focused chain.
Earnings rose 20% to $1.14 a share in Q3, topping views by 7 cents, while revenue rose 18% to $373.5 million, narrowly passing expectations for $373.3 million.
Buffalo's stock rose nearly 7% to 142.60 in late trading after closing down 1% at 133.82.
Q3 same-store sales rose 6% at company-owned restaurants and 5.7% at franchised locations.
Last week, the company announced its sponsorship of the Citrus Bowl in Orlando. The Buffalo Wild Wings Citrus Bowl, formerly the Capital One Bowl, will air on ABC on New Year's Day.

Buffalo Wild Wings has an IBD EPS Rating of 98, meaning that its earnings have outpaced 98% of all publicly traded companies. The restaurant chain has reported strong double-digit earnings advances over the past five quarters, though shares have dipped modestly in 2014.

As other popular chains have invested in more homegrown-sounding niche ventures, including Chipotle Mexican Grill's (CMG) ShopHouse line of southeast Asian restaurants and Yum Brands' (YUM) decidedly un-Taco-Bell-like U.S. Taco Co., Buffalo Wild Wings has invested in Dallas-based Rusty Taco and "artisanal pizza concept" PizzaRev.

Smith said that the company continues toward its goal of 1,700 restaurants in the U.S. and Canada, plans to open 50 company-owned restaurants and expects 40 franchised locations in 2015. There are also plans for more international franchisees and further Rusty Taco and PizzaRev expansion.

The stock market held on to big gains in early-afternoon trading as the market digested a number of high-profile earnings reports.
The Nasdaq was up 1.7%, the S&P 500 added 1.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.9%. Volume was running 13% higher on the Nasdaq and 17% higher on the NYSE in the stock market today.

Blue chips lagged, weighed down by Dow components Coca-Cola (KO)and IBM (IBM). Coke shares fell 6% in heavy volume after reporting that EPS fell 14% for the quarter. IBM dropped 4% more after plunging 7% on disappointing quarterly results Monday.
AmTrust Financial Services (AFSI) rose 4% breaking out past a 46.12 buy point in heavy volume. The stock has a highest-possible 99 Composite Rating.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell 7% in heavy volume after reporting results Monday after the close. Earnings and sales growth both easily topped expectations, but shares fell today on concerns of slower same-store sales growth guidance and rising food costs.

Nearly all industry groups were higher Tuesday, with a number of transportation groups leading the charge. Youth has its advantages. Young companies often come out of the gate strong, and strong growth keeps them looking young.

Today's Young Guns Screen of the Day features hot picks that have gone public in the last 15 years. In particular, the stocks listed below have shown accelerating earnings per share and/or sales growth in their latest results.

Chipotle Mexican Grill's (CMG) earnings surged 56% to $4.15 a share, easily topping views for $3.84 when it reported third-quarter results last week. Sales of the popular burrito and taco eatery chain grew 31.1% to $1.08 billion vs. views for $1.06 billion, marking the fourth straight quarter of accelerating sales growth and second straight quarter of earnings growth.

The $20 billion company earns an IBD EPS Rating of 98, which means that it has outperformed 98% of all other publicly traded companies in earnings growth. The restaurant chain reported a 24% earnings advance in its prior quarter.

Maker of gene-sequencing systems Illumina (ILMN), which also boasts a 98 EPS Rating, last week raised full-year earnings guidance to $2.63-$2.65 from $2.26-$2.28 as it handily topped earnings and sales views.

Earnings, excluding one-time items, skyrocketed 71% to 77 cents a share, beating by 21 cents. Revenue grew 35% to $481 million, the company's best year-over-year advance in more than three years, also topping.
Shares of the company have risen more than 72% from 110.59 on Jan. 1.
Singapore-based Avago Technologies (AVGO), an Apple (AAPL) iPhone chip supplier, last reported earnings in late August, establishing a fifth straight quarter of rising earnings and revenue growth.
Equipped with a 97 EPS Rating, the company's Q3 per-share earnings soared 70% to $1.26, topping views by 21 cents, while net revenue doubled to $1.37 billion, surpassing forecasts for $1.34 billion.

Fellow Apple supplier NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) also topped in Q3 with a 59% per-share earnings rise to $1.35 and a revenue rise of 21% to $1.51 billion. The Netherlands-based chipmaker, which develops near-field communication (NFC) technology that reportedly is used in the iPhone 6, has an EPS Rating of 98.

Shares of Synchronoss Technologies (SNCR), which has a 97 EPS Rating, got a mighty boost to an all-time high of 51.95 as the cloud service's earnings, excluding items, jumped 35% to 46 cents, topping by 3 cents. Revenue perked up 39% to $125.5 million vs. views for $118.9 million.
The company's shares have grown more than 67% from 31.07 at the start of the year. Synchronoss' cloud-service revenue skyrocketed into the clouds with 115% growth from the previous year.

Fellow Young Gun Facebook (FB) reported Tuesday with 59% revenue growth to $3.2 billion, topping slightly but decelerating from previous quarters. The social network experienced a 72% year-over-year earnings rise, minus items, to 43 cents, beating views by 3 cents. Despite the healthy gains, the hefty double-digit growth nevertheless marked a decline from the triple-digit earnings advances of the last two quarters.
RELATED:
Chipotle Back In Rally Mode After Q3 Earnings Scare
Illumina Pounds Q3 Earnings Estimates, Lifts Guidance
NXP Semiconductors Guidance Beats But Stock Falls

The Oak Brook, Ill.-based company earned $1.09 a share, a 28.3% drop from Q3 2013 and missing by 28 cents the estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue fell 4.6% to…

Three hot companies that lead their respective industry groups report quarterly earnings after the close: Apple (AAPL), Chipotle (CMG), and Illumina (ILMN). Here's a look at what analysts expect for the quarter as well as how the results could affect their growth stability. IBD TV's Alissa Williams reports.

Wall Street anticipates fired-up third-quarter results when Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) reports on Monday after the close, but how much earnings growth will investors see from the exceedingly popular eatery chain?
Shares of the casual dining chain, known for their burritos and tacos made with fresh ingredients, fell 1.1% to 638.95 in the stock market on Friday.
Earnings are expected to jump 44.4% to $3.84 a share, and revenue is seen rising 28.3% to $1.06 billion.

The $20-billion company has enjoyed a streak of successes, with shares rising more than 20% from 532.78 at the start of the calendar year. The company has an IBD EPS Rating of 93, which means its per-share earnings growth has outpaced 93% of all other publicly traded companies, and ranks first in the IBD Retail-Restaurants industry group.
Chipotle's same-restaurant sales should perk up 16.6%, according to analysts, with Wunderlich Securities seeing sunny-side-up trends through next summer for the country's eateries.

Though Chipotle and sports-centric Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) have been performing well, other restaurant stocks have struggled recently. Taco Bell and Pizza Hut parent Yum Brands (YUM) missed Q3 views following the summer's meat scandal in China, and Panera Bread (PNRA) is seen by some analysts as disappointing expectations due to "underwhelming" traffic.

Major averages further extended their gains with a little more than an hour left in Tuesday's regular session.

The Nasdaq rallied 2.2%, while the S&P 500 advanced 1.8% and the Dow industrials added 1.2%. Volume was tracking sharply higher across the board in the stock market today, compared with the same time Monday.

Stocks got off to an early start, helped by a flurry of earnings reports. In economic news, existing-home sales improved in September to an annualized rate of 5.17 million, above forecasts for 5.1 million and August's 5.05 million.

Medical research gear, solar and transportation stocks were big gainers among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Mortgage services, wood products and restaurants lagged, as Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) weighed the eatery group down with a 6% drop amid concerns over its 2015 same-store sales growth outlook.

Illumina (ILMN) led the Medical-Research Equipment/Services group to a 4% gain as it gapped up and surged 9%, retaking its 50-day moving average in nearly quadruple its usual trade. The gene-sequencing company reported Q3 earnings and revenue that topped views.

Among other IBD 50 stocks, Celgene (CELG) gapped up and rose 3% in heavy volume. The stock is 5% above a 90.60 flat-base buy point that it cleared Aug. 18 before pulling back as much as 8% below the entry last week. At a Vienna conference, the biotech presented full data from the phase-two trial of its GED-0301 drug for Crohn's disease.

Airline stocks were flying high amid reports of an industrywide domestic fare hike. American Airlines Group (AAL) soared 7%, Spirit Airlines (SAVE) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) rose 5% each and United Continental Holdings (UAL) 4%, all in fast turnover.

Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.Major averages further extended their gains with a little more than an hour left in Tuesday's regular session.The Nasdaq rallied 2.2%, while the S&P 500 advanced 1.8% and the Dow industrials added 1.2%. Volume was tracking sharply higher across the board in the stock market today, compared with the same time Monday.Stocks got off to an early start, helped by a flurry of earnings reports. In economic news, existing-home sales improved in September to an annualized rate of 5.17 million, above forecasts for 5.1 million and August's 5.05 million.Medical research gear, solar and transportation stocks were big gainers among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. The gene-sequencing company reported Q3 earnings and revenue that topped views.Among other IBD 50 stocks, Celgene (CELG) gapped up and rose 3% in heavy volume. Stock futures on Tuesday advanced toward the open for a second straight day, but showed a bit more strength than in Monday's premarket session.

Dow futures were ahead 91.1 points, well above Monday's premarket levels, and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 23.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a healthy 10.2-point gain. Small caps also looked in good shape, with Russell 2000 futures up 4.8 points.

The stock market today rolls into December with automakers releasing November sales numbers throughout the session. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) reported a 3% gain in sales to its best level for November in 15 years. Jeep sales drove the results, rising 20%, vs. a 12% decline for Chrysler products, an 8% slip for Dodge and a 3% fall for Fiat autos.
Auto researcher Edmunds forecasts a total of 1.33 million light vehicles sold during the month, up 2.5% from a year ago. If accurate, it would make this the best November for automakers since 2001.
At 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management releases its November ISM Index and the Commerce Department reports October construction spending.

Retailers with a strong online presence may get a bump from data released by Adobe Systems (ADBE) showing shoppers spent a total of $2.98 billion during "Cyber Monday" — the Monday following the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season, which is designated as a day of technology and online shopping specials. The amount was a record and up 14% from last year's Cyber Monday sales, Adobe said. Adobe also estimated that Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday receipts would top $11 billion, up 15% year-over-year and also a record.
About a third of the Dow's issues were positive in premarket action, the rest were flat. The best gain came from Home Depot (HD), which added 1%.
Adobe Systems rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Baidu (BIDU) posted the Nasdaq 100's largest decline, down nearly 2%.

Automated network control specialist Infoblox (BLOX) rocketed 17% higher before the open. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter earnings, revenue and Q2 guidance above expectations, and management announced a $100 million share buyback initiative.

Mattress Firm Holding (MFRM) bounced 5% higher after announcing late Monday it would buy HMK Mattress Holding, owner of the Sleepy's retail chain, in a $780 million deal. The company said it expects about $40 million a year in cost savings. Mattress Firm also announced its fiscal Q3 sales rose 51%, and said it expected a 10% EPS gain — in line with consensus views.

China-based Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported an investor group was prepared to offer $9 billion to take the Internet security and content provider off the U.S. market. The $77-per-American Depositary Receipt deal could be completed in the coming weeks, the report said. Plans then call for relisting the company on one of China's domestic exchanges.

Qihoo is the most recent in a wave of privatizations among China-based companies trading in the U.S. Another China-based issue, Ikang Healthcare (KANG), announced Monday it was being taken private by a group of investors at $22 per ADR.

Among leaders, stocks on the IBD 50 list were quiet ahead of the open. Most of the group remained flat. Among the few gains and losses, all held to less than 1%. The same was true for stocks on IBD's Your Weekly Review list.
Overseas, markets across Asia gained as PMI gauges tracking China's manufacturing and services sectors showed further divergence during the month. European markets were narrowly mixed near midday.
